PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam ACTING SPEAKER (Mrs Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Minister for Communications making a statement to the House forthwith to explain whether he will issue a direction under section 8 of the Postal Services Act 1975 to require the Australian Postal Commission to deliver mail to and from Queensland without interruption to services in accordance with the duties of the Commission laid down under that Act.
Under the Postal Services Act 1975 the functions of the Australian Postal Commission are laid down. Clause 7 (1) of the Act, on page 4, states:

The Commission shall perform its functions in such a manner as will best meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian people for postal services and shall, so far as it is, in its opinion, reasonably practicable to do so, make its postal services available throughout Australia for all people who reasonably require those services.

All people in Australia have been advised that mail services to and from Queensland will be interrupted until the close of business on 13 May. That is not a decision which is outside the responsibility of the Postal Commission. There are ways and means by which mail can be delivered. Indeed my office, in inquiring of the Postal Commission this morning, was told: 'If you wish to get mail to and from Queensland you can use the private services'. There are a number of private companies operating in the field and the time has come for the Government either to remove the monopoly that is now available to Australia Post and ensure that there are alternative ways by which mail can be delivered around Australia or to require Australia Post to fulfil its proper responsibilities. There is no basis by which the people of Australia can be held to ransom simply because the Australian Council of Trade Unions and this Government are not prepared to take actions to provide those public services which a statutory authority, in this instance Australia Post, is called on to provide. Section 8 (1) of the Postal Services Act states:

The Minister may, after consultation with the Commission, give to the Commission, in writing, such directions, with respect to the performance of its functions and the exercise of its powers, as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest.

We contend that this interruption to a public service to the community has gone on long enough. We know that the Government has given lip service to its concern about the blockade of Queensland. However, we know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is, in private, as the Premier of Queensland said this morning, putty in the hands of the power brokers of the ACTU. We know that the Transport Workers Union, the TWU, and unions affiliated with the State rail authority of Queensland have placed bans on all deliveries until midnight on Friday. We know that that is outside the proper exercise of the responsibilities of Australia Post in meeting its obligations under the Postal Services Act. Indeed, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) will recall that, as Postmaster-General in 1975, he was a party to litigation which was determined by the High Court of Australia. He will recall that in the case of Bradley v. the Commonwealth the High Court-in the judgment of the former Chief Justice and the present Chief Justice-decided that no authority exists for the giving of directions in relation to the refusal to deliver mail, in that instance to one particular client.

There are a number of obiter dicta within that judgment which I think are worth canvassing before the House. Page 566 of the High Court judgment by Chief Justice Barwick and the then Mr Justice Gibbs states:

. . . it is right to start from the assumption that if the Parliament intended to confer on the Postmaster-General an arbitrary power, subject to no condition and to no review, to deprive any person of the liberty to use the postal and telephone services, with all the grave consequences that might ensue, it would use clear words for that purpose.
Although the Act has been replaced, that purpose has not been written into the new Act. The judgment continues:

The Act abounds with indications that it is intended that a letter which is properly addressed and stamped and which is received at a post office for transmission and delivery shall be transmitted and delivered to the address indicated or, if letter carriers are not provided, to the nearest post office, except in cases for which express provision is made.

The delivery of mail has been regarded as sacrosanct. This Government is now running away from its prime responsibility to provide services to the Australian public. It is saying to the people of Queensland that it does not matter that the mail services can be disrupted. It is saying: 'We are going to walk away from exercising our responsibility in this instance to give directions to a prime statutory authority to execute its responsibilities'.

We all know the genesis of the dispute in Queensland. There was a power dispute. The reason the people of Australia are so strongly behind the actions of the Queensland Government is that the Queensland Government has said that where there is a public service-in Queensland's instance, the electricity supply-it is prepared to ensure that those services are provided. We have a marked contrast between the Federal Government and the State Government. The Federal Government is saying: 'We do not mind if people do not get the services for which we are responsible'. The Federal Government is responsible for providing all the mail services through the Australian Postal Commission. The Federal Government should take a leaf from the book of the Queensland Premier and be prepared to take the same stance in relation to the provision of services to the people of Australia as the Queensland Government has shown that it is prepared to take with power supply.

It is not good enough for a government that has responsibility for public services to say that it is not prepared to take action to ensure that those services are provided. That is what this motion is all about. The Special Minister of State (Mr Young), who is at the table, has power under the Act to require the Australian Postal Commission to ensure that mail is delivered. The Postal Commission has an obligation to deliver the mail. The High Court has decided in the case to which I referred, as recently as 1975, that that obligation should be met. A government which has a clear obligation cannot now come into the House and say: 'We will wipe our hands of the whole affair'. This is a prime area where the Federal Government can show where its responsibilities lie.

Of course we know that the Prime Minister is a slave to the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the unions. We know that the left wing calls the shots. We know that the Government is not really concerned about interruptions to trade and commerce. We know that it is not worried about the rights of the average citizen. We know that the pensioners do not matter to the Government. We heard the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) yesterday tell us about how the introduction of a new assets test is really in the best interests of the poor. What absolute rubbish! Indeed, in this instance the Government cannot absolve itself from its responsibilities.

There is a clear provision within the Postal Services Act for the Minister to issue directions. The Australian Postal Commission has a responsibility to provide services. We believe that the Minister at the commencement of today's proceedings, in the light of the notice that has been given to the public of Australia, has a responsibility to make a statement in this House to tell the people of Australia that the Australian mail will get through. In the days of the penny post it used to be regarded as sacrosanct.

Section 94 of the Act provides a penalty of 12 months gaol to anyone who obstructs delivery of the mail. Coincidentally, that is the period of imprisonment that precludes a person from entitlement to sit in this Parliament. Under section 94 there is a penalty for people who obstruct the delivery of mail. The Minister has a responsibility. He should tell this House that a direction will be issued to Australia Post so that the mail will get through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The right honourable gentleman's time has expired. Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Last night I went to the Parliament House post office to post some mail to Queensland. It is not surprising that any member from Queensland who presents to the post office letters to be sent to Queensland expects that service to be provided. I have said before, in response to the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), that something should be done about the workings of the post office in Australia. It is not good enough for the Minister to stand around wringing his hands, saying: 'You are really not doing anything, boys. I cannot do anything because my hands are tied. I will leave it to you'. That is what the Minister says about the post office in Australia. The Opposition says: 'Bring back the no work no pay clause. Direct the board of Australia Post to come to terms with its management and set a target date for performance. If there is a failure to perform, fire the board and try again'.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians are sick and tired of having to stand back and have their basic essential services ignored. How many people complain to members of parliament about the services of Australia Post? Complaints come in every day. There would not be anyone in Australia who can genuinely say that he gets a better service from Australia Post today than he did 10 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even the Minister said Australia Post had to lift its game.

—That is right. In response to those complaints we have had nothing but a weak-kneed display from the Minister, who is purely a tool of a government dominated by the trade unions. It is government for the trade unions, by the trade unions and not of the people. That is what has gone wrong. That is why in Queensland today one sees the beginning of the great crack in trade unionism in Australia. It is the antics of the tactics, particularly the lead which is being given by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, which will bring about the downfall of trade unionism in this country if the unions are not careful.

SPEECH.PARA: This incident in relation to the moving of the post within Australia is very important. Australia Post is dominated and run by the trade unions because it has been too fearful to interfere and enforce management. Many millions of dollars have been spent on the production of new techniques and machinery which have been put to one side and totally ignored because of the fear to confront the union management of the day.

The people of Australia have had enough. Members of this Parliament, particularly Queenslanders, have had enough in relation to the mail services in Parliament House. Why should we, as servants of our electorates, be held to ransom by a few trade unionists? It is time that the Minister issued directions to Australia Post to call in private contractors to move the mail to Queensland. The Minister should not allow the circumstances whereby our mail will sit here and not be shifted until next Monday. While this occurs we have a Government which fumbles with the ball. It is not concerned with what goes on in Australia in relation to the services to ordinary people. It is concerned only with delivering to its own particular audience. There would not be any person representing a rural electorate who is not concerned about the appalling services occurring there. The honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) and the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler) must be wondering what is going on in their areas. They are not here at the moment but they are very dependent on how they communicate with their electorates and the services that are provided in those areas. But they are not here this morning to hear this debate and in that way they are not registering their concern to the Government.

This is a matter of great concern to the whole nation. It does not matter whether one lives in Melbourne or Cape York. The Minister of the day must do his job-administer the Act which he is sworn to administer. He has totally failed to do that, he has totally failed the Australian public and the Government has failed the whole of the nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has been agonising in its tactics committee for some days as to what issues it should raise in this Parliament. For the third day in a row the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has been done over. He continues to want to talk about the major issue in Australia, which is tax reform, and all the other wildcats-members of the National Party-overrule him. They even got the poor old member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in today. He was called upon by the Leader of the National Party (Mr Sinclair) to take a leaf out of Joh's book and reluctantly he brought himself to the dispatch box to associate himself with that great Queenslander, the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. The President of the Liberal Party in Queensland finally found an issue upon which he could associate himself with the Premier of Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: We in government are doing exactly the same as the Opposition did when it was in government. There was one thing lacking from the contribution made by the Leader of the National Party in the presentation of this resolution to the House this morning: He did not detail all the actions that were taken by the Liberal and National parties when they were in government and had an industrial dispute in the post office. Did anyone hear any precedents set before the House about the action that they took when the postal services may have been cut off? There was not one illustration of interference by the then Minister. It is highly dubious what powers the Minister has. I call on honourable members not to use the opinion that has been given by the Leader of the National Party; he is not looked upon as a top Queen's Counsel in these areas. His opinions are not widely sought by the community outside and the only reason I can find for his being upset because the postal services to Queensland may have been cut off is that his cheques might not be getting through; he may have sent a lot of letters to Queensland that are not getting through.

This is the second day on which the Opposition has felt that there is some political push in picking on an issue. Yesterday the assets test got priority over taxation; today it is Queensland. These bans or any previous bans that have been imposed by the trade union movement because of the conflict which has been brought about in the South East Queensland Electricity Board have been a direct result of the Queensland Government's decision to sack nearly 1,000 workers and not give them their jobs back. All this Government has said is that there should be some negotiations about the livelihood of those 1,000 people. We are not in fascist Germany or South Africa where 17,000 people have just been sacked recently. We live in a democracy. We do not live in one of those countries where those sorts of actions may be taken unchallenged. There is a challenge to the action that has been taken by the Queensland Government. People all over Australia resent such action.

We do not support the bans that have been imposed by the trade union movement in trying to bring an end to this conflict. We continually say that there must be negotiations between the parties that are affected-the unions, the Queensland Government and Queensland businesses-to try to bring some rationale and sanity back into the situation in Queensland before it goes any further. The contributions that have been made today by the Leader of the National Party and the honourable member for Ryan do nothing to assist. They did nothing in the same circumstances when they were in government. They did not have their Minister for Communications rushing into every industrial dispute that came up in the postal services area or the communications industry in this country. As I said, not one precedent was set by them in this Parliament upon which, perhaps, we could rely for our actions today.

Of course the action has been taken by the trade union movement in order to apply greater pressure on the Queensland Government. Whether or not it succeeds history will tell us. One thing we can be sure of is that the union movement-organised labour-acting in a democracy will not accept that a thousand of its members can be sacked arbitrarily, that their superannuation, their leave, all the payments that may have been due to them from their life-long service to the Board, can just be diminished as a result of an industrial dispute. Sanity will prevail in the long run because the union movement will not allow those laws to creep over the border.

We have seen in this Parliament the members of the National Party and the Liberal Party associate themselves with the worst elements of these laws by saying, quite unilaterally, that at a national level they would do exactly the same as Joh is doing in Queensland. All I can say is that if they ever get the opportunity of doing that in the national Parliament, with the national laws of this country, they will start a bushfire in the industrial relations area the like of which we have not seen since Federation. Hopefully the Australian people will understand what they are promising them. I note that the Leader of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, Mr Greiner, is attracted to the same thing. Liberal leaders all over the country are saying that they would like to do the same as the Queensland Premier has done in Queensland. That is not the way to bring about the sort of economic sanity and economic growth we need in this country to put the kids back to work and to do the sorts of things that we hope to do in this country. It is no good trying to win political points our of this issue. Sooner of later there will have to be negotiations over the turmoil that has been caused by the industrial dispute in the South East Queensland Electricity Board.

For the Opposition to say today that it wants to suspend Standing Orders so that the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) can come in here and give a definition of what powers he may have under the Act is an absolutely useless proposal. Honourable members opposite know that, because they never did anything in a similar situation when they were in government. In spite of their obvious dislike of the trade union movement and their willingness at every opportunity to do something detrimental to the trade union movement, they cannot give one illustration of an occasion when their Minister would have taken the action that they now call upon our Minister to take. As I said, it is highly dubious what powers the Minister may have in an industrial dispute of this nature. In the case of postal services, as in the case of almost every other industry, there are dispute-settling procedures. Obviously the relevant arbitration commission will be trying to get the dispute settled as quickly as possible, because that is part of its task and responsibility.

It cannot be said that the union movement in Australia has not been provoked into taking some of the actions which it is taking today. Unless we get some negotiations on this matter, these disputes might continue. It is not in our interest in government, it is not in the interest of honourable members opposite as parliamentarians and it is not in Australia's interest that this matter should continue, but the Australian people cannot totally ignore the fact that 1,000 people have lost their jobs, their livelihood, and all the benefits that they may have built up, some of these after a lifetime of service to the Board. This has to be taken into account when considering these matters.

Another thing which has to be taken into account is that honourable members opposite have taken a much stronger view on this issue than they did on the doctors going on strike. The doctors' action was a different matter. The right honourable member for New England did not get up here and say: 'Let's get the Minister for Health and see how he can flog the doctors back to work'. It may be that honourable members opposite feel that the doctors vote conservative. But when 1,000 people, who may be Labor supporters, have lost their jobs at the Electricity Board, Opposition members say: 'Let's stick the boot into them'. It is quite a different ball game. It depends on who is involved. We did not find Opposition members a few years ago asking the then Minister for Aviation to kick the pilots when they went on strike. The pilots directed the cut-off of their services directly at members of parliament; they said that they would not fly parliamentarians in or out of Canberra because of the action the Parliament had taken on lump sum superannuation. We did not have the right honourable member for New England at that time saying to the Minister for Aviation: 'Let's lock up the pilots'. It is a question of who is in the group. The precedent is who might be in the group and where their political allegiances might lie. If their political allegiances lie with the majority, the Australian Labor Party, Opposition members want to kick them. But, if they happen to be an elite conservative group, like the pilots or the doctors, Opposition members want to be silent. They behave like Marcel Marceau; they put their hands over their mouths and forget to say anything. They have no conscience at all.

Let me conclude on this point: The Government does not support the bans, but the Government is taking the same action as the previous Government took. The previous Minister did not take action. It is highly dubious whether a Minister has power to interfere in an industrial dispute of this nature. It is to be hoped that sooner or later there will be negotiations in Queensland which will bring some sanity back into this area.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 April, on motion by Mr Cohen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this legislation for the introduction of a public lending right in legislative form. The public lending right is a scheme designed to compensate writers for multiple use of their works held in Australian public lending libraries. The scheme was originally pioneered in the Scandinavian countries of Denmark and Sweden in the early 1950s. In those countries payments to writers were based on annual returns made by each library showing every book by a native writer either on its shelves or in storage. Books with more than one writer are, in some countries, not eligible for the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia and New Zealand were the first English speaking countries to implement the public lending right. The campaign for this began in 1966 when it was led by the Australian Society of Authors. A survey at the time showed most writers' income to be well below the average minimum wage in Australia. Some writers believed that they were regarded as public property, like parks, gardens or public utilities with the notable exception, in the case of the writer's product, that the public did not have to pay.

Although the public library system has helped considerably in exposing Australian writers to the Australian public prior to the public lending right being introduced, they effectively received no recompense from that source. This situation was obviously unfair to writers because comparable artists, such as composers of music, did receive a royalty every time their work was performed in public. By depriving writers of book sales, the library system made it difficult to earn a living from writing in this country. This must have proved a major disincentive to aspiring writers and in 1973 the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, directed the Literature Board of the Australian Council for the Arts to implement this program. A committee of inquiry was established, convened by the Literature Board's Chairman, Geoffrey Blainey, a noted Australian historian. The committee included representatives of the Board, writers' organisations and publishers and librarians, as well as an observer from the Department of the Attorney-General.

In 1974 a PLR committee began to implement and administer the scheme through a body called the Australian Authors Fund. The first PLR program began in 1975, and the following year its administration passed to the Australia Council-the successor to the Australian Council for the Arts-with members of the existing committee continuing under a new chairman. The scheme was transferred to the predecessor of the Department of Arts, Heritage and Environment in 1980, following changes to the Australia Council Act.

In order to be eligible for payment under the public lending right a writer must be an Australian citizen resident either in Australia or elsewhere, or must be normally resident in this country. The writer should have his work registered in the Australian National Bibliography entry. Australian writers are eligible even if their works are not published in Australia. When a writer registers for PLR he or she is paid 70c for each book held in public lending libraries, while publishers of Australian works receive 17.5c in the dollar. In 1984 the PLR scheme cost $1,435,000, of which $1,156,000 went to 3,910 writers and $279,000 to 255 publishers. It will be seen, therefore, if that is averaged out, that the actual amounts involved are very small. In January 1985 there were approximately 5,800 claimants, and 21,600 book records are being held.

Unlike the payments made in some Scandinavian countries, payments to Australian writers are not based on borrowings; they are based on annual book stocks held in public libraries surveyed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Approximately 60 libraries are surveyed and the data gathered from the survey is consolidated and used to produce estimates of holdings throughout the country.

The PLR represents a public acknowledgment of the writers who bring so much pleasure and learning to the Australian community. The scheme should be regarded as a right, not as a gift. It is a means of which Australian writers can achieve greater financial independence. Authorship must become a profession like any other, subject of course to market forces and public interest, and it should be, wherever possible, less vulnerable to the changing climate of sponsorship or grants. We are seeking to develop a system of reward for writers of excellence. Their success should thus be tied directly to public appreciation through sales of their work.

Writers have long decried their insecure status in the Australian society. Henry Lawson, for example, gave aspiring writers depressing advice when he recommended that, before beginning to write, they should shoot themselves carefully with the aid of a looking glass. The position of the creative writer in Australia's early history was in fact a difficult one. Lawson became a hopeless alcoholic, Adam Lindsay Gordon shot himself-taking that earlier advice-while Barcroft Boake hanged himself with a stock whip.

While one hopes that the situation has improved, the question has to be asked: Is today's writer much better off? A popular misconception is that Australian writers are the recipients of great fortunes. Some people believe that if a writer has one best seller his future is assured. On the contrary, statistics gathered by the Literature Board of the Australia Council indicate that most Australian writers may be better described as being an acutely impoverished minority. For example, for the average novel selling some 2,500 copies, the 10 per cent royalty for the author comes to about $3,250, and that may be for two years work. An Australia Council report claimed that only 5 per cent of writers surveyed made more than $6,000 from royalties in 1982, while a further 4 per cent made more than $6,000 from grants and fellowships. Such earnings do not exactly represent a realistic income, let alone a fortune.

Another popular misconception is that good writing requires little time or mental effort. In truth, it probably takes at least six months-usually longer-to complete a full length novel of any virtue. We still have 10 Australian Prime Ministers, for example, for whom no biographies have been written. A major biography such as that may require three years to research and complete. It is worth noting that most work of this nature has been done by academics who are already receiving subsidies through the institutions for which they work. We can hardly expect an independent writer to devote approximately three years and probably the equivalent of $90,000 of otherwise employed time to a biography for which the rewards are uncertain.

The sad fact is that for the overwhelming majority of writers it is impossible to exist as a full time writer in Australia under the present conditions. The Literature Board attempts to redress writers' problems by providing direct assistance through writers' fellowships, research grants and emeritus fellowships, formerly known as literary pensions. The Board allocated 62 per cent of its 1983-84 funds to programs supporting initial creativity. It aims to help writers buy time to pursue their work from gestation through to the completion of manuscripts.

In 1984 the Board awarded grants to 131 individual writers through the aforementioned three programs. For these some 692 applied, with a success rate of 19 per cent. The Board admitted in its 1983-84 annual report that under current funding levels it cannot even provide writers with income parity relative to those professions it believes comparable, such as journalists, teachers and mid-range public servants. It is worth noting, I think, that in 1973 a fellowship was worth $9,000. In retrospect that was probably too high compared with relative wages. At the same time a Federal parliamentary backbencher's salary was $9,500. By June 1983 a fellowship was worth $18,750 and a backbencher's salary was $36,000, a level comparable to that of the lower ranks of the Second Division of the Australian Public Service. I hope the Government, in its next Budget, will consider sympathetically the difficulties faced by the Australia Council in its ability to fund adequately the Literature Board to overcome some of these problems. In 1985 the Board is providing two grants to new writers: The new writers' fellowship for developing writers, a grant of some $17,000, which requires the recipient to leave full time employment and devote themselves completely to the work of writing; and the new writers' assistance grant of $8,000, which may be regarded as a part-time salary.

If we are to develop greater cultural independence and not be subject to excessive cultural colonialism, as has been the case in the past, further consideration must be given by government and the private sector to see what additional support should be provided to encourage the development of Australian writers. The Literature Board has also provided subsidies for local publishers to ensure the availability of Australian works of literary merit. It has also contributed indirectly, through royalties, to the incomes of writers. Those of us who have ever put pen to paper-for example, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) and the honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman)-would be conversant with the fact that creative thought cannot be forced, that a train of thought born at midday, for example, cannot be easily resurrected by 7 or 8 o'clock in the evening after a hard day's work in one's other occupation. We expect professionally written books from part-time writers, and this is perhaps in many cases asking too much.

What is required is the political will to address the problems facing Australian writers and publishers to see what can be done to assist them both to become more self-reliant. There is no reason why government should be the writer's main benefactor. That is surely the responsibility of the market-place as a whole. The possibility of private enterprise participating in promoting Australian authorship should not be overlooked. The Americans have successfully institutionalised private enterprise support for writers through such bastions as the Rockefeller Foundation and the Ford Foundation. In terms of the bicentenary, I see no reason why private enterprise should not be encouraged to sponsor a bicentenary literary fund. Such a fund may follow the guidelines prescribed by the Literature Board of the Australia Council, providing grants and fellowships to Australian writers, and of course the funds contributed would be tax deductible. Until recently, culture has taken a back seat in the overall development of Australia. It is time that company sponsorship of the arts was directed to Australian writers, who contribute so vitally to our cultural development.

Many industries benefit from the product of the writer, and perhaps none so obviously as the film and television industry. The Australian author may be said to be the nucleus around which our film industry evolved. So important to the film industry is the novelist that the Australian Film Institute employs a writer to read all Australian novels and report on each one's film potential. Many of our better known and internationally successful films and mini-series have been based on Australian literature. For example My Brilliant Career by Miles Franklin, Thorn Birds by Colleen McCullough, The Year of Living Dangerously by Chris Koch. Bliss, a new film based on the book of the same name by Peter Carey, has been invited to participate in the Cannes Film Festival. The internationally respected Australian director, Peter Weir, had his first success from Picnic at Hanging Rock by Joan Lindsay.

It seems ludicrous that writers who are regarded as the grass roots of our film industry can frequently expect less than 10 per cent of the wages received by the scriptwriter who adapts the original work for the screen. The picture, however, is not entirely grim. An author can increase his or her income by being included as a script adviser, but it is doubtful that this would approximate the $75,000 to $125,000 often received by some script writers. This is but another example where authors are not being adequately recompensed for their work. We have to acknowledge that the written medium has been upstaged by radio and television, especially the latter in terms of mass audiences. Nevertheless, all media to a very large extent are still dependent upon the quality of the original written work. There is much criticism of the quality of Australian soap operas, usually because of the weakness of the plot and the failure to develop the characters sufficiently. Much of this can be directly attributed to our inability to develop the capacity to write good scripts, and it is worth noting that the best are often taken from works by Australian authors.

There can be no doubt that to improve the writer's and publisher's lot we need to become more competitive in the international market. It is the responsibility of Australian writers to produce material of high standard for which there will be local and international demand. It is government's role to establish secure structures through which writers can achieve their artistic and financial independence. Australia has a population of some 15 million and one of the highest literacy rates in the world, but we have a maximum potential English speaking readership about the size of the population of Sweden. However, unlike the Swedish author, the Australian author has to compete with books imported from other English speaking countries, notably Great Britain and the United States. Imported books make up 51 per cent of the Australian market. Something like 75,000 new titles a year are published in Britain and the United States and many if not most of these, are available here. Britain's publishing industry could not possibly exist in a domestic market of 56 million people. That is why they have to export, and the same can be said for the United States of America and Canada. The small Australian domestic market prevents industry from introducing economies of scale which would assist in lowering costs overall. It costs approximately 10 per cent more to produce a book in Australia than it does in some of our neighbouring countries. Fifty per cent of Australian books are currently being published overseas. However, this legislation should go some way towards encouraging change in this situation to the advantage of the Australian publishing industry.

The important fact must be emphasised that much of the cost factors in the Australian market are to be attributed to the fact that we have a regulated labour market, where the publishing industry effectively is controlled by one trade union, and it is there that the Australian industry is so different from overseas competition, especially in South East Asia. The percentage costs of publishing the average book in Australia are as follows: Royalty to authors, 10 per cent; editing, 10 per cent; design, 6 per cent; typesetting, 10 per cent; printing, 21 per cent; overheads-electricity, rent and so forth-9 per cent; transport, about 7 per cent; marketing, 15 per cent; and profit before tax, 12 per cent. The need to develop an export oriented market could be the key to establishing a mature and vital Australian publishing industry. But, as I mentioned earlier, it will require a much closer relationship between the trade unions involved in the industry, writers and publishers, to achieve what is obviously a common good, that is, to remain competitive both in Australia and overseas. Writers' earnings are limited by a small domestic market and overseas sales are thus essential if we are to see more successful authors such as Colleen McCullough with her Thorn Birds, which sold millions of copies.

The export of Australian novels is increasing, and some of our novelists have enjoyed great overseas success-this is a great credit to them-in both English and non-English speaking countries. For example, Nancy Cato's All the Rivers Run has been translated into French, with 360,000 copies being released in France alone. Rodney Hall's Just Relations has enjoyed success in the United States, Britain and France. David Malouf's novel An Imaginary Life has been translated into French and Norwegian. The mini-series 1915, based on the book of the same name by Roger McDonald, has been sold to some 37 countries.

The current economic climate will force the Australian film and television industry to rely more on local productions, and this should help the Australian author. Costly foreign soap operas and productions will soon lose their appeal for programmers, who may well have to pay in excess of 20 per cent on existing costs because of the recent devaluation of the Australian dollar. The devaluation will mean increases of between 20 to 50 per cent in the program costs of the three Australian television networks which currently commit about $US120m between them annually on the purchase of overseas programs. There may be some good news for local production houses with increased demand for Australian-made programs which rely so heavily upon the talent and creativity of Australian writers. Therefore, it should undoubtedly be in the interests of the film and television industry to encourage excellence in Australian writing.

It is obvious that we have the potential to export. The question should be asked as to how we can internationally promote our writers. The Literature Board has gone some way towards promoting Australian writers overseas with some creditable success, given the available resources. However, as the Literature Board receives only 6 per cent of total Australia Council funding, it is clear to me that the publicity industry, in particular, and the publishing industry, which usually has affiliated companies in most major English-speaking capitals, have a major role to play in this area.

The second reading speech of the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) noted that the present deficiencies in the public lending rights scheme in terms of the accountability of expenditure of public funds allocated to it 'induce great uncertainty among various literary interest groups'. We were surprised, therefore, to see that under the Public Lending Right Bill 1985 the Minister may, by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, approve the rate of payment to Australian authors and publishers. Under such arrangements there is, therefore, the risk that the rate of payment to authors and publishers may be subject to ministerial change entirely at the Minister's discretion and therefore not be subject to parliamentary review. In view of the fact that this legislation was introduced for the specific purpose of giving security to Australian writers, the Opposition believes that there is a strong case for an amendment to this clause. Therefore, at the appropriate time during the Committee stage of this Bill I shall move an amendment that clause 5 of the Public Lending Right Bill be altered to allow alterations in the rate of payment to be fixed by regulation and to be subject to parliamentary approval.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my remarks by commending the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) on his interesting and informative speech. A lot of the information included in it would be quite useful for many people looking at the field of literature in Australia today.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction of the Public Lending Right Bill 1985 into this House means that another tick can be put beside the list of election commitments fulfilled by the Hawke Labor Government. Whilst the latest commitment was made at the 1983 election, it is not new. It is now 10 years or more since the Australian Authors Fund Bill was drafted by the Whitlam Government to establish a statutory base for the then public lending rights scheme. Unfortunately, as with many incentives that were on the drawing board and in operation at that time, this legislation was discarded along with a very large portion of our pride and privilege as a democratic nation on 11 November 1975.

Since that time, in the typical, slack administrative manner of the Liberal-National Party Fraser Government, the public lending rights scheme has operated without a clear basis and without truly effective practices of accountability and authority. It is nice to see the Opposition now joining the Hawke socialist Government-as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is so fond of calling this most successful and effective Government-in support of this Bill, despite its foreshadowed amendment. It is about time the Opposition supported a Bill such as this. It has had plenty of time to do it-10 years or more. Unfortunately, this is another example of the big talkers that Opposition members seem to be in opposition when they have such an appalling record in government, whether it be in any of the areas of tax avoidance and evasion, unemployment, inflation, defence, industry development, road and transport funding, youth and crisis accommodation, education, housing and, particularly, the arts. The former Government was not a credible government in the area of the arts or in many other areas for that matter. Because of that, as much as anything else, I believe that it is not so effective in opposition today.

Fiscally, this Bill is only a very minor piece of legislation. It controls the expenditure of only about $1.78m. However, behind it is a clear commitment to the arts which has not been seen since the Whitlam years. The Whitlam period was a very rare period of cultural development and soul in this country. While researching this speech for today I looked back to 1976 when the Fraser Government was introducing the Australia Council Amendment Bill into this House, a Bill which covered the Australian Authors Fund as it was known then. Mr Tony Whitlam, the member for Grayndler at the time, spoke on the Bill and pointed out that the Budget allocation for the Australian Authors Fund was only $300,000 and that the rates at that stage, 1976, had not been altered since 1973. That reflects a point in the speech by the honourable member for Bradfield, who showed his concern for the recompense to authors which the previous Government was not prepared to follow at the time. When the Liberal-National Party Government left office in 1983, with this country clearly in economic chaos, the value of payments on public lending rights was only $1.227m, certainly an improvement on the figure of $300,000 for 1976-77. However, considering the ravaging inflation Australia suffered in those years, it was a very meagre effort.

By direct comparison, with inflation clearly under control, the Hawke Labor Government in two Budgets, not in seven Budgets, has raised the value from $1.3m to a budgeted expenditure for this year of $1.78m. That is just a clear symptom of this Government's fine record in the arts. In the last two Budgets the Hawke Labor Government was working to peg back the effects of the disastrous monetarist policies of the former Liberal-National Government, the remnants of which now sit opposite. Even chained with that burden, the Hawke Labor Government has been able to restore arts funding in Australia to almost two-thirds of the 1975-76 level-the most highly regarded Hayden Budget. Part of that increase in arts funding has been to the public lending rights scheme, which today we are seeking to protect with its own legislation-this Bill.

When in government, the Liberal-National Party coalition had plenty of opportunities to strengthen our nation's literary arts and industries. It is fair to say that it clearly failed. It is worth noting that Australia, again under the Whitlam Government, was the second government in the English-speaking world-after our tenacious little neighbour, New Zealand, did so in 1973-to attempt to introduce such a scheme.

Public lending rights now return to our writers and publishers some recompense for the fact that their works are available without direct cost to the consumer, through public lending libraries, to many millions of Australians who would otherwise be in the market to purchase their works directly. This is another example of the clear recognition of the Australian Labor Party of the value of our cultural heritage, our authors, publishers and workers in the publishing industry, such as the members of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union. It is also fitting that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) introduced this Bill during Heritage Week this year.

Our literature is one of the most vital and immortal aspects of our heritage. Our National Library has a magnificent collection of illuminated manuscripts which are the heritage of other nations of a hundred years, a thousand or more years gone by, works produced in the Dark Ages and Middle Ages by artisans who might have spent their lifetimes producing a single work. Our own culture contained Aboriginal art, an art that goes back thousands of years and, in many places, further than the time of the illuminated manuscripts which adorn our National Library. We should be seeking to protect that art as a very important aspect of our culture and heritage. Today, with the power of the printing press and the ability and opportunity of so many more people to read and enjoy literature, the world is a very different place than it was 10 years ago, 100 years ago or 1,000 years ago. Australian literary works and artists-our authors, illustrators and printing tradespeople-deserve our greatest respect. We must protect their work and the heritage they produce for us, just as we protect and value the heritage of the illuminated manuscripts of other ages and exotic cultures in our National Library.

The public lending rights scheme and the 4,500 or more artists and publishers it supports-albeit in a small way-is now protected by this legislation as it has been waiting to be for 11 years or so. It is not coincidence that matters of such value must wait until Labor governments are elected for such progress to be made in our heritage and culture. Just as we now seek to protect or enhance the rights of our literary workers to be recompensed for their product which is available to most citizens through public lending libraries, so we must now direct our attention to areas of art that today's technology has now opened up to a wider community. One could almost call it electronic literature or electronic art.

Just as Caxton brought information, enjoyment and culture to the world with the invention of the printing press and Edison extended the world of music from the elite orchestral concert hall to the common family living room, a world which today has been further extended by the portable tape recorder, the stage-live theatre-has been transformed to the movie screen and, with recent technology, to the video cassette. That opens up new problems for our artists. It is estimated that every recording produced is reproduced two and a half times by pirate or private taping. Movies also can be pirated by parasitic entrepreneurs or private individuals from video cassette to video cassette.

There is no real recompense or protection for Australian musical artists who lose income through retaping of their works. There is no real compensation or protection for Australian film artists or film makers whose work is pirated through commercial or private copyright abuse. This is a dilemma for this Government, for the Opposition and for the general community. I urge the Government, in considering this Bill and the arts and artists in Australia, to address itself to this problem so that our cultural electronic industries can be developed and protected from such parasitism.

Let me make the point, before the Opposition calls for the Government to protect the industry from the public purse, that, unlike public lending libraries, which are a publicly funded service to the community, musical recordings, tapes and video tapes are very much more the property of the individual. Whether an amount is built in to the price of the product from the outset, or there is a regulated add-on to protect copyright, is a matter for consideration, but we should all be aware of the extent of the problem and the restrictions it places upon the development of our new cultures, new heritage and new industries. Australian movies, videos and music recordings can rapidly flow across to international markets, as so many have successfully done over the past decade or so. Australians are very proud to see the way in which their films and music have reached into the international markets.

The problem with Australian literature, as has been pointed out, is that published books have a very much smaller and restricted market in Australia. They are in competition with works in the most widely read language in the world-English-and in competition with huge quantities of cheap books from overseas, as the honourable member for Bradfield pointed out. Australian publishers face the problem of getting books into many outlets, such as newsagencies. This Bill goes a long way towards providing order and justice for authors and publishers. By 'author', I mean anyone who has made a substantial contribution to the development of an Australian book; the writer, illustrator, translator, compiler or editor. The requirement that the person be an Australian citizen or a resident of Australia will mean that the vast majority of the public lending rights payments will remain in Australia to further encourage and develop Australian literature.

The arts have always been an important facet of our lives, whether or not we have been fully aware of them. In so many ways the arts are an expression of our society and times. The Liberal-National Party Government concentrated its arts expenditure, I am sad to say, on the so-called areas of excellence, such as opera and ballet. That was to the great detriment of community-based art forms available to the common person. The common person could never afford the highly priced art forms of opera and ballet, where there is a $45 subsidy from the taxpayer on every seat. This Government is very concerned that the arts funding reaches out to all Australians, so that all Australians will be free to participate in, enjoy and contribute to our cultural heritage.

This legislation is essential in order that Australian literary works may continue to grow and enrich our lives. The Public Lending Right Bill 1985 is a long-awaited and valuable piece of legislation. I believe it should be passed as presented by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the opening remarks of the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples), I had to ask myself whether this was an animated mummy who had been disinterred from some crypt, since he painted a picture of the Australian literary and cultural scene which would have us believe that nothing at all was done by the previous Government in this area. Might I remind him of three or four actions by the previous Government: First, the introduction of extremely generous-to my mind, far too generous-tax incentives for the Australian film industry; second, the implementation of the building of the Australian Art Gallery-a very expensive project which, had we been the Philistines he sought to paint us, we would have no doubt knocked on the head; third, the extensions to the Australian War Memorial; and, fourth, setting in train the Australian Museum.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been said by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the Opposition supports the Bill. It is grounded in justice and it provides for compensation to authors for loss of potential income. Authors are not highly paid. Their income is intermittent and their effective working life is variable. It is notorious that some authors write themselves out at a very early stage; that inspiration dries up, and originality of conception becomes harder to summon up. It is only right that they should be compensated for the use of their books which are borrowed from public libraries. That is a use which is probably increasing, so that there is all the more need for the kind of scheme at which the House is looking now, which has been in place in an administrative form for some time. I know that the Australian Society of Authors welcomes the scheme. I have spoken to the Society which believes-and I think it is right-that it is better and more secure that this kind of scheme should be on a statutory basis.

I have a personal interest in compensation to authors for the use of their works when those works are not bought over the counter from a book shop. In 1975 I appeared as junior counsel for the University of New South Wales in the case of Moorhouse v. University of New South Wales. Some copying had taken place of a work of Mr Moorhouse at the University of New South Wales. Action was brought for infringement of copyright. The High Court of Australia eventually declared that copyright had been infringed. That is an example of an author-backed by the Australian Society of Authors-who took action to protect his own work and livelihood.

The rates of payment under the existing scheme will need to be looked at. I am sure the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) has those in mind. If one looks at what has happened, it is apparent that the authors have been losing out over the years. In 1975 the rates of payment per book were 50c for the author and 12.5c for the publisher; in 1983 they were raised to 60c for the author and 15c for the publisher; in 1984 they were 66c for the author and 16.5c for the publisher; and in 1984-85 they were 70c for the author and 17.5c for the publisher. I do not suggest for a moment that we should seek compulsorily to link the benefits provided by the scheme to the consumer price index, but it is perfectly plain that it is only just that compensation should take account of movements in the CPI so that the authors and publishers-but mainly the authors-are justly compensated for what is an actual loss of income, because when people go to public lending libraries and borrow books they do that in preference to buying the books.

There are one or two questions I want to raise with the Minister. The first is the length of the appointment of the Public Lending Right Committee. The Committee is set up to administer the scheme and, as I understand it, members can be appointed for up to eight years. It seems to me that an eight-year tenure is too long and I would be glad to have the Minister's views on that.

The second question arises out of the particular provision in clause 5 (4) (d) which, in effect, provides that where an author dies, the widow, widower or child of the deceased author or a person having relationship or association with the deceased author of a kind specified in a scheme is entitled to certain benefits under the scheme. I have no quarrel with the rights of people in this country to enter into whatever relationship they wish to do so-that is entirely a personal decision-but I do wish to know whether it is the intention of the Government that benefits under the scheme should go, for example, to de facto homosexual partners. What kind of relationship will the scheme extend to? We should know this. The Minister must have clearly in mind the kind of relationships that will be brought within the confines of the scheme and will receive the benefits under the scheme. For my part, I hope that it is not a case of the Government being afraid to describe in detail and to tell us who these beneficiaries will be. We are entitled to know this. We are voting on this Bill and we should know what we are voting on. We should know what kind of relationships will come within the scheme which will be promulgated by the Minister.

My next question relates to the scheme itself. Clause 5 of the Bill provides that the Minister may, with certain specific limitations, by notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, approve a scheme and modify the scheme so approved. We do not know what kinds of schemes will be put for our approval. I would have thought it was perfectly simple to state in general terms in the Bill or to the House today the general outline of these schemes, even if the detail of particular matters has to be dealt with by gazettal or by regulation. It is, after all, asking the House to vote in support of a proposal which has, as a central part of it, a scheme about which we do not yet know. I ask the Minister to tell the House the general nature of the scheme that he will propose.

My last point is this: The scheme applies only to public libraries; it does not apply to universities or schools. I know that the Australian Society of Authors wants an investigation into the extension of the scheme to universities and schools. I do not express a view one way or another on the merits of whether the scheme should be extended to schools and universities. That may be something that the Minister has looked at. I would be very glad to hear his views on the subject and whether he believes it is worth while examining the question without, at this stage, expressing a view on behalf of the Government one way or the other. I wholly support the general concept that there should be a statutory code or statutory rights for authors so that they can be compensated for the use of their books when otherwise they would be compensated by the sale of those books.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor governments have a long-standing commitment to the arts. This is nowhere more evident than with the introduction of the Public Lending Right Bill. The public lending right scheme was originally introduced by the Whitlam Government in 1974. It is in accordance with Australian Labor Party policy and it is yet another reminder today of the major commitments made and introduced during the Whitlam years. The campaign to introduce the scheme was launched by the then Vice President of the Australian Society of Authors in 1963, Mr Simpson. Despite receiving promises from the McMahon Government to introduce the scheme-one of the many promises the McMahon Government made and failed to keep-it was not until 1972 when Gough Whitlam put public lending rights in Labor's 1972 election policy that Australian authors saw a real commitment by government.

SPEECH.PARA: After being introduced in 1974, the scheme operated initially under the Australian Authors Fund Committee as a prelude to the passing of the Australian Authors Fund Bill. As with much of the reform legislation of the Whitlam years, that Bill lapsed with the 1975 dissolution. I suppose it is fair to recognise that the Fraser Government continued the scheme but on an administrative basis, funding the scheme with the heritage, arts and environment appropriations. Whatever recognition may be given to the Fraser Government for continuing the scheme, it must be pointed out that that Government, despite strong pressures over those years to formally establish the scheme as a guarantee of continuation, failed to do so. It has taken another Labor Government, the Hawke Labor Government, to take up the 1972 policy commitment and to formalise the Labor Party's commitment to the principle of public lending rights.

This scheme supplements the Copyright Act which protects authors from unauthorised use of their publications and which also makes payment for the use of those works. Since 1982, that Act has given authors a right to payment for multiple copies of their works made in educational institutions. This Bill will formalise a system of paying authors and publishers fees for their books stocked by public libraries and should be seen as supplemental to those 1982 amendments to the Copyright Act. The system originated in Scandinavian countries in 1946, but it has been advocated successfully by authors in only a few other countries. It should be emphasised that the scheme is limited to Australian authors and publishers. The Bill provides for payment at the present rate of 70c a year for each copy of an author's book held by a public library, provided the number exceeds 50. Publishers will also be compensated at the present rate of 17.5c a book.

It is of interest to note, after listening to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) pointing out his Party's commitment to the arts, that when the scheme was established in 1974 the author's rate was 50c a book and the publisher's rate 12.5c. It took the Opposition in government six years to increase the rate to 60c to authors and 15c to publishers. In 1983, less than a year after Labor gained government, the rate was increased to 66c to authors and 16.5c to publishers. As I have indicated, the rate is now 70c for authors and 17.5c for publishers. That indicates the real commitment that this Government has to the arts as opposed to the hypocrisy that we hear from honourable members opposite. I should point out that the Australian Museum is a Labor Government initiative and that the National Gallery got off the ground during the Whitlam years. I do not see any commitment from the Opposition on those principal projects for the arts in Australia. Without question, the record and attitude of the Labor Party stand in direct contrast to the platitudes of the Opposition.

Entitlement to public lending rights expires on the death of the author or 50 years after a book's first publication. After death, entitlements will continue to be paid to an entitled author's spouse or children for the remainder of the 50-year period. That marks a fundamental change to the original 1974 scheme, which limited payment to spouses and dependent children. I am concerned about the present provision in the Bill. It seems to me fundamental that an entitlement provided for by a statutory enactment should create a proprietary right for an author that could be passed on in his will or left as any other asset can be left through the law of succession. This is not provided for in this Bill. I hope that some time in the future this matter will be looked at and some change will be made.

If an author has a proprietary right under the Copyright Act which is carried on after his death, I see no reason why under the Public Lending Right Bill the same position should not apply, why on his death that proprietary right should not be an asset of his estate which he may leave in his will to be distributed to, say, literary foundations or other institutions, just as he can with any other assets that he may have.

There is not much that I wish to add to that. I believe that the Bill has been very well covered by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the honourable member for North Sydney and the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples). The fundamentals have been adequately explained. I am proud to see that by putting statutory effect to this fundamental proposal the Hawke Labor Government is following the example set and fulfilling the promises made in the Whitlam years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I wish to pick up some of the comments that have been made in this debate on the Public Lending Right Bill. First of all, I commend all the speakers who have spoken in this debate. We had a very thoughtful contribution from the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I apologise for not being here when he spoke, but I was asked to go to meet Fess Parker of Daniel Boone and Davey Crockett fame and, unfortunately, due to the fog, I was delayed in getting back. I heard part of the shadow Minister's contribution and I congratulate him on it-not that I agree with everything in it. It was a very thoughtful speech. He has obviously done a lot of work on this subject since the Public Lending Right Bill was introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to congratulate the honourable member for Jagajaga (Mr Staples). I congratulate also the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) and, of course, the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). I particularly congratulate the honourable member for Jagajaga, who has been extraordinarily interested in this Bill. He has been to see me about it a number of times. He made the very important point that, while minor criticism of the Bill has been made by the speakers on the Government side, in the 7 1/2 years that the Opposition was in government nothing was done to extend the scheme to provide a statutory basis for it. The public lending right scheme was introduced by the Whitlam Government and it has been extended considerably by the Hawke Labor Government, so I really do not think that honourable members opposite are in a position to throw too many brickbats on this issue.

A number of questions were raised. I understand the honourable member for Bradfield will move an amendment at the Committee stage. I will deal with that later. A question was raised by the honourable member for North Sydney about the appointment of members to the Public Lending Right Committee for a term of up to eight years. This period is a little longer than normal-three to six years is more usual. The reason for this proposal is that there is a need to build up expertise in this area to fully understand it. I am not sure that many people will stay on the Committee for eight years, but the major reason for this proposal is that it is a highly skilled area and specialist people are required for it.

Incidentally, I notice that present in the gallery today is one of Australia's distinguished librarians. I refer to Mr Harrison Bryan, who is about to retire. I am delighted that he is here. He has done great public service to this country. Naturally, he is very interested in this Bill.

A question was raised about de facto homosexual relationships. To be perfectly frank, we do not take people's sexual preferences into account. It is irrelevant to us. Another question was asked about how the scheme will operate. It will operate as it has done for the last 10 years. Without going into all the details of it--

TALK.START.PARA: —Without proposing any real changes?

—No. The essence of this Bill is to enshrine the scheme in legislation so that it will be difficult for future governments to change it without repealing legislation. At the moment it is simply a Budget item. Having been through a number of Budgets now, I understand the process. As a Budget item it would be much easier for a government suddenly to decide to do away with it. No government will be able to do away with this without repealing the legislation, which would be a much more difficult thing to do. Questions were asked about expanding the scheme to take into account universities and other places. That may be a possibility in the future but it is a question of funds, of what moneys are available. At the moment it is not being considered. It may be considered in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Minister, in his speech, raised the question of scriptwriting. It is not really relevant to this Bill, but I totally agree with what he said. We have a deficiency in that area. I am moving away from the subject of the Bill, but this is something that the Australian Film Commission is very conscious of. Earlier this year a scriptwriters' conference was held in Melbourne. I went to it, not because I could make a great contribution to it but simply because I wanted to indicate to the industry that I was extremely interested. One of the major problems of the film industry is that the quality of scripts universally is not as high as it could be. So I completely agree with the honourable member for Bradfield. That is something we will be working on.

I will not go into the whole debate about who did what to whom regarding the arts. I think that this Government and the previous Labor Government have a very proud record. I am not sure that we can take all the credit for the Australian National Gallery. I believe we can take credit for the Museum of Australia. However, I do not think the debate ought to be about who did what in the past. I thank honourable members for their contributions. We will see what will happen from now on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, line 4, omit from the definition of 'scheme' 'approved', substitute 'determined'.
(2) Clause 5, page 2, lines 24-27, omit sub-clause (1), substitute the following sub-clauses:
'(1) The Minister may, by instrument in writing- (a) determine a scheme for and in relation to the making of payments to persons in respect of books; and
(b) determine modifications to the scheme determined pursuant to paragraph (1).

'(1A) Sections 48, 49, 49A and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 apply in relation to determinations under sub-section (1) as if in those sections references to regulations were referenced to determinations, references to a regulation were references to a determination and references to a repeal were references to a revocation.'
(3) Clause 5, page 2, line 28, omit 'approve', substitute 'determine'.
(4) Clause 5, page 2, line 35, omit 'approving', substitute 'determining'.

The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) was aware, from my earlier discussions with him, that the Opposition would move a substantive amendment to clause 5 of the Public Lending Right Bill. We have done this, really, to add substance to the remarks made by the Minister, both a few minutes ago in this House in response to comments made by other speakers in debate on the Bill and in his second reading speech. The Minister said in his second reading speech:

The scheme has lacked a coherent framework of accountability for the expenditure of public funds allocated to it, and a clear source of authority for the decisions of the Public Lending Right Committee.
He went on to say:

These deficiencies have also induced great uncertainty among the various literary interest groups, which have maintained strong pressure for formal establishment of the scheme as a guarantee of its continuation.

Those latter words are the ones upon which I put the most emphasis. A few moments ago the Minister said that it would be difficult to change the public lending right scheme without amending the legislation. I have put to him before, and I do so again finally in this House, that while it is true that the legislation would remain on the statute books for an indefinite period, depending entirely on the intentions of the Parliament, there is no doubt that clause 5 as it is currently constituted gives the Minister virtually absolute power to change the scheme significantly simply by a notice published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

Clause 5 quite clearly states that the Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette, approve a scheme for and in relation to the making of payments to persons in respect of books, and modify the scheme so approved. It does not even say 'the scheme'-that is, this piece of legislation; it simply says 'a scheme'. The concept of modification opens up, I believe, an extraordinarily wide range of initiatives, not necessarily for the current Minister, who I have no doubt is interested in this subject, but for any future Minister of any future government effectively to emasculate this program without going anywhere near the Parliament. It was simply for that reason that we put forward this amendment to ensure that if that did occur in the future, it would be up to the Parliament to determine whether it believed the amendments so proposed were consistent with the overall purpose and spirit of the legislation.

I am surprised to be advised by the Government that it does not wish to accept this amendment. Frankly, I suspect that it is again an example of a bureaucratic desire to have in place legislation which is sufficiently flexible to enable public servants effectively to control the manner in which the spirit and desires of this Parliament are to be carried through both in terms of regulation and of the effect they may have on those sections of the community which are meant to benefit from them.

In my final observation, I remind the Minister that, as he so rightly said in his speech, it is the Australian writers who have for some years asked for a degree of certainty as a guarantee of the continuation of this program. If the Government is to put in place legislation which effectively means that, subject only to the budgetary process, this or any future Minister could significantly alter both the method and substance of payment and in fact the whole philosophy underlying this program. The legislation is sufficiently loose and open to enable that to take place. I believe that in whatever field which passes legislation through this Parliament, ultimately should depend on the wishes of Parliament.

In this case the Government is asking us effectively to hand to public servants, through the Minister of the day, the capacity to emasculate this program if they so wish. It is specifically for that reason that we are asking for this modification which would require that any significant changes to the legislation in terms of the form of payment and so forth would come through the Parliament in the form of regulations and would thus be subject to the normal procedures of this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have gone from one extreme to the other, from having no legislation, which would enable governments literally to strike out payments without being answerable to Parliament in any way, shape or form, to the Oppositions's now wanting to have total control by the Parliament, taking it completely out of the hands of the Government. I am sure the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) has been a member for long enough to know that thousands of decisions made by government do not have to come into this chamber; otherwise the country would be unmanageable and every cent of funds allocated would have to be accounted for on a day to day basis. One literally could not run the country in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments moved by the Opposition have the effect of removing the control of the public lending right scheme from the hands of the Minister, and the Committee responsible to him, from administering the scheme. The Public Lending Right Committee is specifically constituted from representatives of the literary and library communities to provide expert technical advice on the administration of the public lending right scheme. The value of this advice would be undermined if it were subject to the possibility of being disregarded by Parliament, even though it had been accepted by the Minister. As the Bill is drafted, the Minister and the PLR Committee provide a focal point of accountability for all groups affected by the scheme. This would be diffused if the Parliament assumed control over the operation of the scheme.

The Bill as drafted will not radically alter the effective operating system which has been worked out over the 10 years since the scheme's inception. The amendments would alter and unnecessarily complicate the system by making even the most simple changes subject to a lengthy process of legislative drafting and parliamentary ratification. for example, if as is typically the case, the need for a modification of the scheme became apparent halfway through the public lending right year, the change would need to be formulated, agreed to and published at least two months prior to the beginning of the next public lending right year. This timing would be impossible to achieve of these modifications had to await further a suitable parliamentary sitting in order to be reviewed and ratified. Any disallowance would exacerbate the situation.

To give a concrete example of the type of modification which can arise, the definitions of 'eligible author' and 'publisher' have been expanded and refined several times since the scheme began, to ensure fairness in the scheme's application and to reflect changes in publishing practice. Modifications of this nature must be dealt with in a timely manner so that the scheme remains responsive and dynamic. The inbuilt delay of parliamentary review would militate against this.

The situation with rates of payment under this scheme is even more critical. Rates of payment have to be determined as part of the annual budgetary process that can be promulgated only after the Budget is brought down.
