TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday during Question Time, following an answer given by the Prime Minister on the situation in Lebanon, the Leader of the Opposition made a comment supporting the Prime Minister's remarks. I quote his comment:

INTERJECT.PARA: First of all, I would concur with the remarks made by the Prime Minister on Lebanon and I would like to place that on the record. I am pleased to hear that the matter will be taken further, hopefully in the Security Council of the United Nations.

This comment was edited from the broadcast in accordance with principles governing the delayed broadcast on Question Time. Long-standing practice is that extraneous matter is removed and only questions and answers are broadcast. However, given the bipartisan nature of the comment in this particular instance, I think the remarks could have remained as part of the broadcast.

TALK.START.PARA: —With your indulgence, Madam Acting Speaker, I want to indicate my total endorsement of the course you have followed in bringing this matter to the attention of the House. It is appropriate that this should be so because I appreciated the endorsement by the Leader of the Opposition.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. I ask it on behalf of all those who served in the defence forces of this country. The Prime Minister will recall his condemnation on Tuesday of all those Australians associated with the Vietnam war, which he described as 'an obscene purpose'. I remind the Prime Minister that this was a war against communism by Australians. The Prime Minister will also recall that yesterday was the fortieth anniversary of the end of the Second World War in Europe and that a little over one week ago it was the tenth anniversary of the end of the war in Vietnam. In view of the Government's failure to recognise the sacrifices of Australians in either of these two wars, will the Prime Minister at least state in clear and unequivocal terms the Government's attitude to the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, Mr Uren, who is reported to have attended a dinner last week arranged by the Communist Party to celebrate the communist victory in Vietnam, thereby denigrating the 47,000 Australians who served in that war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate very much the opportunity I have been given by the honourable member with this question. With regard to my colleague, the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services, there is no one in this Parliament who is entitled to question the integrity, the commitment and the readiness of this man to lay down his life for his country. It ill becomes any Opposition member to bring into question the integrity of the Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: Now, let us examine the question in a little more detail. It starts with a gross misrepresentation. That is no surprise, coming from the other side of this House. There was not one word in what I said in this place the other day or in anything that I have ever said at any stage in my consistent opposition to the Australian commitment in Vietnam-made under false pretences by a conservative government-against the men and women who with honour, integrity and commitment of purpose went to Vietnam. Never once in my consistent opposition to the then Government's adventurism did I say anything against the soldiers who were conscripted to go there; I spoke out against the Government which sent them. It is a gross misrepresentation for the honourable member or anyone else to suggest that I or this Government have ever said anything-one word-against the men and women who were involved in that commitment. Just as consistently as we have not said a word against the people who were involved there in service, we have condemned those who, under totally false pretences, sent those people to Vietnam. The Government of the time lied-
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw that word.
—That is an unparliamentary word.
—Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw the word 'lie'.
—Is that a parliamentary word?
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. If he interjects again, I will name him.
—The Government of the time misrepresented--
—On a point of order, Madam Acting Speaker, the Prime Minister's use of language was clearly unparliamentary and I ask for a withdrawal.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Prime Minister withdrew his comment.

—The Government of that time grossly and deliberately misrepresented the basis on which our troops were sent into that conflict. That is now a well-established fact of record and history. The honourable member in his question said that it was a war against communism. At the time the then Government said that essentially it was a war against the downward thrust of ruthless Chinese communism. That is what it said. It was wrong when it said that. It betrayed an abysmal lack of understanding of the facts of history and of current events. Anyone who had any understanding of the facts of history would not have confused and identified the interests of China with those of the Vietnamese. Anyone who had a rudimentary understanding of history knew that. But because the then Government was prepared to divert attention in this country by trying to get the United States involved in a land war in Asia, it had no concern for the truth, it misrepresented the facts and it tried to have the people of Australia believe that what it was doing in sending young men from Australia to Vietnam was protecting Australia from China and Chinese communism. The Government of the day was blatantly wrong then. Even if Opposition members did not have the good sense to know that they were wrong then, one would have thought that they would have had the decency 10 years later at least to confess their mistakes. But they have never had the decency to confess their mistakes.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us understand the depth of Opposition members' hypocrisy even more; let me point out two simple facts which further demonstrate that hypocrisy. At the very time they were saying that young Australian men should be in Vietnam and were conscripting them to fight there against the downward thrust of Chinese communism, how sincere were they? At the very time they were saying that China was the enemy whom our men were fighting against, they were exporting Australian steel to China. They claimed we were fighting in Vietnam against China, yet their commercial considerations could not interfere with their patriotism; it was much more important to endorse the sale of steel to China-to the enemy-than to speak truthfully about the issue. That is point one in their hypocrisy.

Let us get to the very depths of the hypocrisy of honourable members opposite. They were the people who sent young Australian men to Vietnam, to die and to be wounded. When the survivors returned from service in Vietnam-having gone there at the command and direction of honourable members opposite, under the total pretence and misrepresentation of the facts that honourable members opposite created-they asked for reasonable recompense and understanding of their condition created by their service in Vietnam. They wanted a royal commission into the conditions of their service and into what they and their wives and children may have suffered as a result of their having been sent to Vietnam. Would honourable members opposite meet their reasonable demands? No. Honourable members opposite conscripted young Australian men to die under false pretences. When the survivors came back and asked for nothing more excessive than a reasonable examination of what happened to them honourable members opposite refused. It was not until the Australian Labor Party came to government that we, as a government of principle, agreed to their request. Honourable members opposite expect to be taken seriously when one of them gets up and asks a question like that which I have just answered. They will be laughed out of court, as they should be.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam ACTING SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon a parliamentary delegation from Singapore, led by Mr Wong Kan Seng, Minister of State for Home Affairs and Community Development. On behalf of the House, I extend to the delegation a very warm welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Prime Minister: Is the Government satisfied that the assets test is not hurting ordinary Australians and others genuinely in need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and I can say unequivocally that the Government remains committed to the basic principle which underlies the introduction of the assets test, and that is that pensions in this country should not be directed to those not in need. I will not go into great detail, but I would have thought that the overwhelming majority of Australians would have found it obscene, as we did, that the people of Australia were actually paying a pension to an Australian who had two villas on the Mediterranean, that it was thought appropriate that a person who had so arranged his affairs as to have two assets on the Mediterranean should still receive a pension. I say quite clearly that we do not believe in that. It is the case that in introducing a change of these dimensions some problems have emerged.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to the honourable members in cockies corner that their formal extra-parliamentary organisation, the National Farmers Federation, supported the introduction of the assets test and applauded it. They should not sit on the Opposition benches and try to put a cloak of morality around themselves. The National Farmers Federation supported the test, but to its member's credit, being reasonable men, they came to us and said: 'We don't want the test abolished'-unlike the hypocrites opposite-'but it has come to our attention that there are some difficulties'. They were not asking for its abolition. I simply say that we are taking account of these difficulties, and I can assure this House that they will be remedied.

ANSWER.PARA: Our principal approach in this matter stands in contrast to the cynical, opportunistic approach of the Leader of the Opposition. His pathetic efforts yesterday to secure not the amendment but the abolition of the test marked his final, pitiful retreat from his principled position of 1981 when, I remind the House, he said that he supported--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you hate the pensioners?
—Order! The honourable member for Denison will cease interjecting.

—Honourable members opposite do not wish to hear this, but they will hear it. In 1981 the Leader of the Opposition said that he supported Budget measures which 'avoided the situation where those who don't need government assistance are given help at the expense of those who do'. Could we have anything more unqualified than that statement by the Leader of the Opposition? Very significantly, today's Melbourne Sun reveals it all, because it tells us that the Opposition Leader's pursuit of the course he took yesterday to try to get the abolition of the means test-a course which, I may say, has been conceded by his colleagues to have been a miserable failure-was pursued against the advice of his Deputy Leader.
—Nonsense.

—I hope the Deputy Leader of the Opposition will not let us down now because I am going to give him some praise. We all recall that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition remained a consistent supporter of the needs-based approach to welfare. I will take one of his several quotes. Even as late as 27 November 1983, what did he have to say? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, a consistent supporter of the assets test principle, said:

ANSWER.PARA: I'm personally in favour of a needs approach to the payment of welfare.
He went on to say:
I have been for some time and I don't walk away from that.

Obviously, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is still not walking away from that position of principle. He is trying his best, among this sea of cynicism, to stick to his principles. Whatever the facade may be that the Opposition is putting up on the rift that exists within its ranks, the simple fact is that the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy are at odds. We have the situation where the Leader of the Opposition himself has decided to lead in matters economic. Is that not incredible? The Leader of the Opposition is going to lead in matters economic. It is hard to believe, but he is going to.

I ask the House rhetorically: What was the sin of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he should suffer this disgrace? He did two things. Firstly he has been prepared to impose upon himself some limits to cynicism and political opportunism. But, even worse, his major sin is that at times he has been prepared to congratulate the Government on economic decisions which it has taken. That is a sin which cannot be countenanced by his colleagues.

Politics is a tough business and one hopes at times for a bit of luck. But not even I could have hoped for as much luck as this. Despite the fact that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition went through a period of discreditation, at least it is acknowledged that he knows something about the subject. But he is to be pushed aside and replaced by a man who is barely numerate, an exposition of whose knowledge in matters economic would impose no severe strains upon the back of a postage stamp. The sound we can hear in the background is the sound of the business community laughing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware of the studies conducted under the Orani model at Melbourne University which show that a rise in indirect tax will mean a decline in real gross domestic product of more than 3 per cent? What are the implications for welfare beneficiaries? Is his concern for these beneficiaries the sole basis of his opposition to a broadly based indirect tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why the honourable member is not asking any more questions about the assets test. He has done so on three or four occasions and neither he nor the Opposition has made any progress. Essentially, they have made no progress because they are not prepared to debate within their parties serious issues and to develop serious policy positions. That has been remarkably evident in successive days in debate on the assets test. The assets test is about the achievement of a fair distribution of very limited resources.
—I take a point of order, Madam Acting Speaker. I did not ask about the assets test.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Minister is answering the question.

—In government, hard decisions are necessary. The difference between the Government Party and the Opposition parties is that, when we face difficult decisions, we allow open, democratic and serious debate within our party room and within the community. The issues of taxation and taxation reform raises quite fundamental questions not only for the future of taxation and the distribution of wealth but also for social security beneficiaries for a very long time in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that I have made various remarks in terms of that debate. But the fundamental point that I made in my speech last Sunday is that it is not a case of one particular measure being important when one addresses the relationship between taxation and social security; it is the fundamental direction, the question of redistribution overall, the question of gains and benefits not in relation to any particular measure but to the overall result that is achieved. That is an extraordinarily difficult issue which the Government faces. The Government is doing so in a way that I believe is responsible and extraordinarily open. I wonder why it is that the Opposition appears to be too scared to expose its arguments within the context of the taxation summit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Communications inform the House what powers are available to him under section 8 of the Postal Services Act in respect of mail bans currently affecting postal services into Queensland.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Griffith for his question. As honourable members are probably aware, this morning in this place the Leader of the National Party of Australia demanded that I issue a direction under section 8 of the Postal Services Act requiring the Australian Postal Commission to perform functions specified in section 7 of the Act. The Leader of the National Party suggested that the failure of the Government today to indicate that it would take that step would show that the Government was unwilling to take what was a legally available option to bring that dispute to an end. Because of that suggestion, it is necessary to explain the position according to the advice currently available to me, which I think would have been to the knowledge of the Leader of the National Party in any event.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that no direction can be given by me which interferes with the Commission's function of forming a subjective judgment which is antecedently connected with the exercise of a power or duty vested in the Commission. The duty cast on the Commission to make postal services available throughout Australia for all people who reasonably require those services is set out in legislation. It is dependent on the formation of a decision on the part of the Commission that it is, in its opinion, reasonably practical to perform that duty. Accordingly, as far as I can judge, the ministerial direction power is not available in respect of the part of section 7 to which the Leader of the National Party referred this morning.

The interesting aspect of this is that I am in a position to inform the House in these terms because the Leader of the National Party, when he was the Minister for Communications, sought advice from the Attorney-General's Department on this very point and that advice forms the basis of the answer that I have given here today. As I said earlier, the Leader of the National Party knows, or ought to know, that the position that he was putting this morning in this place is not supported by legislation. In fact it is illuminating to see how the Leader of the National Party performed during the unprecedented industrial turmoil which destroyed communications services during his period as Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely. Now tell me.

—The right honourable member can interject. But, if he had spent more time attending to the matters of Australia Post than he spent arranging for telephone services to be connected for his relatives on Lord Howe Island, Australia Post would be in a much better position than it is now.

ANSWER.PARA: The memorable period of industrial relations under the then Minister was in 1981-82. I will tell honourable members what happened. Australia Post lost 323,000 work hours because of industrial disputation. It was the worst record in the history of Australia Post. At that time the Leader of the National Party was the Minister.

We saw the way he carried on in here this morning. I will refer to the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 December 1981, when he was the Minister. What was the front page headline? It was 'Communications chaos'. That shows his performance. The very next day the headline was 'Mail walkouts block pensions'. That is not a bad record at this stage. These headlines followed: 'A million mail items pile up', 'long distance calls hit' and 'telex exchange sit-in goes on'. All that occurred during his period as Minister.

But did he issue a direction under section 8? No, he did not, for the reasons that I outlined earlier. One of the few sensible things that I can find that he did say with regard to a Telecom dispute is reported as follows in the Sydney Morning Herald of 11 December 1981:
. . . the Government supported the idea of another hearing in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

That is a strange sort of situation but it seemed fairly sensible to the right honourable gentleman, who had the gall to come into this chamber this morning and put on a theatrical performance. Finally, the current position is that the section 25 notification of the dispute lodged by Australia Post on 7 May has been listed for hearing before Commissioner Grimshaw of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on 10 May 1985 at 10 a.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Speaker, the Minister read from a number of documents. I require him to table them.
—Are the Minister's documents of a confidential nature?
—No, Madam Deputy Speaker. They are my written-over notes which the Opposition is welcome to have if it wants them.
—Notes do not have to be tabled.
—Madam Acting Speaker, the Minister said that he would table them. Will he table them please?
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The Minister does not have to table them. He may table them if he so wishes.
—He offered to table them.
—Order! He may table them if he so wishes. If he wishes to, he may do so.
—He will not table them; it is obvious.
—The Minister is under no requirement to do so but if he desires to do so he may do so.

—Madam Acting Speaker, on the point of order, I indicated that I was referring to my notes which are written on. I said that, if the Leader of the National Party wants to have a look at them later, I will be quite happy to give them to him.

—Does the Minister for Social Security stand by his statement made to the Australian Capital Territory Council of Social Service on 20 March that the imposition of a consumption tax 'could very well trigger a financial crisis in Australia's low income household'? Does this include welfare beneficiaries? Does the Minister agree with the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions that compensation for the imposition of such a tax would be just about administratively impossible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a great deal to add to what I said in relation to the previous question. Quite clearly, any form of tax depends on the circumstances, the rates and the whole range of factors with which it is introduced. It is true that I have been concerned about the question of compensation in relation to an indirect tax, it would be very surprising if a responsible Labor government did not concern itself with that question. Whatever aspect of taxation change occurs will have implications for a whole range of people, which is why the Government has been very concerned, in terms of the preparation for the possibility of changes in taxation, to ensure that all the arguments and implications are examined and that the various interests that will be principally concerned with any tax change are not only properly consulted but also have the opportunity, within the context of a tax summit, to address their arguments with respect to information provided by the Government in the form of a White Paper.

ANSWER.PARA: If the Opposition looks back at its record in government with respect to tax I think it will see that that Government not only imposed a massive increase on indirect taxation, in particular in the oil levy, but also showed no concern to look at the compensation question and all the implications for the lower income sections within the Australian community. That is not the way that we go about government. We go about it on the basis of putting the cards on the table, allowing people to see the information and make their own assessment and their own judgments. I believe that many people on the opposite side of the House will be involved in a fairly keen debate when that information is available. It is unfortunate that they do not have the guts to turn up at the summit and put their argument there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Health aware that blood glucose meters, costing around $200 each, are now in widespread use for the monitoring of blood sugar level in diabetics and are considered essential by many medical specialists in the treatment of diabetic patients? Can the Minister inform the House why no private health insurance benefits tables in Victoria provide any cover for the acquisition of these meters, yet cover is available in the Australian Capital Territory and New South Wales? In particular, why does Medibank Private not provide in Victoria cover similar to that which it provides in other States? Will the Minister take this up with Medibank?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the widespread use of blood glucose machines for monitoring the blood sugar content of diabetics and I recognise that a high cost is involved in their use. I have to point out that it is up to individual funds in each State to determine what benefits they will make available on their ancillary tables. These are the tables which, in some States, cover such items as these glucose machines. The funds necessarily limit the number of items they cover in order to keep the costs of those contribution rates down as much as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: Insofar as Medibank Private is concerned, each State Medibank Private determines its own range of items that will be covered by ancillary benefits on the basis of the community demand and the range of items offered by its competitors. So we have a somewhat different situation in each State. However, Medibank Private carries out regular reviews of its ancillary benefits. I have asked the General Manager of Medibank Private as a matter of urgency to arrange for the Victorian State executive of that fund to have an immediate discussion with the Victorian diabetics association on the need and the possibility of having these meters included on its ancillary tables. I urge the other private health funds in Victoria to take the same action.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to the comments made by the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions indicating the ACTU's present opposition to a broadly based indirect tax. I ask the Treasurer: Does the Prime Minister's seventh principle of tax reform mean that the Government will not proceed with the introduction of a broadly based indirect tax if such a tax is opposed by the ACTU?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear precisely what the President of the ACTU said this morning on the radio. I think the intent of his remark was to indicate that there was no agreement between the Government and the ACTU on the nature of the tax mix that will apply after the tax summit in July this year. That is true; I am happy to confirm that. I am also happy to confirm what the Leader of the Opposition said in respect of the Prime Minister's principles outlined in the course of the election campaign. The whole point of the taxation summit is to try to arrive at some major consensus of view-in focusing on the same problems and the same data-on possible national solutions to the question of the Australian taxation system.

ANSWER.PARA: Nevertheless, the question is interesting because it shows that the Leader of the Opposition is determined to be a negative influence on tax reform in this country. The matter of public importance which is listed for debate after Question Time today is the third or fourth such matter listed in the same terms designed only to be mischievous about the prospect of tax reform in this country. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition and his Deputy seek to pick the eyes out of tax reform and agree to the things that only they, with their own ideological obsessions, would be inclined to agree to. They ignore the fact that there may be a need to bring a package to the table and simply hammer a case for the things which they prefer.

My colleague, the Minister for Social Security, has already indicated the unwillingness of the Leader of the Opposition, his Deputy and his Party to be represented at the national taxation summit. They are determined to be anything other than constructive on the question of taxation. The whole point of the question is not to help the process of reform, which they showed themselves incapable of doing, which they had no guts to do, it is only designed to cause trouble. I make this point: At least this Government has a framework to discuss not only the broad thrust of economic policy, but also taxation policy within the framework of the prices and incomes accord. The relationship which the Government enjoys with the Australian Council of Trade Unions is such that this sort of an issue can be discussed. That is not a framework which the former Government ever wanted to establish. In fact, it attacked the ACTU as virulently and as often as possible. We will leave it to the Australian people to make a judgment over time about who will deliver on tax reform in this country, who has been constructive and who has been opportunist. I will be very surprised at the end of the section if the Leader of the Opposition does not end up being as opportunistic on tax reform as he has been on the assets test.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations inform the House what are the prospects for resolution of the current electricity dispute in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The industrial situation in Queensland that has led to widespread industrial action is a matter of great concern to this Government and we certainly want to do everything we can to bring that industrial action to an end and to bring a resolution to the basic issue in this dispute. In that regard it is recognised by everyone that one of the great achievements of this Government in its period of office has been that we have been unable to reduce the level of industrial disputation in this country to the lowest level in 17 years. That record is being somewhat upset at the moment by this action in Queensland which is substantially outside our control.

ANSWER.PARA: The developments in Queensland are of concern to us not only because of the industrial disputation which is now occurring as a result of it, but also because of the prime nature of that dispute involving a great infringement on the democratic rights of the people of Queensland. We are concerned to bring this matter to a resolution and are working assiduously to bring that about. I must say that it appears that there is no desire on the part of the Queensland Government to bring this dispute to an end and to bring an end to the industrial situation which is now occurring. I think there would be no real concern by the Opposition in this House either; it supports unqualifiedly the position of the Queensland Government.

The position of the Queensland Government was revealed to everyone this morning on the AM program when the Premier of Queensland was interviewed about this dispute. He was asked: 'Will the Government negotiate at any time on this issue?' He said: 'No, we won't negotiate on it'. Then the questioner said: 'I suppose there is some feeling that perhaps your interest in bringing the Hawke Government down might be above your interest in resolving this dispute'. The Premier replied: 'Well, my main objective is to get rid of the Hawke Government. That is the main, prime objective'.
Opposition members-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Opposition members are all saying: 'Hear, hear!' It is very interesting that they are all saying that. The Premier of Queensland was saying that he was not prepared to resolve this dispute. That was not his main concern; his main concern was to bring this Government down. In other words, this whole business is being played for political mileage and not to resolve an industrial situation which is inconveniencing not only the people of Queensland but having an impact on the whole of the country. Members of the Opposition say, 'hear, hear'. They say that the Premier should be out there playing politics, that he should be out there trying to exacerbate industrial action and industrial disputation. When honourable members say, 'hear, hear' they support that. We are very interested to note their reaction. They are not really concerned about resolving this industrial dispute, they are concerned- like the Premier of Queensland to whom they give unqualified support-to make political mileage out of what is going on. They support entirely his refusal to negotiate despite the fact that leaders of business, such as Mr Williams, who is the head of the Confederation of Australian Industry, say that negotiation is the only way to settle this dispute. The Premier of Queensland says no to that for political reasons and members of the Opposition say, 'hear, hear'. They are revealed for what they are on this matter absolute charlatans with no real concern about resolving this industrial matter, but rather seeking to make political mileage out of it. On the other hand, at least this Government is working assiduously to try to resolve this industrial situation and to resolve the underlying dispute.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not at liberty at present to reveal exactly what we are doing. The course of action that we have embarked on will, I believe, provide very good prospects of a resolution of the industrial action and a resolution of the underlying dispute within the next few days. I cannot be absolutely certain that that will be the case, but I have good reason to think that we will be able to bring that situation about. It is nonsense to argue, as the Leader of the Opposition and others have argued, that this Government is not undertaking any action at present. We are doing everything in our power to try to bring the underlying dispute to a point of resolution and to stop the industrial action that is going on; unlike members of the Opposition, who are not concerned about the situation at all but concerned about only the political mileage they can get out of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am delighted to announce the Government's decision to select the design of Australian Shipbuilding Industries, of Jervoise Bay, Western Australia, for the construction of the boats to be acquired under the Pacific patrol boat project. The successful design-known as the ASI315-is for a 31.5-metre, 165-tonne vessel. The ASI company has succeeded against competition from 12 other designs submitted by 10 companies from Western Australia, South Australia, New South Wales and Queensland. The ASI design is based on a requirement, prepared after consultation with participating countries, to take account of characteristics most important in the envisaged roles-including range, speed and accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's decision is the culmination of a process which began in late August 1983 when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the support of Pacific leaders, announced the project at the Canberra meeting of the South Pacific Forum. I have already informed Ministers of participating countries of the Government's selection. Five countries-Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Tonga and Western Samoa-have already indicated an intention to take part in the project and the Government is examining options available to assist other countries in the region with maritime surveillance.

I should like to remind honourable members of our purpose in pursuing this project, as part of the Australian defence co-operation program with regional countries. Primarily, the Pacific patrol boat project is intended to provide Pacific Forum states with an effective means of surveillance and enforcement in their maritime exclusive economic zones. For many countries in the region, fisheries are a major resource. The Pacific patrol boat will contribute to the deterrence of illegal fishing and to the monitoring of the activities of licensed operations. The boats can also be used for a range of other tasks, including police work, immigration, quarantine, and search and rescue.

Australian and regional countries' strategic interests are complementary. The Pacific patrol boat project supports common defence interests and common resolve to maintain a secure and stable environment in the region. The Pacific patrol boat project will assist with the establishment, or further development, of regional naval capabilities to support national security concerns, and the creation of a regional maritime support infrastructure. We also hope that the project will further encourage co-operation between countries of the region, particularly in surveillance of their often adjacent maritime resource zones. These things are of value to the countries concerned and they are of value to Australia. As maritime capabilities are introduced or expanded in regional countries, they will provide potential for direct and continuous linkage with Royal Australian Navy operations in the region and the Royal Australian Air Force P3 Orion surveillance flights that now take place on a regular basis. The single, standard design approach provides benefits of commonality of support and maintenance in the region and economies of scale.

On the Australian side, the contract with ASI will include design and construction of patrol boats, with an initial two years support package and operational and technical training. The RAN will provide training and, as necessary, long term advisory assistance in country, as well as operationally managing the project. We are also discussing with the New Zealand Ministry of Defence how we might take up its offer to assist with the project. For their part, participating countries will be providing the necessary national infrastructure to support the boat, such as wharves, workshops and operational headquarters and national surveillance administrative systems to permit effective use of the vessel. They will also pay all operating and support costs for the vessel. The project should provide work in Australian industry for about 60 people for about four years and give ASI a strong basis for winning additional sales in Australia and overseas.

The final cost of this multi-million dollar project will be determined in negotiations with ASI. Current financial planning is based on the expectation of building up to 10 boats. Prior to the completion of negotiations with the company, my officials will visit participating countries to provide details of the ASI design and why it was selected, and to discuss the work the countries are doing to develop support facilities and command and control arrangements so as to make effective use of the boats when delivered.

I congratulate the ASI company on its outstanding response to the Pacific patrol boat tender and I congratulate RAN and departmental officials on their diligence and efficiency in evaluating all responses and preparing recommendations for Government.

The ASI315 design is longer, larger and more spacious than that of the next ranked tenderer. Its hull is more easily repairable and its seakeeping and survivability capabilities are assessed as being better, particularly in extreme sea states and winds. The ASI project also has a $5m advantage on price over that of that tenderer on the cost of 10 boats. I also congratulate the other tenderers. Many of the submissions were for excellent vessels. Some exhibited a high degree of expertise indeed and would have provided a satisfactory vessel.

The Government commends the project to the House as a most appropriate use of defence resources to assist regional countries in developing capabilities to protect their sovereign rights, to support major Australian defence interests in the region and to provide Australian industry with an opportunity to participate in the largest and most complex project ever attempted under the defence co-operation program. I am issuing a Press release today providing more details on the project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It was with some incredulity that I read this document and heard the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) make his statement, because there is another matter on which he gave a Press conference earlier today which is of at least as much interest to the community as this one. I notice that in this instance he has made the statement in the House and is issuing a draft Press release outside it. I believe it is totally inappropriate for major policy statements to be made outside the Parliament on matters relating to the acquisition of land in the Orange-Bathurst area for defence exercise purposes and for us not even to be extended the courtesy of having some comment on it in the Parliament.
—Ask me a question.

—As the Minister knows, it is appropriate for him to make policy statements in the House. The practice of this place has always been for statements on matters of high policy content to be made in this place and not for a Press statement to be issued outside, unless the Parliament is not sitting. The circumstances are that the Minister thinks he will get a few brownie points on this statement whereas on the other statement he knows he will not. He knows he has got himself in a position where the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said one thing and he is doing another. It is a difficult issue and it is one that should be debated.

SPEECH.PARA: This statement relates to progress with the Pacific patrol boat project. It is regrettable that the Minister has in no way analysed in this statement the circumstances of the retention of the Attack class patrol boats in the Royal Australian Navy. As all honourable members would know, a number of these boats have been made available to countries in our region. I understand that there they have operated satisfactorily. They have been refurbished within Australian shipyards. In the Royal Australian Navy they have been replaced with a upgraded patrol boat, which is the general class patrol boat now in service with the RAN. The Attack class boats, however, have generally proved not to be satisfactory in the deeper waters and where high sea states are possible around the Australian coastline. I believe that before this statement was concluded it would have been appropriate for the Minister to tell us what his intentions are with the balance of the Attack class patrol boats. I think there are four or five remaining in service. Undertakings have been given by the Prime Minister about further patrol boat orders with North Queensland Engineers and Agents Pty Ltd in Cairns. I believe that honourable members in this place would like to know whether those Attack class boats are to be taken out of service and whether further Fremantle class patrol boats are to be built and tenders are to be called for them. I would have thought that would have been phase one of any statement to be made in this House regarding patrol boats.

The second matter that I believe should have been discussed in this statement but which regrettably is not is that of coastal patrol generally and the extent to which these new patrol boats are intended for use within Australian waters to supplement facilities already available in the RAN. I point out to the Minister that many State patrol boats-fishing boats and whatever-operate in closer waters. I would have hoped that in considering a boat-something which, in general terms, as I will explain in a moment, I support-we would look towards Australian orders as well and, if the boats are not suitable for the RAN we would see whether they might be able to fit into some of the requirements for coastal surveillance which, as all honourable members know, is a very important present duty of the patrol boat elements within the RAN, taking up a good deal of their operational time. They do an excellent job, but perhaps instead of replacing the Attack class boats with more Fremantle class boats we might introduce some of these new Pacific class patrol boats, the ASI315s. In that way we might be able to conserve our assets.

The third area I wish to comment upon is within the general category of the ASI315, about which this statement sets out the details. There are a number of elements in it that I think are commendable. There is no doubt that all of us support very much the design and construction of patrol boats in Australia. I hope that we also support the principle-we certainly do on this side-of co-operation with New Zealand and other countries in our region in the design and construction of defence facilities. As the Minister has explained, this project is within the defence co-operation program. That program does not, in our conception of it at least, amount only to the giving of physical aid; it involves trying to develop capabilities within our region to assist in the development of a defence capability against external aggression. One way by which this can be done is to ensure that in our region those countries that have a common defence interest-they include the Pacific islands, which are specifically mentioned, and the countries of South East Asia-can work together in procurement and the development of a design an manufacture capability. I believe that in this project's development many of those elements are present, and for that reason I believe it is very commendable that the project is being developed as it is.

I notice that the Western Australian shipyard has been successful in gaining a tender. I congratulate Australian Shipbuilding Industries (W.A.) Pty Ltd on its success in this respect. I believe it to be a capable shipbuilding yard and its principals are to be commended, not only for their design ingenuity but also for their record. However, I put it to the Minister that there is a wider problem which needs to be taken in hand by the Government. It involves, of course, not only the Minister's responsibility but also that of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). I think we need to look at the shipbuilding yards around Australia to try to see whether a program of future shipbuilding intentions can be developed so that around our coastline we can try to preserve those existing shipbuilding capabilities. I believe it essential that we develop a shipbuilding capability in Western Australia and, as I have said, I congratulate the Australian Shipbuilding Industries company for its success in this project.

However, I am concerned that the record of Australian shipbuilding has been a success only up to a certain point. We have had yards such as the Adelaide ship construction yard, which in the past did a great deal of excellent work in building earlier patrol and supply boats for oil fields, but which is now virtually out of business. The Whyalla shipyard is now out of business. Around Australia at the moment we have a few yards. I believe that governments of whatever complexion, would do well to try to take out, for example, the needs of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation's Antarctic research vessels to see whether we can try to program so that those yards that are in existence can continue, not only in the interests of those employed in the yards, who of course would benefit, but also to assist with the procurement requirement of the Australian defence forces.

There is an enormous problem in the decline of capability generally in the manufacturing industries in Australia as far as the repair and maintenance of Australian defence equipment is concerned. I believe this statement today by the Minister addresses one area where some capabilities could be developed, and I hope they will be there for the future. But I commend to the Minister the idea of trying, in conjunction with his colleagues, to develop some type of schedule which might assist other shipyards which are functioning to try to retain their capability. This is a project which would certainly have the support of members of this side of the House. I repeat that in that respect I know that NQEA is getting to a very serious stage of its operations. I hope that in the Minister's examination of those facilities which might be possible within the funds available to him its needs can be taken into account.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in tabling the 1983-84 annual report of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I seek leave to make a statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an attractive publication highlighting the research achievements of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and setting out its policies in some detail. CSIRO has been of invaluable service to the nation in the past in making a major contribution to the success of our primary industries, which are the very foundation of our economy. It now offers a powerful tool for the task of restructuring and revitalising our manufacturing industries, which is essential to our future prosperity. We now need to identify and breakdown the inhibiting factors which so far have held back the manufacturing and service sectors from taking advantage of the high levels of expertise available in CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: The annual report shows that, in the four years from 1979 to 1983, the number of scientific staff within CSIRO engaged in research for manufacturing industry rose from 630 to 710, an increase of 12.5 per cent, that is to 28.5 per cent of the total research staff. This growth was achieved by CSIRO's realisation of the importance of the manufacturing sector, even before the change of government, and indicates a willingness to co-operate fully with this Government's program of revitalising industry.

It is not widely appreciated that CSIRO has also already given substantial assistance to secondary industries. Without CSIRO's contributions over the past few years, the prospects for increasing our competiveness on the international market would be much bleaker than they now are because of the low level of private investment in research and development in this country. In this context I quote a comment of a recent Japanese visitor, an official from the Tsukuba Expo '85 who said: 'without CSIRO Australia would be a Third World country'.

One example of CSIRO's role in boosting our technological capacity is the formation of the company Austek Microsystems Pty Ltd arising from CSIRO's very large scale integration program in Adelaide. Four years ago, we had no indigenous capability in integrated circuit design. Within two years, over 200 application-specific chips, that is, dedicated or 'custom' chips, had been designed by Australians through CSIRO adopting a central co-ordinating role for newly trained designers. Having established the mechanism to ensure Australian capability in integrated circuit design by early 1983, the VLSI program went on to concentrate on the design and construction of a '100 k' chip, that is, a chip with 100,000 components. The new developments were incorporated into CSIRO training courses, ensuring that Australian designs will continue to be competitive with the best available from Silicon Valley or anywhere else in the world. According to plan, the researchers then left CSIRO to set up their own company, Austek, to exploit the capability commercially. We are now seeing the beginning of a flourishing new industry in Australia. None of it could have happened without the CSIRO environment.

It needs to be emphasised over and over again that in many divisions of CSIRO there have been dramatic changes in emphasis in the past five years. The world research is changing with unprecedented speed and CSIRO is changing with it. Biotechnology is a notable example. In 1980, CSIRO had 57 professionals in this area. By 1985 there are more than 200. Fifty-one per cent of those additional positions were found from redeployment of resources, 30 per cent from priority funding-areas designated by the executive in consultation with me-and 19 per cent from external funding. In the Division of Plant Industry as much as 65 per cent of additional positions have come from external funding. The number of professionals in Molecular Biology has doubled in five years.

CSIRO is carrying out pioneering work on the chemical interaction between metals and ceramics, a field of increasing international interest and with close collaboration with industry. The work on partially stabilised zirconia is now being developed in the private sector and has created a high degree of interest in the United States and Japan. The annual report for 1983-84 details some of the actions taken by the CSIRO Executive to ensure that this kind of success is repeated. These include: The formation of a new commercial company, SIROTECH Ltd, to bring marketing and industrial expertise to bear on the problems of transferring CSIRO technology into industry and to communicate the real research needs of industry to CSIRO scientists; the implementation of new criteria for promotion of scientists, giving greater emphasis to research achievements of direct benefit to industry and the community; the establishment of a new policy on manufacturing industry research, emphasising the need for increased short-term tactical research to support CSIRO's main role of long term strategic research; the formation of a new Division of Information Technology to conduct research on the acquisition, storage, processing and dissemination of information by computer technology and other means for the benefit of industry and the community; the formation of a research unit to stimulate the development of a space-technology industry in Australia; and the encouragement of industry groups and individual firms in the manufacturing sector to communicate the strategic research needs of their industries. Discussions have taken place at top level with numerous companies, including members of the Federal Chamber of Automotive Industries and of metal and chemical industries.

Pressure is frequently brought to bear on the CSIRO executive for the Organisation's scientists to concentrate on the problems of the moment. Their response, quite rightly, is that CSIRO should be doing part of its work on short term tactical problems so that it can get to know industry and its needs, but that the majority of such problems should be tackled by industry itself. It is often insisted that CSIRO's research must be relevant, but relevance has a disconcerting habit of changing from year to year. The priorities of 1980 may look absurd by 1985. The proposition that in 1985 we could carry out only research which could be applied to 1985's industries is a guarantee of failure. When do we begin thinking about 1990? Must we wait for another five years? If we do, we will be doomed. There was a telling illustration of this point on 6 March, 1985 when Rod Carnegie assisted the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to launch SIROTECH Ltd, CSIRO's new technology transfer company. Rod Carnegie said that we must put more emphasis on relevant research, and the illustration he gave was biotechnology. But when did biotechnology jump the hurdle to become relevant? Very recently. Even two or three years ago biotechnology would have been regarded-although not by me-as a classic example of pure research, on the frontiers of knowledge. It is essential that industry lift its currently deplorable performance and make a serious effort in applied research.

At the recent Venice Conference on Technological Innovation and Job Creation, President Reagan's science adviser, Dr Jaye Keyworth, said that between 1981 and 1985 administration expenditure on basic research had increased by 60 per cent. The Republicans reversed the Carter Administration's policy of increasing funding of applied research as a means of bailing out companies and now put the entire responsibility for this on industry. The percentage of expenditure by CSIRO in basic or fundamental research is difficult to estimate precisely. There is a considerable degree of overlap in many areas between fundamental and applied. I would define basic research as an inquiry into the way in which the universe and its systems work, without a product or practical application in mind. Strategic or mission-oriented research, such as the work on PSZ, involves fundamental research into physical properties, but with an end product-a new industrial material-in view. The best estimate is that 10 to 15 per cent of CSIRO's research expenditure is basic, or fundamental.

CSIRO's main role is strategic-to lay the foundations for technologies and industries for the future. This kind of research is not aimed at solving the immediate problems of any one company. Instead, its aim is to come up with research results that will be profitable to a large number of Australian companies. Strategic research is appropriate for government-funded institutions because it is usually beyond the scope of any single company to perform. It is the sort of work government should be involved in and it is the sort of work CSIRO has been doing superbly. To be successful, it must be accompanied by a certain amount of fundamental research which has no apparent application to any existing industrial product or process. CSIRO research should continue to cover the whole spectrum, from the most fundamental to the most immediately technical, with the middle ground of strategic research being its speciality. I commend the CSIRO annual report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This Labor Government has earned a great deal of controversial publicity for its handling of science and technology matters. This statement by the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) fuels the controversy, because his is a brave statement and a correct one.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the record in summary. The Government took a vigorous public relations position to say that it would promote scientific endeavour in this country. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation report demonstrates the ongoing strength and significance of the CSIRO. The Labor Government started its term in office with an integrated portfolio of Science and Technology, including the CSIRO. It appointed one of its most eloquent members to be the Minister for Science and Technology-eloquent but, unfortunately, lacking political clout in the Cabinet. Science seemed under this Government to have a rational policy future. The Minister has taken a great interest in CSIRO, and that is manifest in his statement today. The fact is that the statement is a statement in defence of CSIRO as much as it is an advocacy. It is not a defence against statements from this side of the House; it is a defence against attacks on CSIRO made by the Government leadership, particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Button. It is a defence which can only stand to the Minister's permanent credit, because the issues raised cut right across factional lines. Support for basic research funded by government and support for strategic research funded by government are fundamental to our economic future. I feel that support for the Minister's statement today and its implied rebuke to the Government will commend itself to the great majority of members of this House and the scientific community.

For these reasons, the constructive treatment of science seemed earlier much better than in other areas, where the blood-letting and the battles between the factions reach fever pitch and provide the inside dopesters of the Australian Labor Party, the journalists and the National, which is a bitser television program, with a welter of political material feeding the fraternal warfare of the factions. We thought CSIRO and science would be free of strife, but unfortunately they are not, although it is a different sort of hassle.

The Budget decisions of last year were plainly vindictive against CSIRO and against the Minister as punishment for some of his more frank admissions and some of the exaggerations which are the characteristics of his eloquence. The CSIRO budget was sliced by $9m. Then, when the Government was returned last year, we found the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, was given technology as part of the dismemberment process of the scientific area of government. No one denies that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has some very pressing problems which need technological support for their solution. Senator Button unfortunately sees technology as an instant product to be laid on. He does not see it as the end product of a process which will draw upon the reservoir of intellectual strength which a nation builds around basic research and the strength of well chosen project research strategically related to our long term industrial future; for example, new welding technology. The Minister for Science in his statement is properly eloquent on this point. The spin-off of skills from this fundamental world will become available for problem solving of short term problems, but the intellectual environment for short term problems does not have a life of its own. It is organic to the more basic outreach of intellectual effort.

Thus, Senator Button, who has taken over the argument for the Government attack on CSIRO and university research, embraced a dangerous fallacy when he said: 'To endorse basic research, however, is not necessarily to say that it has to be at the same level as at present'. The fact is that basic research is not high. Its current rate is 10 per cent, and it may go up to 15 per cent, although there is some doubt about that. How can politicians step in and tell scientific bodies what basic scientific research is worth while and what is not? We have to create a reasonable environment for the leaders of the scientific community to do that. Governments can set guidelines for funds, and that is prudent, but for the Government to slash and cut in the best toe-cutting tradition of the Labor Party is not a process which commends itself to anyone, least of all the scientific community.

Not only has Senator Button taken over from the Minister for Science the vital decision making power in the area of technology, but he has also set himself to warn the scientists of Australia that this Government thinks that too many of them are wasting their time. What is Senator Button's input into the current dispute now developing over a review of CSIRO? The basic issue is the effort of the Government to shift research effort from fundamental areas to problem solving for industry. There is an important connection and a need, but the Government needs to encourage industry to do more. That is the matter which should be in the Government's mind when it considers taxation reform.

The system of licensing imported technology for manufacturers in Australia has a life of its own, independent of CSIRO and scientific policy. The remedy for building a better system of incentive for Australia to do more research and development lies squarely in Senator Button's hands. The patents and licence system can be greatly improved, but that is not a cause which grows out of CSIRO's functions, although it can be ably assisted by CSIRO as it stands ready to assist industry. The Minister rightly calls for industry to lift its game, but the administration of the Industry portfolio should give firm commitments now to the creation of a broad system of incentives, including tax relief, promised by the Prime Minister prior to the last election.

As recently as last Tuesday, Senator Button was still unsure when the 150 per cent tax write-off would be introduced. He went further, proclaiming that the Government does not in general approve of these tax concessions. What hope then is there for the economic future of Australia through research with a Minister such as this? Whether such ambiguous statements are intended to pave the way for a backdown is unclear, but the situation certainly needs to be clarified. The Minister for Science understands these things, but the Prime Minister and Senator Button do not understand them. They prefer the Medicare approach of the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett)-destroy before you create. That is the Prime Minister's approach in things he does not understand. The statement of the Minister for Science carves the message: 'No review of CSIRO is necessary'. One only has to look at the statement. The Minister said:

CSIRO has been of invaluable service to the nation in the past in making a major contribution to the success of our primary industries, which is the very foundation of our economy. It now offers a powerful tool for the task of restructuring and revitalising our manufacturing industries, which is essential to our future prosperity.

One could not get a more ringing endorsement of what CSIRO has done and what it is doing. Where is the argument for this review, which is now being undertaken against the advice of the Minister? Despite criticism, CSIRO has continued to get on with the job, including the vital job of servicing the needs of the manufacturing industry. The headlines in the Age of 7 May are not far off the mark: 'Review threat to CSIRO-Hawke, Jones clash over Probe on Government-funded studies'. I think there is proof enough of that in the Minister's statement today. He thinks the review is mistaken-if he does not, he certainly should. Of course, we are not really talking about studies; we are talking about a vital ingredient of Australia's economic future. That is what we are dealing with here.

We do not think that the pressure of the Government's concern is well placed. The problem is not CSIRO, but a Government which cannot get its policy-making house in order. That is the point of real concern. That is why the scientists, so difficult to stir, as the Minister has found, came to Canberra a few weeks ago to warn Australia what was going wrong in this area-an unprecedented gathering of scientists saying that it is not good enough.

The Government wants its mistaken attitudes to find the favour of a dim public memory. An inquiry is to proceed in its horse-drawn way, so that the Government's blunders can be buried in yet another report. The real inquiry required is an inquiry into the reasons why research and development has declined in the private sector. An inquiry into CSIRO is irrelevant to the national requirement.

It is clear that Senator Button seeks to brutalise CSIRO's established priorities, which place emphasis on strategic research; that is, the creation of basic technologies to give Australia a sound technological leadership. The Government is diverting the energies of the leadership of CSIRO in a contest made equal only by the fortunate fact that there will be a considerable lapse of time which will allow the Government to rethink its basic hostility to science. If the portents are right-this is the most hopeful thing-a coalition government will be given the task of sifting through the debris from the inquiry, and a coalition government will give proper support to the CSIRO and science.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
National Flag
To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) the Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that 'the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron,Mr Hawker,Mr Lloyd,Mr McArthur and Mr Shipton.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the passage of the Social Security and Repatriation Assets Test Abolition Bill to repeal the Labor Governments iniquitous and unfair Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cadman and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Small Businesses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
They adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not ''windfall gains'' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Acting Speaker has received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continued confusion and chaos surrounding the Government's tax reform proposals.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I could begin today's debate in no more appropriate way than to say on behalf of the Opposition: 'Welcome back Cliff Dolan'. Over the last few months, for a combination of reasons-one of them ill health, about which we are very sorry, and we are pleased to note Mr Dolan's restoration to full health, together with visits overseas and the like-we have not heard a great deal from Cliff Dolan. But over the past 24 hours Cliff has really become the silent man, the sleeper of the great tax debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Remember all those headlines last week? It was only a week ago, but a week really is a long time in politics, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has found out today. The headlines included: 'Optimism after tax talks', 'PM on tax: full speed ahead'. That was in the Sydney Morning Herald. The Australian Financial Review had 'Consumption tax now looks certain'. 'Government-ACTU near deal on taxes'. That was even better and that was in the Australian. 'Unions ready to give tax the nod' was in the Sydney Morning Herald. Look at that beautiful photograph of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer. Look what the caption says-'likely to make port safely after a dangerous spell at sea'. Finally, we have the marvellous headline which says 'Unions veer to new tax'. All that was while Cliff was away. He had left the shop to the ambitious Simon and the ever present Bill. They sat down and had a bit of a talk and true to form the Treasurer did not come out and say exactly what was discussed at that meeting. Remember the dictum of this Treasurer when it comes to discussions with his party colleagues. It was very well summed up at his Press conference after the granting of licences to 16 foreign banks. The Treasurer was rolling around congratulating himself on what a great fellow he had been in conning his mates into throwing away their historic opposition to foreign banks. This is a report of what the Treasurer had to say:
Mr Keating went so far as to admit that the ALP conference resolution to issue only a ''limited number'' of (banking licences) was never intended to be honoured.
Asked whether he had engaged in a ''ploy'', Mr Keating replied 'not so much a ploy, but one is not bound to be frank always'.
It would appear that the Treasurer was less than frank when he was talking to Mr Crean and Mr Kelty and he was less than frank in the leaks that he authorised about those discussions.

However, he has been caught out by Cliff Dolan. Cliff Dolan belongs to the old Labor school. I do not agree with his policies, I think they are out of date, but he is honest and he has been consistent. Cliff Dolan's only mistake in this whole debate is to believe that if the Labor Party says in an election campaign that it will do something or that it will not do something it means it. Throughout this whole debate the policy chameleons on taxation have been those who now sit on the Government front bench. They are the people who have bobbed and weaved, dodged and ducked from one position to another. Cliff Dolan has consistently maintained the historic Labor Party opposition to indirect tax. Why would he not do so? Why would he not maintain that historic Labor Party opposition to indirect tax? He was encouraged until very recently to believe that that was the policy supported by all leading members of the Australian Labor Party because year after year leading members of that Party have gone around Australia stirring up hysterical emotional opposition to a sensible change in our taxation system. If, as a result of that, the attempts of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister fail they will have only themselves to blame. They will not have us to blame because it is they who have gone around the country over the last few years stirring up, on a totally dishonest and irrational basis, opposition to a sensible change in our taxation system.

Who could blame the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in the face of such a campaign, for saying: 'I believe this. I am a simple believer in the old Labor Party faith of opposition to indirect tax'? He heard the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) year after year when he was shadow Treasurer in the last Labor Opposition criticise indirect tax. The Minister said that my faith in indirect taxation was 'absolute nonsense'. The Minister said that indirect tax was regressive, highly inflationary, would exacerbate economic recession and would be a totally unsatisfactory means of dealing with taxation reform. Those are the unrepudiated words of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. That is not the end of the matter. At the National Press Club on 25 August 1982 the Minister said:
We have indicated a general opposition to or dislike of increases in indirect taxes.
He said again on 8 September 1982:
Increases in indirect taxes are likely to reduce the equity of the tax system.

They are not the words of Cliff Dolan on AM this morning, although they sound very like them: They are the words of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, spoken a bare two years ago. No wonder the President of the ACTU cannot quite kick the habit of being opposed to indirect taxation. His only crime is that he was converted to the cause. His only crime is that he believed that when an Australian Labor Party leader got up and said 'We are against a broadening of the taxation base' that would remain Labor Party policy. Of course, he did not count on the philosophical flexibility of the present Treasurer. He did not count on the policy chameleons of the present Government that now sit on the front bench. He did not count on their capacity to repudiate the things that he thought they believed in.

The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), that great friend of freedom of choice in the Australian education system and that great friend of all sorts of other causes in the Australian education system, said that indirect taxation was iniquitous, that it was inflationary, that it could not be justified in any economic or social way and that the range of people affected by it would be enormous. One could almost imagine that we were hearing the words of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). So it goes on. The then Leader Opposition, the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Hayden), said:
. . . I intend to strongly oppose what I regard as the misguided proposition that Australia should be moving towards a greater reliance on indirect taxation.

That was said in November 1982. If we go back over the last five years we finds that virtually every prominent ALP spokesman had something to say in opposition to indirect taxation. Is it therefore any wonder that Cliff Dolan should state the attitude that he stated on AM this morning? It is a wrong attitude. It is an attitude that I have always repudiated. It is an attitude that the Opposition repudiated in the last election campaign. It is an attitude that is out of date but at least Cliff Dolan, unlike his colleagues, is showing a germ of consistency on this matter. If any people are to blame for Cliff Dolan espousing that view, and if any group of people is to blame for the difficulties that now exist in persuading the Australian community and the trade union movement of the desirability of changing our taxation system, it is the very people who are now trying to undertake that persuasion. They are the people who, year after year, fed the lie to the Australian people that some kind of indirect taxation system was wrong, inequitable and nasty.
