They are the people-the present Treasurer is one of them; the Prime Minister is one of them; the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is one of them-who, when we in the former Government were talking about changing the taxation system, went around the countryside stirring up every kind of emotional hostility.

Yesterday in the Parliament the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) pointed his finger at us and said: 'There are difficult choices that have to be made in Australia and everybody has to behave responsibly'. Government members did not behave responsibly when they were in Opposition. They did not give a darn about the need to bring about a change to our taxation system. They were interested simply in a short term political expedient. It is now coming back to bite them, because some of the people they were talking to listened to them. Many of the people they were talking to in the trade union movement listened to them. On the AM program this morning, Cliff Dolan was asked about the discussion between the Treasurer and the ACTU. What did he say? He said that the Treasurer either was lying or did not understand. That is what the President of the ACTU said when he spoke on AM this morning. He said that the Treasurer was either telling a lie or could not understand the plain, ordinary meaning of the English language. I do not mind which charge the Treasurer pleads guilty to. It has to be one of them.

What did we hear from him today? What did we hear from the lamb today? He said: 'Well, you know, there really isn't any agreement between us'. I notice the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) grinning and nodding in approval of that. There is no agreement between the ACTU and the Government on taxation reform. The Treasurer went one step further and said: 'Not only is there no agreement; but if we can't get the ACTU to come to the party it's not on'. That is what the Treasurer said. Yet last week he was the greatest fellow in the world. We read all those beautiful headlines about how he had broken through and the armies of opposition were in retreat. He did not count on General Dolan, who was called back in to service. What did he say? He said: 'Look, Paul, it's not on, mate. It's not our policy'. So the General came back and the whole issue is now back in the melting pot. There's no one happier, of course, than the good old honourable member for Melbourne. He has been consistently wrong on the question of taxation reform, but at least he has been consistent as, indeed, has the President of the ACTU.

There can be no clearer difference on a matter of principle than that which exists on this issue between the Government and the Opposition. The coalition was the only group of parties in the last election that had the honesty to say what we would do in regard to taxation. We went to the people and we said: 'We have a tax policy'. We said that first and foremost that it must be based on the proposition that unless spending is reduced overall taxation cannot be reduced. This present Treasurer has produced the biggest taxing and the biggest spending Budget since Federation. This Treasurer has increased spending at three times the rate at which it rose under the Fraser Government. This Treasurer has had some forward estimates dragged out of him today. Do honourable members remember the forward estimates of two years ago? They were sacrosanct. They were holy writ. Everything that was stated in them was right. A year later they were illusionary and a bit shonkey. A year later still the Treasurer did not even want to let them see the light of day until he was forced to do so by the Prime Minister and his colleagues.

We have to reduce spending if we are to improve the taxation system. We said we favoured a broad-based consumption tax. We made that perfectly clear during the election campaign. We were candid, we were frank about it; unlike the Treasurer, who was devious and deceitful about it. On 28 November 1984 the Treasurer appeared in a debate with me on The World Today. I ask honourable members to listen very carefully to what he said. I bet Cliff Dolan heard it and that is why he has gone a bit sour on the Treasurer. He said:
The only people promising a broadly based consumption tax in this election is the Coalition parties under Mr Howard.
Let me make this quite clear. We've got no plans for any new taxes, we are not campaigning in this election on any new taxes.

Those were the words of the Treasurer during the election campaign. They were worth as much and were as honest and as candid as the words he used at the opening of the ALP campaign in Dundas on 7 November. Those words have an ironic sweetness in view of what is to come on Tuesday night. He said:
I have completely ruled out any mini-budget next year.

Those were the words of the Treasurer when he opened the ALP campaign. No wonder Cliff Dolan does not trust him. Good old honest Cliff might be wrong, but he sticks to his principles. I heard him say many times before the election: 'We're in favour of capital gains tax. We're in favour of wealth taxes. We're in favour of death duties. We're dead unimpressed with indirect taxes'. That has been Cliff Dolan's position all along. The difference in policy between us and the Government could not be clearer. We have a policy. We support a broadening of the tax base and a lowering of personal tax. We support income splitting. We will have none of this radical feminist claptrap from people such as the Minister for Education and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who want to discriminate against single income families. We will have none of that kind of inequity. We believe in the introduction of tax deductions for child care expenses to facilitate choice and, of course, we are unalterably opposed to capital gains taxes, death duties and gift duties. That is a coherent package. We were candid enough. We had the guts to put it to the Australian people at the last election. We won marks, we won seats, we won votes because we put it forward. By comparison this Treasurer and his Prime Minister ducked for cover. They deceived, they fibbed, they dissembled, and it is now coming back to haunt them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I was amused to hear the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), refer to lambs. Yesterday, the Sydney Morning Herald had a front page headline claiming that it had the Government's tax package. Yet we had not one question from the person in the Opposition responsible for taxation the honourable member for Bennelong. As I walked by the table at Question Time, he said: 'What about Ross Gittins?' He did not have the guts to get up and ask a question. Today, at the end of Question Time, he said to the Prime Minister: 'I've got a harder question for you'. We know that as Deputy Leader of the Opposition, he could have had that question placed first or second on the list today, but he did not. Why was this so? It is all revealed in the Bulletin in an article entitled: 'Why Peacock has isolated Howard'. There is reference to his questions. This was not by sudden chance or indolence. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Peacock is sitting on Howard, as firmly and discreetly as he can.

Yet in the honourable member for Bennelong came today. He was unable to ask a question yesterday and unable to do so again today. The lame duck waddles into the House to put up the third proposition, in the same terms, that he has put up in the last two months. We find now that he is relying upon Cliff Dolan and is taking his name in vain-as though Cliff Dolan would have anything in common with the honourable member! But, of course, this is the person who, at the first whiff of grapeshot on tax reform, went straight into the bunker. The great coward of the Australian tax debate, the honourable member for Bennelong, the spruce goose of the Australian tax debate, was all revved up but could not get off the ground. For years he told us how he would reform the tax system.

A couple of weeks ago I got a request from him for access to his papers when he was Treasurer. He asked for material about sales taxes and retail taxes. We find that he has given that material to Laurie Oakes. An article in the Bulletin this week states:

How John Howard did the spadework for the sales tax. This is how desperate he is to get his name on the maker's label. I will tell honourable members what he did. He made tax reform in this country so hard by putting up propositions and then having them shot down and dragged into disrepute. He did the spadework all right. He dug a great big hole for everybody who was serious about tax reform in this country. He did so through his cowardice in raising the issues and then ducking into the bunker the moment that the first whiff of grapeshot came by him. He should not talk about his having any credentials on tax reform. He never at any stage attempted to get tax reform. The first no he got from Malcolm Fraser was the final no. He got back into his hole in the way that he is in his hole now under the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). Good on the Leader of the Opposition, if he can keep on top of the honourable member. That is where the Leader of the Opposition ought to keep him.

The honourable member for Bennelong was suggesting that he had something sensible to say about tax reform. All that can be guaranteed from the coalition with relation to tax reform is that the coalition is determined to be a negative influence. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said: 'We will pass this Government's tax package no matter that we may be opposed to measures in it'. He said that. I understood what he said. He was saying: 'The Government has a mandate for it. The Government campaigned on it. The Government said that it would have a tax summit and that it would review the tax system. It has a mandate for its changes' by implication, he said 'I am prepared to give the Government its changes and take my chances in the electoral market place at the next election' I respect that view. If he thinks he can beat us on our tax reform measures, that is fine. But for how long was he allowed to stand by the statement that he would pass a capital gains tax if it were part of the Government's program or that he would pass a broadly based consumption tax or any other changes to the income tax base? For how long was he able to stand by that statement? He was nobbled within three days. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition spent three days persecuting him within his own Party and then, at the Thredbo meeting, the Leader of the Opposition was forced to back off from his statement of principle that he would allow the Government to pass the package for which it had an electoral mandate. That is where the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his Party stand on tax reform. They will pick the eyes out of any Government reform package. They will support the things in which they can find comfort-the things about which they are ideologically obsessed-but they will do nothing but that. They will oppose everything else. As with the assets test, they believe in means tested welfare but do not agree with the assets test that we have. The same sort of double standard and hypocrisy that we have seen with the assets test we will see with relation to tax reform. That will extend even to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition trying to derail any process which the Government has under way in terms of tax reform.

I do not mind the Deputy Leader of the Opposition making the stupid point that I am supposed to have said last Friday that the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government are in perfect agreement on tax reform. I never said such a thing or intimated such a thing. The fact that some journalist on AM cannot get the information straight does not impress me at all. The fact is that on Friday I said, and I will repeat it, that we had had a useful meeting with the ACTU. The whole point of tax reform is to try to get groups focusing on the same problems and the same set of data so that people of goodwill can hope to draw the same conclusions. That is the difference between this Government's approach to tax reform and the approach of the former Government. We have been doing what has to be done to get structural change in this country.

One has to talk to the various constituent groups. One cannot hope to do it by running an idea up the flagpole and then diving back into the bunker the first time the grapeshot goes over one's head, which is what the previous Government did for years and what its cowardly Prime Minister and leader did also. That is not what we are doing. I understand the risks in terms of newspaper headlines, speculation and the sort of stupid, idiotic point scoring such as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is now engaged in. I understand all of those costs. That is the price one has to pay for consultation. But some of the roadblocks in the Australian economic system can be pushed to one side. Without that kind of consultation and that focusing on the appropriate data and the appropriate arguments, that structural reform is not possible.

At no stage did the coalition speak to anybody, not even business. Leaving aside the ACTU, it did not even speak to business. Let us not kid ourselves that the coalition ever spoke to business. it said: 'Business has nowhere else to go; it will not go to the Labor Party. We will not consult it. We will treat it with contempt'. The coalition Government had given business an inflation rate double everybody else's, a 20 per cent interest rate and had driven its profits into the ground. It did not consult with business. It never tried to get reform. The former Treasurer hid behind the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System as though all he had to do was to commission someone to do a study. Anybody can do a study and put his conclusions on the ground. But the former Treasurer could not get the changes in and he proved that. That is what this is all about; it is about getting the changes through-not about knowing what to do.

Anyone can work out what to do but it is a different matter to get the changes through. The previous Treasurer had no framework to get them through. The business community holds him in contempt. The trade union movement holds him in complete contempt because his record with trade union members was one of virulent attacks on them from the day he took office. How dare he take Cliff Dolan's name in vain as though Cliff Dolan would have any sympathy with the honourable member or any point of accommodation with him. Cliff Dolan would hold in contempt every last member of the Opposition, including the former Treasurer. We have had enough of that hypocrisy.

The fact is that the coalition Government at no stage ever sought to do anything about tax reform in this country. One of the problems of the current tax system is the breakdown of compliance with the system. That breakdown of compliance has accelerated through the 1970s as the system was left and dragged into disrepute by the inactivity of the former Treasurer and the former Government in sanctioning blatant tax avoidance through paper schemes-knowing about them in 1975 but doing nothing about them until 1982. That is the reason why the tax system is in a position of major disrepute. It is also in that position because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was using the inflated tax dollars to give the promise in 1975 and 1977 of tax indexation. He took in the tax dollars and watched the massive compression in the scales, the massive increase in marginal rates, so that now we have a narrow income base with massive marginal rates of taxation. Whom can we thank for that but the coalition Government.

The coalition has governed this country for 30 of the last 35 years. The tax system is in the state it is in because of the coalition's failure to do anything about it. The high marginal tax rates in this country are a consequence of the coalition's complete disinterest in the state of the tax system. The coalition fudged its way through the 1970s with $3 billion from the crude oil levy, which allowed it not to do anything about marginal tax rates. This got the coalition off the hook of indexation. The coalition slid through the 70s, taxing people through stealth, through the taxation system and through inflation. That is the problem that we face today. But did the former Treasurer come in with an indirect tax, with a trade-off proposition for tax cuts? Never! He came in with an indirect tax as an add-on to the tax system. There was no talk of a tax package. There was no talk of knocking the rorts out of the system. There was no talk of removing the tax shelters, of removing the rorts, or of wiping out the paper schemes. The former Treasurer was driven to wipe out the paper schemes by Mr Costigan and Mr La Franchi, who produced their reports and embarrassed him. He then tried to hide behind the secrecy provisions of section 16, only to be flushed out by Bill O'Reilly when he published his telephone book of letters against him. That is the record of the former Treasurer and the former Government.

The former Treasurer never at any stage tried to do anything about tax reform. He never sat down and said: 'The system is in disrepair. Let us try to agree on the basics for change. Let us talk to business, the unions, the various constituent groups and the social security lobbies to try to find a solution to this seemingly incurable problem in taxation'. We had one pathetic attempt to talk about indirect taxes and then it was straight into the bunker. We then had broken promises on tax indexation and tax cuts and inactivity on tax avoidance and evasion. The former Government left the smelly heap on our doorstep for us to do something about it. As with a lot of other challenges, we are facing this one. The former Treasurer might think that it is clever to come into this chamber and score off us because we are in a consultative process and because there have been material leaks in newspapers. That is all well and good. But the point of the matter is that nobody outside this Parliament will be impressed by what the honourable member for Bennelong had to say or by what he is doing.

I noticed yesterday-this is a point I have made before-that the small business organisations were misreported in a Taxation Commissioner's report which stated that there were losses of $4 billion in unincorporated income. I corrected that point and I said that is was $1 billion. One of the small business lobbies said that I have charged the small business community with tax evasion. That statement about unincorporated enterprise was made by a Taxation Commissioner, not by me. I thought I had made that point adequately. The fact that it has not penetrated the minds of some of those lobby people is more a commentary on them than it is on me. The fact that we now have massive under-reporting of income, evasion of the system and non-compliance is just a manifestation of the problem. How can we expect people to comply with the system when over the years, they have seen everybody who has received any tax advice ripping off the system and the Government sitting by and watching it happen, as it did right through the 1970s and the early 1980s?

We on this side of the House will continue to press ahead with our electoral mandate for tax reform. We will continue to press ahead with the tax summit to seek as much agreement as possible. I will continue to consult with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and every other relevant body. We will not be deterred from this important but difficult mission to try to secure some important and lasting changes to the Australian taxation system. At the end of this Parliament the Australian people can make a judgment about the end product of our work compared with the end product of the work of the former Government. They can make a judgment about the bona fides of the Opposition when they look at its failure to develop a constructive attitude to tax reform and they look at the kind of opportunism which it is displaying today with this mealy-mouthed, stupid attack on me, Dolan and everybody else involved in the question of tax reform. We will let the public be the judge, but the people will judge honourable members opposite harshly, as they did last year and as they did two years ago. After the next election they will remain where they are-on their backsides in opposition, where they deserve to be; the grubs that they are; the people who could do nothing with Australia; the people who shirked all the challenges. The public will leave them where they are-rotting in opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was interesting to hear the Treasurer (Mr Keating) claiming that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has some difficulty in getting some questions up. My recollection is that the first time the Treasurer popped the question it cost him money. If he wants some more answers like that he should continue to call us grubs because that is where we can put him any time we like. I have a message for the Treasurer from the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), who said in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . obviously it would be a very serious matter, if there was a likelihood or a significant risk of the sort of CPI increase which could flow from some of the levels of consumer tax which some people are suggesting, that is a CPI increase of the order of 7 per cent or even higher, feeding back via the indexation into wages.

The Treasurer can tell us what message he has just got from the Senate in that regard. Mr Deputy Speaker, welcome to the day of tax confusion. A check of today's status of our tax future, as revealed in recent newspapers, tells us that we have a Treasurer who wants a 12 1/2 per cent retail tax. We have a Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and leader of the Left who does not want a retail tax but believes that he will reduce the Budget deficit by harassing pensioners. We have the convenor of the Centre Left, Senator Peter Cook, who just wants higher taxes. We have that redoubtable numbers man, Senator Robert Ray, who wants death duties. We have the leaders of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, who do not want retail taxes and would prefer higher wages. We have that noted media spokesman for the Left, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand), who wants increased taxes on wealth. Then, of course, we have the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and all he wants is to be popular. He wants to be popular with the people. He wants to be popular with the Caucus factions. He wants to be popular with President Reagan. The harder he tries the less popular he gets. We all know that because no one trusts him any more. His popularity is declining with his continued indecision. We call him 'backdown Bob'. His inability to keep his promises is now matched by his inability to make decisions. He just wants to be popular and he does not know on whose side he wants to be at the moment.

Let us have a look at some of the U-turns made by this Prime Minister, this man who must make the final decision on tax. We have had the MX missile reversal and the Sinai reversal. We have had the Age tapes reversal, the tertiary fees reversal and the Medicare reversal. We have had his statements on productivity from which he backed down the following morning after Simon said. We have had the interest rates reversal and his promises that he would reduce interest rates. What a total lack of decision and leadership.

Let us have a quick look at that very topical business of Queensland and the role of the Prime Minister there. He has two choices: He can attack the Queensland Government, as he frequently claims in this chamber that he can, with his foreign affairs power-something of which I do not approve but which he can do if he likes-or he can attack the unions through section 45D of the Trade Practices Act. But what does he do? He does neither. He has two different options and he chooses neither.

Not for him the political hara-kiri of some positive moves in the tax debate towards reform. He is sitting down, hiding away, waiting for the fight to be over. That is what he did in the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Nothing has changed. His program is simple. First, he wants to get approval from the ACTU. Second, he wants to try to flatter those non-union guests to the summit to approve the ACTU line, as he did at the National Economic Summit Conference. Third, he wishes to convince Australians that such approval is tantamount to the approval of all Australians. Those 100 people he will invite to the summit will be presented to Australians as their community representatives. Of course, during that summit, he will go on with the line that we hear every day that all the Opposition is trying to do is to make political points. We are not here to make political points; we are here to protect the public from people who are as extravagant and as irrational as honourable members opposite. They go on about the assets test as the Treasurer just did. The assets test is an attack on poor people who have property. Honourable members opposite have never been able to make that link.

The tax summit is a sham and those attending who have any illusions that the Government sees this summit as a learning process must think again. But let us have a look at who will get to the tax summit. In the Australian the other day, all printed up for us, we find that 27 of the approximately 100 people attending the summit will come from the ACTU executive, not solely from the trade union movement. They represent 2.9 million Australians-many unwilling contributors-out of the 100 people invited. Of course, we had a very similar situation when he had that so-called farce, the Economic Summit. Small business, which I try to represent in this place, will have approximately five representatives; yet between 1978 and 1982 its 700,000 employers generated 310,000 jobs while big business shed 288,000 jobs. That is all the attention that this Government will pay to small business. What about the other sectors? Who is getting all the consultation in this tax debate? Day after day we read in the newspapers that the Australian Council of Trade Unions said this, or the Treasurer rang up the ACTU; someone is always consulting the ACTU. It is entitled to be consulted. What about the small business community? What consultation is it getting? What real consultation is the Australian Taxpayers Association getting? The farmers have been heard and have been told to go away because the Government does not agree with their figures. Why has not small business been consulted on the great financial and administrative burden that the implementation of a retail tax will impose upon it? It would not have been a bad idea had the Treasurer or the Prime Minister bothered to respond to a telex which I sent to them. It stated:
Your reported intention to introduce a retail sales tax raises the need for sympathetic and sensible consideration of those in business who will be obliged to collect your tax.
The present wholesale sales tax places excessive burdens of both administration and liability upon the business involved.
The extention of such a tax system to the retail sector will vastly increase the number of voluntary collectors and extend to relatively unsophisticated business administrations.
Further, the community does not expect a repeat of the asset test fiasco where total administration costs exceeds saving.
I seek your assurance that these business proprietors will be either compensated for their efforts or if not, that your government will
A Not demand payment of tax before it is collected from the consumer
B Place the onus of collection of tax lost through genuine bad debts with the Commissioner and not the retailer
C Produce a simple taxing regime that can be administered without the small business operator having to give substantial amounts of valuable time to preparing returns and statistics.
Small business already carries a disproportionate burden of government charges and it would be intolerable to place further burdens upon them.

My telex has not even been acknowledged or replied to. No doubt that very sincere effort was also considered as a political ploy. The Government proposes to appoint 5,000 more tax collectors. That is what the Government talks about when it talks about the problem that it will impose on small business. That is quite unnecessary. The tax can be collected simply and the administrative burden can be very small. I do not think that the Government would know how to do that as it has shown with the assets test-get the 1,500 employees first and worry about the details later.

Let us have a look at an average weekly earnings graph which was published in the Weekend Australian recently. It is very interesting. There are two massive peaks in the marginal tax rate. The first peak occurred in 1973-74 in the Whitlam years. The other peak, which has taken the marginal rate for average weekly earnings into the 40 cents tax bracket, occurred in 1984-85. Thirty years ago an average weekly earner paid 10.2 per cent of his salary in income tax. Today he pays 24 per cent. At that time his marginal rate was 19.2 per cent; today it is 47 per cent. Today, if a person on average weekly earnings wants to buy a modestly priced new motor car, at $10,000, he must earn $18,870 on overtime to be able to afford it. Out of the $10,000 he will pay $1,300 in sales tax. If he wants to work overtime to buy the car he will pay dollar for dollar to the Government. This situation has been created as follows: Tax revenue was raised by 9 per cent in one Budget and 17.9 per cent in another Budget, an effective 30 per cent increase in two years. Expenditure went up by 15.6 per cent in one Budget and 13 per cent in the other, an effective 31.25 per cent increase. The Government's trilogy promise is based on that record. I shuddered when the Prime Minister promised things were not going to get worse. How could they get worse? The Government has increased taxes by 8 to 10 per cent since the previous Government was in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have witnessed, once again, the charades in the acting out of what is purported to be a serious debate on tax reform during this discussion of a matter of public importance. If honourable members look at the former Treasurer's contributions in previous matters of public importance debates they will notice that they have a certain repetition about them. I am reminded of a Michael Jackson film clip: The former Treasurer steps out on to the stage, waves his arms around, makes comments about the graveyard of tax reform in the 1970s, waves his arms around a little more and goes back off-stage again. The reality is that during the period that the former Treasurer had the responsibility for tax reform, nothing was done. When we have these debates we are simply repeating arguments that we have had very often. This Government is seriously approaching the fundamental issues of tax reform in a co-ordinated and responsible way and consulting widely with the community. It is my confident hope that at the end of that process there will be a more equitable, simple and productive tax system. Quite recently a very learned commentator on tax reform issues, Professor Russell Mathews, described the current situation thus:

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia, it is no longer necessary to be rich to be liable for penal rates of income tax. There is a popular conception of the tax system which views it as a kind of Robin Hood taking away from the rich to give to the poor. This must be recognised, like Robin Hood himself, as pure fantasy.

I must demur from this learned gentleman's opinion. It is my very strongly held view that there is not a popular conception that the system is in any way progressive. That may have been the case some 10 or 15 years ago, but it is certainly not the case now because of the widely held view that too many people have the option of paying tax and that increasingly, as is empirically the case, the burden of payment of tax revenues is falling almost totally on the shoulders of ordinary pay as you earn taxpayers. Much has been said in this House about the increase in the level of payments over the last decade or so. I will not traverse that ground again. Professor Mathews continued:

Because of the widespread tax avoidance and evasion which characterises the Australian tax system, the nominally progressive rate structure is inoperative except for wage and salary earners. Far from emulating Robin Hood, Australian taxation policies have more in common with the protection rackets operated by the Mafia, where relatively poor and defenceless citizens are taxed for the benefit of the rich.

Professor Mathews has very articulately summarised the current state of the art in terms of taxation policy in Australia. In a very lucid address to a tax forum recently held in Sydney he went into the complexities of our tax system and offered some propositions for reform. It is sad indeed that when members of the Opposition debate these issues they tend to confine themselves to personalities, they tend to embrace hyperbole and exaggeration and they never try to address the very serious issues that we are attempting to confront in terms of tax reform.

The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has been in this House for a long time. Did we hear him argue against the people who were ripping off our tax system in the previous Government? Of course we did not. Members of the Liberal and National parties ought to be ashamed of their record on tax avoidance and evasion. Tax avoidance and evasion literally exploded under the previous Government. In June 1975, under the Whitlam Government, a total of 861 individuals and companies were identified by the Commissioner of Taxation as being involved in tax avoidance schemes. The sum of money involved was $973m. Compare this: By June 1983, at the end of the period of the Fraser Government, the number of individuals and companies involved had grown to 34,944 and the tax in dispute amounted to $1,666m. That ought to be a matter of considerable shame.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much now?

—It is no good the honourable member interjecting. He likes to interject. He was silent in this House when these rip-off merchants were carrying money away from various schemes in a wheelbarrow. It fell on to the shoulders of the ordinary PAYE taxpayer to provide the revenue for roads and schools, et cetera. It became optional to pay tax under the previous Liberal Government. Opposition members ought to be ashamed of that.
—You have a million dollar tax cheat on the front bench of your Government.

—The honourable member for Denison interjects in his gutless way. I suggest that if he proposes to do that he should at least have the courage to confront the person against whom he addresses those allegations. I shall recall a couple of comments made during that period. In 1978 the President of the Taxation Institute of Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: During the past year or two, tax avoidance became big business in Australia. It became a disease which, being allowed to go unchecked, reached epidemic proportions.
Nothing was done. In 1980 Professor Russell Mathews stated:
Tax authorities, governments and the courts have allowed tax avoidance to flourish on such a scale as to make personal income tax a voluntary tax for the rich non-salary earner.

Frank Costigan, the Commonwealth Auditor-General, Phillip Lynch as he was in those days, and Mr Gyles, QC, the Special Prosecutor, have also made statements on the matter. The Australian Taxation Office estimates that 6,000 companies were involved in bottom of the harbour schemes and that their promoters alone earned about $150m in commissions. Currently before the courts are some of those who have been caught up in the whirlwind of this Government's legislation which has attempted to ensure that tax is paid on an equitable basis and that those prepared to rip off the system and break the law go where they should, that is, before the courts to be properly assessed by a judicial forum.

The Hawke Government's response, by comparison, has been worthy of commendation. In both opposition and government the Australian Labor Party served notice that the tax avoidance industry would be seriously challenged. Indeed, sales tax legislation will be brought into this House later today which will attempt to recoup approximately $400m avoided by those not prepared to contribute their fair share to Australia's welfare and future.

It will be interesting to see whether the Opposition parties, both here and in another place, are prepared to treat that sort of legislation on its merits to ensure-at least to a marginal extent-that the ordinary PAYE taxpayers of Australia can obtain some relief. One can go through the changing of attitudes to section 260 of the Income Tax Assessment Act-another area in which this Government has taken some initiative. There has been a significant increase in the penalities for avoidance and the pursuit of tax avoidance individuals in this country.

We could talk for a long time about our commendable record on these matters but it is worth getting back very briefly to the fundamental principles that will guide the tax summit. I note, without comment, that the honourable member for O'Connor, when he was not invited to the National Economic Summit Conference, had the temerity to come into this chamber and squat. He severely embarrassed his colleagues because he did not have an invitation although he alleged that he should have had one. Now he has an invitation and he is not prepared to take that up, quite simply because the Opposition parties will be obliged to put up or shut up. They will not have the luxury of being able simply to address themselves to personalities or to repeat tired jargon that they have been pursuing, at least during my membership of this chamber. That is why they have not accepted the invitation. They do not have any ideas. They want to have the luxury, as soon as a tax package is produced before this House, to oppose that package for the most base of political motives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I understand that the honourable member for O'Connor seeks to make a personal explanation. Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During the speech of the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffiths), he made a statement which I am sure you heard, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I did not raise matters regarding tax avoidance in the previous Parliament, of which he was also a member. I draw the honourable member's attention to my identifying the tax evasion of $70,000 and tax avoidance of over $1m of probate which was undertaken by the now Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins).
—Order! The discussion is concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 in two main respects. Firstly it will enable Telecom Australia, in specified emergency situations, to intercept a telephone call in order to establish the location of a caller so that appropriate assistance can be given. Secondly, it will enable formal evidence of acts done by Telecom employees in enabling members of the Australian Federal Police to execute an interception warrant to be given by certificate in court proceedings.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act permits a Federal Court judge to issue a warrant to members of the Australian Federal Police to intercept telecommunications in the course of investigating narcotics offences. The warrant is given to Telecom whose employees take the technical steps necessary for police to conduct the interception.

Initially, material obtained by interception was used for criminal intelligence purposes. However, as it is admissible as evidence in criminal proceedings, there are cases where it is appropriate and necessary to put the material into evidence. Strict proof of actions taken by Telecom employees would require those employees to give evidence in court. Telecom management has been advised that employees are unwilling to give such evidence because public identification of their involvement in narcotics interception would cause fear for their own safety, that of their families and that of their fellow workers.

Telecommunications interception is of great assistance to the Australian Federal Police in the prevention and detection of drug offences. It would be contrary to the public interest for the lawful interception of telecommunications to be reduced or prejudiced. In this Bill, the Government proposes that evidence of acts performed by Telecom employees to enable the execution of an interception warrant be given by a certificate signed by the Managing Director of Telecom. Such a certificate would be conclusive proof of the matters contained therein. The matters which will be contained in the certificate are formal matters of evidence only and do not go to any issue before the court.

The Government recognises that there is an objection to a prosecutor seeking to establish, by certificate or averment, an element of the prosecution case going to the conduct of the accused. However, proof that a warrant was executed strictly in compliance with its terms is a purely formal matter. Further, proving compliance by certificate would not conflict with the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee has taken the view that Parliament should enact legislation to ensure that averment provisions are only resorted to by prosecutors where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant. Further support for this proposed amendment is to be found in the reports made by Mr Frank Vincent, QC, and Special Prosecutor Redlich.

I turn now to the other major amendment. A number of organisations and individuals have requested that Telecom be allowed to conduct emergency interceptions in order to locate the origin of a call where life appears at risk. The classic situation is where a person informs another, by telephone, that he or she proposes to commit suicide. As the law currently stands, such interceptions are unlawful.

The Government accepts that any interception of a telephone call is an invasion of privacy and is cautious in extending lawful interception. However, it is clearly desirable to locate the origin of such calls as soon as possible. It is also desirable for police to be able to communicate the location of the distress call to persons who can assist in preserving life. Accordingly, the Government proposes that the Act be amended to provide that, where a member of a police force forms the view that the tracing of the location of the caller is likely to assist in dealing with the emergency, he may request Telecom to intercept the telephone call and to provide the location of the caller to police. The amendment also provides in effect that the police may lawfully communicate the whereabouts of the caller to people such as ambulance officers or doctors who can assist in preserving life.

The use of this power of interception will be monitored. The Bill requires the Managing Director of Telecom to report annually to the Attorney-General on the general circumstances of each intercept. The Bill also provides for the Attorney-General to table that report in Parliament.

The Act also makes a number of minor amendments. The first is to rectify an omission in the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1985 passed by the Parliament earlier this year. The amendment in question referred to documents or information which may be given to the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. It included a definition of 'unlawfully obtained material', as meaning certain documents or information which disclosed the commission or possible commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or a law of a Territory. This Bill adds to that class certain documents which disclose the commission, or possible commission, of an offence against a law of a State. The Bill also provides that this amendment be deemed to come into operation on 29 March 1985, the date upon which the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1985 commenced operation.

Sub-section 7 (6) of the Act provides that material obtained by an interception may be lawfully given in evidence in certain prosecution proceedings. This Bill makes it clear that those proceedings include committal proceedings. Finally, the Bill provides that this amendment, and the amendment enabling certain matters to be proved by certificate, apply in relation to proceedings instituted before or after the commencement of the Bill. This Bill has no financial implications and I commend it to honourable members.
Debate (on motion by Mr Everingham) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill (No. 1), continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Bill into each period of sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making a large number of non-contentious amendments. Some of the amendments made by this Bill tidy up, correct and up-date existing legislation. Other amendments are of minor policy significance or are matters of routine administration. The Bill amends some 65 Acts to remove obsolete provisions relating to the rights of Commonwealth public servants. Those provisions were made redundant by the repeal on 15 March 1981 of the Officers' Rights Declaration Act 1928. Officers' rights are now preserved by section 87TA of the Public Service Act 1922.

Administrative changes to the Commonwealth Public Service were made following the elections last year. The changes included the renaming of departments, the creation of a new department and the transfer of functions. Amendments to 25 Acts have been included in the Bill as a consequence of these changes to the machinery of government. The Bill also amends a number of Acts by removing any references to 'British subject' by reason of the passage in 1984 of the Australian Citizenship Amendment Act 1984. Also, in accordance with Government policy, the Bill amends a number of Acts by replacing gender specific terminology with epicene terms. Amendments are proposed to bring certain penalties in legislation up to date with present economic values and present day perceptions of the nature of the offences to which they relate. Many of the proposed amendments will be self-evident or sufficiently explained by the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill. I propose to confine my comments to addressing the more noteworthy changes included in this Bill.
Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980

Consistent with long standing Australian support for the conservation of Antarctic fauna and flora, the amendment to the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980 enables the ratification of the Convention for the Conservation of Antarctic Seals.
Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972

The amendment will permit the making of standing acting appointments to the Australian Institute of Marine Science, thus obviating the need for Executive Council action to be taken in relation to every absence of the Director.
Australian Security Intelligence Organization Act 1979

The Act currently requires the Security Appeals Tribunal, subject to one qualification, to give copies of its findings to the applicant, to the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and to the Commonwealth agency concerned. The Tribunal has recommended that it should have a discretion to furnish copies of its findings to the Attorney-General. The Government accepts the spirit of the recommendation, but considers that the Attorney-General should be given a copy of the findings in every case because he is responsible for ASIO and for the administration of the Act. The Act is amended accordingly.
Australian Tourist Commission Act 1967

The amendment empowers the Commission to invest its funds, subject to Division 2 of Part XI of the Audit Act 1901, instead of Division 3 of Part XI as at present. This will enable the Commission to make the best possible use of any surplus funds and to keep its accounts in accordance with normal commercial practice.
Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984

The amendments permit adjustment levies imposed under this scheme to be recovered in the same way as if they were excise duties. Also, the responsible Minister may notify proposed levy adjustment alterations when Parliament is not sitting.
Bounty (Electric Motors) Act 1984

The amendment will ensure that the value added figure applied to a bountiable motor includes the cost of any process or service-if provided by the manufacturer at registered premises-unless research, development or design costs apply. These latter costs, if incurred in Australia, attract a bounty irrespective of whether the work was undertaken on registered premises.
Cocos (Keeling) Islands Act 1955

The amendment will enable the making of ordinances for the operation of the Supreme Court of the Territory of Cocos (Keeling) Islands and will provide easier access to that Court for members of the public
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904

The amendments concern the financial accounting and reporting requirements under Part VIIIAA of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 for registered organisations and their branches. Organisations or branches whose annual incomes do not exceed $10,000 will be able to apply to the Industrial Registrar for a certificate of exemption from the existing financial and reporting requirements of the aforesaid Part of the Act in relation to accounts. Instead, less onerous and costly requirements will apply to those bodies.
Defence Act 1903

Under the common law, members of the Defence Force cannot sue the Commonwealth for moneys owing to them in respect of their service. Section 12 of the Defence Act 1903 varies this position to a limited extent by permitting members to sue after leaving the Defence Force. This situation is changed by extending to serving members of the Defence Force the right to sue. Because garnishee proceedings do not lie against the Crown this procedure is not available to creditors of members of the Defence Force. The amendments create similar statutory rights and obligations regarding garnishee proceedings in relation to members of the Defence Force to those that apply to other Commonwealth employees. The Bill also makes other amendments to this Act.
Defence Force Discipline Act 1982

The provisions of this Act provide for the issue of summonses and warrants on the basis of sworn information or affidavit. The amendments power authorised officers of the Defence Force to swear informations. Under the Act a commanding officer may direct that a subordinate summary authority is not to deal with a particular charge against a person. The amendments will enable a commanding officer to direct that a subordinate summary authority is not to deal with a class of cases. There is a requirement under the Act that legal officers, to whom convictions by summary authorities are referred for legal advice, should be authorised or appointed for this purpose. The amendments omit the requirement for such authorisation or appointment as this will create an unjustifiable administrative burden.
Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

Following consultation with the Northern Territory Government amendments to the Act are proposed to ensure that appeals from the Supreme Court of the Northern Territory will lie to the Northern Territory Court of Appeal instead of the Federal Court of Australia. The amendment is expressed to come into operation on a date to be fixed by proclamation. A date will be fixed after appropriate consultation with the Northern Territory Government and after that Government has taken the necessary steps to establish its Court of Appeal.
Health Insurance Act 1973

A number of amendments to the Health Insurance Act are being made as a consequence of the replacement of the Capital Territory Health Commission by the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, which was effected by the Health Services Ordinance 1985.
Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976

The amendments provide for wrecks and articles lying above the low-water line to be protected under section 5 of the Act provided the Government of the State concerned has no objection. Provison is made for States including the Northern Territory and Norfolk Island to make a general declaration on all wrecks over 75 years old; in addition, the time limit for a provisional declaration is extended to five years and the protected zone of a shipwreck increased to 200 hectares. The amendments also make provision for wrecks straddling Commonwealth-State waters.
Insurance Contracts Act 1984

The amendments overcome minor problems relating to the provision of information or advice to insurers. The amendments should facilitate the operation of the Act when it comes into operation later this year.
Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946

The amendments will enable the Minister to provide guardianship to minors, who have entered Australia with a supporting relative, when care arrangements have broken down. The consent of the supporting relative is required. A person whose interests are affected by a guardianship decision may apply for a review of the decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
Life Insurance Act 1945

The main amendment will enable life offices to transact business, relating to the issue of annuities for purposes of roll-over of lump sum termination payments, in the same statutory fund in which superannuation schemes are transacted.
Management and Investment Companies Act 1983

The principal amendments to this Act increase the time limit applying for the filing of annual returns by licensed management investment companies, to allow a more reasonable period for compliance. There is a consequential change in the expiry date for licences.
National Gallery Act 1975

A number of amendments are proposed which will enable the Australian National Gallery to be more efficiently administered, enable it to undertake additional functions and activities, and establish an Australian National Gallery Fund with a power to invest funds. The need for the amendments, which are largely of an administrative and machinery nature, has become apparent now that the Gallery has been operating for more than two years.
Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

The amendments give effect to minor technical amendments recently adopted by the Marine Environment Protection Committee of the International Maritime Organisation's International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, 1973-78.
Sex Discrimination Act 1984
The amendment will enable 'class' exemptions from the Act to be granted to avoid a multiplicity of applications for exemption in certain circumstances.
Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975

The Bill provides for a number of amendments to overcome administrative problems which have arisen since the Act was extensively amended in 1978. The proposed amendments have the general support of the National Labour Consultative Council. I commend the Bill to the House.
Bill (on motion by Mr Everingham) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This is the main Bill in a package of six Bills that together will amend the sales tax law in a number of important respects. Included in this Bill are measures necessary to counter arrangements under which wholesalers are avoiding sales tax by selling goods by retail under agency and other marketing arrangements. The Bill also reflects this Government's firm resolve to stamp out tax evasion. Substantial sales tax evasion has recently come to light based on abuses of the present procedures for registration of sales taxpayers and their right to obtain goods free of tax by quotation of a certificate number.

The Bill therefore contains a number of measures designed to strengthen the existing sales tax registration and quotation procedures. Some proposals of the former Government announced on 20 August 1981 that will correct deficiences in the existing machinery and liability provisions of the sales tax law are also covered by this Bill. I turn now to the details of each measure.
Indirect Marketing Arrangements

This Government's views on tax avoidance are well known. We came to office on a promise to smash tax avoidance in all its forms. Sales tax has not been immune from the influence of the promoters of tax avoidance schemes. But sales tax avoidance, once it takes hold in a particular industry, is cancerous in its growth. The level of sales tax payable directly affects the ultimate price of goods and its avoidance by one firm in an industry gives an unwarranted competitive advantage in the market-place to that firm. Others in direct competition with that firm are often forced to engage in similar sales tax avoidance or go under. One particular avoidance arrangement that has gained currency relies on the fact that sales tax is generally payable on the last wholesale sale in the marketing chain. The amount on which the liability for tax is calculated is intended to include all the costs and profit-margins of those in that chain up to, but not including, the retailer. Known as agency schemes, these arrangements are based on a wholesaler appointing a normal retailer as agent. As a result, the wholesaler technically becomes the retailer for the purposes of the sales tax law.

Prior to entering into the scheme, the wholesaler's goods would be sold to the retailer who, as owner of the goods, would sell them to customers of the retailer's store. Under the scheme, the wholesaler retains ownership of the goods, but places them in the retailer's store alongside the retailer's normal stock. The retailer, as agent of the wholesaler, then sells the goods to those same customers of the retailer. This complex and highly artificial arrangement is claimed to have the result under the existing sales tax law that sales tax is payable, not on the wholesaler's former price to the retailer, but on the price at which the wholesaler purchases the goods. This price is, of course, much lower and excludes all of the marketing costs of the wholesaler and the wholesaler's profit margin. The cost to the revenue of these arrangements is estimated to be at least $200m per annum.

There is another variation on the same theme. In this case, the wholesaler obtains permission to use a section of the retailer's store from which the wholesaler's goods are sold direct to the public. Again the goods are displayed alongside the retailer's goods. From the retail customer's point of view there is no distinction to be seen between the two. As with an agency arrangement, the wholesaler assumes for sales tax purposes the mantle of a retailer. Floor-plan arrangements, like agency arrangements, are claimed to exclude from the taxable sale value of the goods concerned the wholesaler's costs and profit margin. The considerable savings in sales tax sought to be obtained by these schemes are used to achieve a competitive edge in the particular market for the wholesaler's product and to inflate the profits of those firms engaging in them. Those wholesalers who, on principle, resist the temptation to enter such schemes and who continue to market their goods in the traditional manner suffer as a result. That is not a situation that this Government will tolerate.

At the same time, the Government recognises that some businesses have for many years, and for genuine commercial reasons, sold their goods to the public through agents and, to a lesser extent, under floor-plan arrangements. While there is no sales tax avoidance purpose present in this situation, the revenue is affected in the same manner and to the same degree.

The Government sees no valid reason for excluding from the amendments those who, although their use of agency and floor-plan arrangements can be justified on sound commercial grounds, benefit from similar reductions in the amount of sales tax payable. For this reason, the amendments will not require that there be a sales tax avoidance purpose, nor will they be retrospective in effect. (Quorum formed)

Under amendments proposed in this Bill, where any person, other than the manufacturer of goods, sells goods by retail under these arrangements-referred to in the Bill as indirect marketing arrangements-sales tax will in future be payable on the fair wholesale market value of the goods. In other words, the sales tax advantage sought to be achieved will be removed. This is done by treating persons who sell goods under indirect marketing arrangements as wholesale merchants for sales tax purposes. A similar result to this is already achieved in the case of a manufacturer under the existing law.

Some consequential changes to the sales tax regulations will be required and these will be submitted to the Federal Executive Council for approval after this Bill has been passed by the Parliament. The new basis for taxing sales of goods under indirect marketing arrangements will apply to sales of goods made after the date of royal assent to the Bill. This will allow time for those who will, under the Bill be now treated as wholesalers to become registered for sales tax purposes.
Registration and Quotation Procedures

Once a person becomes registered as a sales tax payer, that person has to meet a number of obligations that arise under the sales tax law. There are, also, certain privileges associated with being a registered sales tax payer. The most significant is the ability to purchase goods, sales tax free, in certain circumstances, by quoting the number of the sales tax certificate that is issued upon registration. Substantial sales tax evasion is occurring because registered persons are abusing this privilege by quoting, or purporting to quote, a certificate number when purchasing goods in situations where they ought not to do so because they do not intend to meet their sales tax obligations. At the same time, unregistered persons are known to be quoting bogus numbers when purchasing goods and obtaining those goods without payment of the sales tax due on them. So far as the vendors of the goods are concerned, it is more often than not a case of complicity by studied indifference to the false quotation. Those vendors claim that, under the present law, they need not be concerned about whether or not the purchaser's quotation is lawful.

A feature common to such practices is that payment is made in cash of a substantial amount and the purchaser often gives a false name and address to avoid being traced. These fraudulent practices are of the worst kind. Every taxpayer in Australia is a victim of the unprincipled participants in these frauds. The cost to the revenue is estimated to be upwards of $200m annually. Action is currently being pursued by the Taxation Office, with the assistance of the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions, to bring the participants in the frauds before the criminal courts. That is, however, a long and complex task and the Government cannot, and will not, stand idly by while the criminal law takes its course.

Stricter administrative arrangements are, in the Government's view, called for. Measures in this Bill will, therefore, strengthen the registration and quotation procedures in several ways to counter these evasion practices. First, the maximum level of security that the Commissioner may require from a registered taxpayer, or a person seeking registration where he considers the revenue is at risk, will be increased from its present level, set in 1930, of $2,000 to $25,000. Secondly, the Commissioner will be authorised to refuse or revoke a sales tax registration where the basis of the application was false or misleading, or where security is not provided when called for. Thirdly, the Commissioner is to be given the authority to prohibit a registered person from quoting his certificate where the Commissioner is satisfied that the person has abused, or has aided or abetted others to abuse, the certificate quotation procedures. Another feature of the new arrangements will be that the Commissioner will be authorised to publish in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette, or to circulate vendors with, details of certificate numbers that have been cancelled, revoked or withdrawn.

The most significant measure against evasion to be put in place by this Bill will be a positive duty on vendors of goods not to accept quotations for sales tax purposes if the circumstances surrounding the transaction appear to be suspicious. More particularly, in future a person will be liable to make good any sales tax evaded where, upon receiving a quotation from a purchaser of goods, there are reasonable grounds for believing that the purchaser is not a registered sales taxpayer. The quotation is unlawful, the quotation is false or misleading, or the certificate number quoted has been published or circulated by the Commissioner. Where a suspected quotation turns out to have been valid, the Commissioner will be able to remit or refund any tax payable or paid by the vendor.

As a corollary to this measure, a collector of customs is to be authorised to retain imported goods that have been the subject of a quotation, where the collector entertains doubt about the bona fides of the quotation, until sales tax is paid. Decisions of the Commissioner in relation to registrations or quotations of certificates that will be made under these new arrangements are to be subject to the usual rights of objection by affected taxpayers with a further right of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. These changes will also operate from the date of royal assent to the Bill.

I turn now to mention certain proposals of the former Government that are also the subject of the Bill. The proposals are among those announced by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition as Treasurer on 20 August 1981 and which my colleague the present Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) indicated in a statement of 30 March 1983 that we would proceed with. Drafting resources have not permitted some of the more complex proposals of the former government to be included in this Bill, but those of an anti-avoidance nature have been included and the remaining proposals will be made the subject of a later Bill.

The first measure I mention concerns a technical problem with the definition of manufacture contained in the sales tax law. One particular aspect of that definition has been exploited by some manufacturers in a way at variance with the intention of the legislation. This will be overcome by a re-expression of the definition in this Bill. This measure will, as announced by the former Government, apply with effect from 20 August 1981. This change is expected to lead to the recovery of approximately $1m in avoided sales tax.

Another measure will bring the provisions of the sales tax law relating to returns and payment of sales tax on imported goods into line with the Customs law and procedures. This is to be achieved by applying, from the date of royal assent to the Bill, sales tax on imported goods at the rate applicable at the time the goods are entered for home consumption under the Customs law. The transitional provisions applicable to certain anti-tax avoidance amendments of the sales tax law made in 1978 have also been found to have an unintended operation. These transitional provisions are, as announced by the former Government, to be terminated with effect from 20 August 1981. This termination will prevent further indeterminate revenue losses.

Finally, the Bill provides for a broadening of the information gathering power of the Commissioner to ensure that it extends to access to goods and gives taxation officers the right to examine, take samples of and analyse goods. The opportunity is also being taken to ensure that persons are required to provide reasonable assistance to the Commissioner in the exercise of this power, thus overcoming in relation to sales tax a limitation on the information gathering powers of the Taxation Office imposed by a recent decision of the High Court of Australia.

Mr Deputy Speaker, an explanatory memorandum containing detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill is being made available to honourable members and I do not therefore propose to further address the matters covered by the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Everingham) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Keating, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill contains a further measure to counter sales tax avoidance. Together with the three remaining Bills in this package, it will ensure that royalties paid in connection with the manufacture, sale or lease of goods, but under arrangements that have the effect of excluding them from the taxable sale value of the goods, will not escape the payment of sales tax. Since its enactment in 1930, the sales tax law has contained a general provision designed to include in the taxable sale value of goods royalties paid in respect of the goods.
Sales Tax Assessment Bill

Avoidance arrangements have developed under which the intention of the present law can be readily circumvented. The result is that royalties that ought to form part of the taxable value of goods are freed from sales tax. The arrangements in question, which are particularly prevalent on the recording industry, were described in some detail in statements by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition on 20 August 1981 and 6 January 1892 when, as Treasurer, he announced the then Government's intention to amend the sales tax law to counter these particular avoidance arrangements. Under one arrangement, a retailer engages a manufacturer to manufacture goods to order and the retailer sells the goods either by mail order or direct to the public, often via an agency or floor plan arrangement. I have spoken earlier about these practices. Under the arrangement the retailer has the responsibility for payment of, and pays, the royalty on the goods. The amount of the royalty is therefore not included in the taxable price for which the goods are sold to the retailer by the manufacturer.

Under measures contained in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill 1985, royalties paid by retailers who sell goods under indirect marketing arrangements will be subject to tax under the present scheme of the sales tax law. This Bill will cater for the additional situation where a royalty is paid in respect of goods, but the person who pays the royalty is someone other than a person who has dealt with the goods. Without such a measure, the royalty amendments in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill could be easily circumvented. Because of the definition of 'royalty' in that Bill which is to be applied for the purposes of the Bill, royalties paid for the performance or exhibition of matter subject to copyright, such as a musical work or a motion picture, will not be subject to tax under the measures in either Bill. The cost to date to the revenue in relation to goods sold under royalty arrangements, other than indirect marketing arrangements, has been around $2.5m. This Bill, because it is not retrospective in its effect, will not recoup that lost revenue, but it will prevent further revenue losses.

For constitutional reasons, and to conform with the existing structure of the sales tax law which is contained in nine separate assessment Acts, each with its complementary taxing Act, this Bill proposes the enactment of a further assessment Act that will be entitled the Sales Tax Assessment (No. 10) Act. It contains the necessary machinery provisions for the assessment, collection and administration of the new tax on royalties. The measures contained in the Bill will apply to royalty payments made on or after tomorrow in respect of goods, notwithstanding that the goods may have gone into use or consumption in Australia, provided that the goods on which the royalty is paid were the subject of a taxable transaction or act for sales tax purposes under one of the other Sales Tax Assessment Acts. Explanations of technical aspects of the Bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Everingham) adjourned.

This is the first of three taxing Bills that I mentioned in introducing the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) 1985. It is a requirement of the Constitution that a law imposing taxation shall deal with only one subject of taxation and that laws imposing Customs duties and laws imposing excise duties deal only with those duties. This Bill will, respecting that requirement of the Constitution, formally impose sales tax payable under the Sales Tax Assessment Bill (No. 10) on royalties in cases where that sales tax is technically a duty of excise. As I explained in introducing that Bill, the sales tax will be payable by the person who pays the royalty. The rate of tax on such royalties is declared by the Bill to be the rate of tax applicable to the goods or which the royalty is paid. I commend the Bill to the House.
