This would assist in unifying the area and providing a greater cohesion of services. The Committee approves the variation subject to the incorporation of the area into the suburb of Monash.

Variation 11 provides access to a site within the Erindale group centre. The new plans for Erindale as a group centre allow for a total of 4,000 square metres of retail space plus 2,100 square metres for a hardware store, a garden centre and catering and drinking establishments, and will provide much-needed retail services for the area before construction of the Tuggeranong town centre. With regard to variation 13, which provides for a major realignment of the extension of Drakeford Drive, the Committee approves works associated with construction of the proposed road from Isabella Drive to Johnson Drive. However, approval is deferred on the section from Johnson Drive to Tharwa Drive pending further information concerning the intersection of Tharwa Drive and proposed land development in South Tuggeranong.

Variation 14, which provides access roads in north-western Theodore to new residential blocks, is approved on the proviso that initial purchasers are informed of the lack of bus services and other facilities in the area.

Variation 16 proposes to delete some roads from the city plan in order to set aside a portion of the proposed residential area as public open space which contains Aboriginal axe grinding grooves and artefacts regarded as having high archaeological and general heritage significance. The Committee approves variation 16 and stresses the necessity for the development of adequate protective safeguards of the Aboriginal artefact site from acts of vandalism and desecration. I thank the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO MEXICO AND CENTRAL AMERICA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Mexico and Central America and seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to thank our Consul-General in San Francisco, Mr A. J. Melhuish, for his kind assistance to the members of the delegation and for the reception given by him and his wife in our honour. To our perceptive Ambassador in Mexico, His Excellency Cavan Hogue, who is now our Ambassador to the United Nations, and Mrs Hogue, as well as to the entire staff of our Mexican Embassy, I convey our many thanks. They looked after us extremely well in Mexico and travelled with the delegation through Central America. The briefs, written and oral, provided by the Ambassador and his staff were of great value to us. Without the help and guidance of our ambassador, our delegation would not have been as successful as it was.

SPEECH.PARA: I also wish to express my gratitude to our High Commissioner in Jamaica, where my wife and I made an unscheduled stop. We spent several hours in Kingston in the company of His Excellency Mr R. E. Little and his wife, without previous notice and on a public holiday. It was Independence Day in Jamaica. Our discussions helped me to understand the socio-political and economic situation in the Caribbean, as well as to compare it with the Central American situation.

In contrast, I wish to mention that on our return to the United States of America, two other Government members of the delegation, Senator Maguire and Mr Michael Maher and my wife and I spent a day in Los Angeles. To our dismay, the Consul-General in Los Angeles was too busy even to send a driver to assist us, even though we had cabled notification of our arrival weeks before.

Finally, I would like to thank Mr Derek Abbott, the secretary to the delegation, for his untiring work and the excellent manner in which he performed his duties, and to express our gratitude to Mr Max Hughes, who travelled with us representing the Department of Foreign Affairs and who is now our Ambassador to Poland. I valued his prudent advice and we all enjoyed his company.

In July last year, I led the first Australian parliamentary delegation to Central America. We visited Mexico, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica. The group of countries we visited have many things in common. First of all, apart from local Indian languages, Spanish is the common language and over 90 per cent of the people are Catholics. Ethically there is little difference between the people in the various countries, again except for the Indians. The size of countries in Central America varies, although with the exception of Mexico, which is the size of Queensland with a population of over 70 million, all are small by our standards.

Also common to all countries we visited is the fact that most rely on agricultural exports as their main income. Only Mexico has developed an import substitution industry to any sizable extent; it has become a net exporter of petroleum. It is also common to all States that they are all suffering badly from the economic crisis, as the prices of their agroproduce is depressed on the world markets. Of course, in my opinion, the depressed prices of Third World country exports are not a coincidence but are another form of exploitation of the underdeveloped world by the rich North. Manipulation of world prices, coupled with artificially high interest rates payable on loans from the International Monetary Fund and other Western banks, makes the bleak economic situation of countries on the isthmus and the poverty of their people even worse than it otherwise would be. During my travels, I came to the conclusion that the Third World is underdeveloped not by some historical accident, but because the exploitation by the developed world keeps it underdeveloped.

Central American countries, of course, have a common history. The Spaniards conquered the area in the sixteenth century. By the seventeenth century the colonial administration was established and the mining of silver and gold brought enormous riches to few. The development of latinfundias, the rich landowner class and the mass of landless peasantry, further enlarged the enormous socio-economic gap that today characterises the countries of Central America.

We, as visitors, could not help but notice at first glance, on the one hand, the poverty of the people living in mud huts or makeshift sheds made from cardboard and tin, without sanitary facilities and, on the other hand, the enormous luxury that the rich live in. Without the military, the oligarchy would not be able to maintain its riches and privileges; hence, the long string of various military dictatorships after liberation from colonial rule. It is only the arms, domestic and foreign, that still perpetuate the rule of the elite. It is in this light that one can understand the social instability of the area.
The Reagan Administration is trying to brainwash the world into thinking that the revolt of the oppressed people in Central America is due to the communist influence of Cuba and the Soviet Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, too.

—I will come to that. It presents in its propaganda the simplistic picture of struggle between East and West. All the evidence that I could gather during the delegation visit convinces me that the struggle of the people of Central America is a struggle between North and South. I cannot emphasise enough that the problems of central America are North-South and not East-West. The United States effort to prove otherwise is belied by its long history of intervention in Central America. Nearly all the countries in the area suffered from United States military intervention long before the communist revolution in Russia. Time and again the United States invoked the Monroe Doctrine-its self-given right to rule and dominate the Central America region-long before United States politicians heard about communism. The problem is not Soviet arms and the Cuban presence in the area, but United States arms and the United States military presence over a century which have prevented progress and supported the perpetuation of oppression and exploitation of the people in Central America through Western transnational companies and domestic oligarchies. One has only to recall the history of the United States invasions and intervention last century and early this century in Panama, Puerto Rico, Honduras, Cuba and Nicaragua to establish who is pulling the strings in Central America.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that as long as there is no resolution of socio-economic conditions in Central America, there will be no peace in the area. The United States has throughout history supported the rule of domestic dictatorships and the rule of the privileged elite and is doing this even more today thus preventing the resolution of the problem and keeping the people of Central America in poverty and deprivation. The United States intervention has in the past prevented, and continues to prevent, the development of political pluralism by its support for the rule of the elite which always reverts to military dictatorship to safeguard its privileges when quasi-democratic means fail.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will send you off to Afghanistan and see how you come back.
—I see the honourable member for Mitchell is not too pleased with this.
—Order! the honourable member for Hotham will ignore the interjections and continue with his Committee report.

—The irony of the situation which the delegation found is that the oppressed people of Central America, who are desperately fighting for freedom, are forced to look for encouragement to the Soviet Union where there is no individual freedom, while the United States, which grants these freedoms to its own citizens, does everything to deny such freedom to the brutally oppressed and exploited people on its own doorstep. United States influence and intervention bring with them oppression and denial of basic human rights. This is nowhere more obvious than in El Salvador where human rights violations are appalling. In Honduras, though human rights abuses are less obvious, they still exist, even though, like in El Salvador, the real power in the country is vested in the hands of the American Ambassador. In contrast with this, we found no evidence of atrocities in Nicaragua. To the contrary, we saw there signs of an emerging democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Arriving with us in Nicaragua on the same flight was Arturo Cruz, who had come from the US, where he had lived for some time, to register as a candidate in the presidential elections in Nicaragua. Some 200 of his supporters staged a noisy demonstration at the airport to welcome him. There was no hindrance to the free expression of their support. Can you imagine Solzhenitsyn or the like arriving freely back in the Soviet Union to lead the opposition. Yet the US officials wanted us to believe that there is a Soviet-type dictatorship in Nicaragua.

Ambassador Negroponte, in Honduras, as well as the US Charge d'Affairs, Mr Ken Bleakley, in El Salvador, made a point of telling us how the Nicaraguans are supplying the rebels in El Salvador with arms. They forget to mention that El Salvador and Nicaragua have no common borders and that the sea routes are controlled by the US Navy. Overland the only route to supply arms would lead through Honduras, where the US and Honduran Army are in control, not to mention the Contras, the US financed rebels who are active on Nicaraguan borders.

The United States intelligence has the means, by electronic surveillance, to pinpoint a pistol on the ground, yet we were not shown any captured shipment of arms which would be sent from Nicaragua to the FMLN in El Salvador, nor were foreign journalists in the past couple of years. It is obvious that the United States has the means to detect the alleged arm shipments, yet no reports of such detection were proven to us or to anybody else. It is beyond doubt that Ambassador Negroponte and other United States officials were not telling us the truth when they alleged that significant arms shipments are taking place from Nicaragua to El Salvador. The truth is that the Salvadoran Army is armed by the Americans, that the United States Army is the real power behind Durate in El Salvador as well as in Honduras, where it is arming the Nicaraguan rebels, and the Honduran forces. In Honduras the United States army is physically present and is conducting exercises Big Pine 1 which took place just before our arrival and Big Pine 2 was scheduled for after our departure-together with Honduran forces and Nicaraguan rebel mercenaries. No one has to be a Rhodes Scholar to work out who is the villain in Central America.

The people of Nicaragua do not have surplus arms and military equipment for export. Their only export is agricultural produce-bananas, coffee and excellent rum and cigars. Nor is the Reagan Administration afraid of the military might of a small nation of three million living on a territory twice the size of Tasmania. What the Reagan Administration dreads is the example of Nicaragua that a small nation can shake off the United States yoke, that a small but united people can rid themselves of United States imposed dictatorship of Somosa and elect a popular regime whose aim is to serve the people of Nicaragua and not the interest of foreign monopolies and the domestic oligarchy.

The success of the people in their fight against tyranny is the reason for Reagan's obsession with Nicaragua. The President of the strongest and mightiest country in the world is hell-bent on destroying a small nation. When his own Parliament refused funds for such a purpose the President imposed a trade embargo on Nicaragua. Our Government, together with many other governments of the Western alliance, is opposed to Reagan's trade embargo. So are many other countries, especially those in the region, such as Mexico and the rest of the Contadora group. Reagan's policies are counterproductive and are designed to force Nicaragua into Soviet orbit against the expressed wishes of the Nicaraguan leaders. Finally, let me quote from a statement of the Mexican Government relating to the situation in Nicaragua:
Mexico is convinced that the only proper way to solve the current conflicts in the Central American Region is through dialogue and through negotiation.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is supposed to be a debate on the report of a parliamentary delegation.
—This very much concerns our delegation and our observations.
—It is your personal view.
—Absolute rubbish!
—I know that honourable gentlemen opposite are supporting the offensives.
—Order! The honourable gentleman will ignore the interjections and continue.
—The statement continues.

SPEECH.PARA: In view of the recent events, Mexico wishes to express its deep concern that the processes of negotiation in the region may be severely deteriorated. Mexico insists on the solution of differences between the States by means of negotiation and political dialogue, which is the only way to overcome the prevailing tensions. Applying economic sanctions is not compatible with the objectives of the Contadora Group.

I fully endorse the statement of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) disapproving of Reagan's embargo. I also fully support the Mexican stand and all others who support the right of the Nicaraguan people to determine their own destiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I have the report prepared and endorsed by the parliamentary group that went to Central America. Let me say at the beginning that it contains none of the statements just made by the Chairman of the delegation, the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) in his presentation of that report.
—Perhaps the honourable gentleman would like to give his version?

—Madam Acting Speaker, I would, but I think that has to be put on the record. Let me assure you that, had such matters been written, I doubt very much whether another member of the delegation, the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher), would have put his name to it either because that is not what we saw and it is not what we heard; it is the personal view of the Chairman. In fact, before the delegation left Central America, certain members of the group had to complain bitterly, in the presence of all members of the delegation, as to the political behaviour of the Chairman. We felt that that behaviour showed us as an extremely partisan group, not one that was there to listen, but one that had made up its mind before it arrived. This was no credit to an Australian parliamentary delegation-what is more, the first one that had ever visited there. There was some vigourous questioning from all sides and that was to be welcomed. But when it came to expression of opinions I remember only one occasion when the Chairman decided to change his mind and that was when he started to get a little bit aggressive with Mr d'Aubuisson and he then remembered, of course, that there were two loaded machine guns behind his back.
—Perhaps the honourable member would like to report on the delegation rather than the Chairman.

—Madam Acting Speaker, I am certainly reporting the facts in a way which you tolerated earlier. You listened to a political statement. As I said, I assure you that what was said earlier is not in this document. If I had the time I would read it to you. This is a well balanced document prepared by Mr Derek Abbott and it has my endorsement, but it does not say any of the things which have just been reported to this Parliament. What we heard was an anti-American statement that had very little to do with the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me say something about some of the things I noticed when I was with the delegation. I do not recollect many occasions when the Chairman and I were not in the same company. It was suggested that Nicaragua, of course, is the land of milk and honey and that there are no atrocities in Nicaragua. There is no doubt that the whole of the Central American area, with the exception probably of Costa Rica, is a place where violence is not uncommon on a daily basis. It is most tragic to see the level of problems that those people have, particularly when it comes to violence. In many places human life is not worth much. Nevertheless, if people suggest that it is any different in Nicaragua because they do not see guns in the streets they should think again.

In El Salvador we were invited to meet rebels in a prison. It was very clear that it was a proper prison, yet we were allowed to go into a cell in that country and, without any supervision whatsoever, talk to people. There were people who claimed to be in detention without trial. There were people who claimed many things against the government. We were allowed to listen to them and we listened to them in detail. There was no interruption to our listening and in all it appeared that we were getting the truth. We requested the same thing in Nicaragua. What were we taken to? We were taken to a model prison that was the next best thing to a holiday camp, specially contained for the purpose of showing tourists such as us. One fellow was a dentist. He was out on day leave all the time fixing up teeth in the other prisons, but it was not the sort of prison that was a prison. In fact, it insulted my intelligence because that is not what we wanted to see. That is the way we were treated there.

The Chairman of the Delegation has stated that there is no evidence of arms being taken from Nicaragua to El Salvador. Included in our trip was a visit to Costa Rica. Although the Chairman did not bother to spend much time on Costa Rica, it is as close to a parliamentary democracy as exists in that area. There is a good reason for that. I think it was in 1949 that the Constitution was altered to say that there will not be an army in Costa Rica. To this day there is no army. I felt we would get a balanced judgment in Costa Rica. The Foreign Minister, or a man at least of that order, told us that there was no doubt that Nicaragua was sending guns to El Salvador. In Mexico we talked to the representatives of the rebels. We asked them why they were not participating in the elections that were about to be held and which would be reasonably democratic. They told us that their safety could not be guaranteed. I raised that matter with the Deputy President to Mr Duarte. I asked why these people could not be guaranteed their safety. He said: 'They are lucky. Nobody is guaranteed safety in the political context in El Salvador'. That is a great tragedy. Approximately 20 per cent of their politicians from both sides have been assassinated in the last two years. He said: 'How would you like to be me? I am in the middle. I am a moderate. I get attacked from both sides, but I stood'. We then discovered why these people do not want to participate in the elections. At the very best they could attract 17 per cent of the vote. Only one person tried to tell us differently and that was the Foreign Minister in Nicaragua. He, a priest, insulted my intelligence by trying to tell me that they could attract 50 per cent or 60 per cent of the vote. Everywhere else we went-I repeat, I trusted the information given by the people of Costa Rica-they said that they could attract 12 per cent to 17 per cent of the vote. They will not participate because they cannot win. They are determined to win by the gun. Those guns are coming from Nicaragua.

Unfortunately the only thing that will save the El Salvadorean democracy-there are guns on every corner and assassinations are taking place- is the activities of the Contras in Nicaragua. They are taking the heat off El Salvador because Nicaragua is finding that it has got troubles on its own ground.

No doubt we were told a lot of lies in many places, but we were told a heap of lies in Nicaragua. I would not like to endanger some of the people who talked to me privately by telling honourable members what they said because I would fear for their lives. There is no doubt that things are not too good there. The situation is that what Somoza stole from the people, Ortega spends on guns. Of course, the people are no better off. The Government makes a big thing about giving them education, but the education is clearly not designed to teach them literacy but to teach them politics. There was a substantial influence of Cubans in that.

I was not going to speak on this particular issue. I support the report. I congratulate Derek Abbott on his efforts. He has done his best to give us the history and to try to put forward balanced and sensible remarks. It is a pity that it has been spoiled in this way. I reject entirely the statements regarding the United States of America. We met United States people in the embassies. They gave us the story as they understood it and they were a lot more believable on many occasions than some of the people we met in Nicaragua. I was happy enough with some of those people too. But to suggest that the United States is the only trouble maker in that area is not correct. It is a great pity that when we were there the Nicaraguans wanted to give us history lessons that we would often get from children. They kept telling us about a fellow called William somebody or other who was a pirate. He was not a representative of the United States, he was a pirate. He went there and took the country over. These sorts of things happened at that time. Of course, every kid in school gets taught that and has it poked down his neck. One would think that it had all occurred yesterday. These kids are being taught to hate the United States and yet the people scream like stuck pigs when any sort of embargo on trade is placed on their country.

Quite contrary to the Chairman's remarks, the only market the people of Nicaragua have available is the big United States market. That is being proved at the moment. Whether or not they are paid what everybody else believes they should be paid is a matter of market forces. They are not exploited because the United States probably does not need any of the products it buys off them anyway. It is rubbish to say that they are being exploited. Why do they not go to Russia or Europe to sell their goods so that they are not exploited? They are selling on the most convenient and the most profitable market. They just happen to grow things like coffee and bananas and there are a heap of them around. Honourable members might say that they should grow some sugar.

TALK.START.PARA: —An awful lot of coffee.

—Yes, but that is pretty hard to sell too. These countries have got great difficulties. I thought all of them were very hospitable to us and I thank them for the things they did. We all recognise their problems. It was an extremely interesting and informative delegation. The staff and the delegates worked extremely hard. Anybody who bothers to read the last pages of the report will see the type of itinerary that we followed. I am very pleased and gratified that I went there. It is a great pity that throughout this visit politics and people's views surfaced as to the rights and wrongs of what is happening in a place that we knew nothing about when we arrived. As I said, certain members eventually telexed the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and complained about that situation. At times we were embarrassed by statements that had been made in parliaments and other places. I am embarrassed again now because I thought that had all cooled and gone away. It is a pity that what is not written in the report was reported to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, it was suggested that Mr Arturo Cruz returned to Nicaragua. We were there. The honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher) remembers our arrival and the welcome that these people gave us. We interviewed this man two days later and he was already getting ready to leave the country because he discovered there were not going to be free elections. He was not going to have access to the politically controlled media. There is a free newspaper there, but the people have to travel twenty miles with all their editorial matter to submit it to an army base to be censored. By the time they got back it was too late to put it in their newspaper. They would not put a censor in there to make sure of it. They complained to us about that. More importantly, Mr Cruz was concerned that every time they tried to have a political meeting it would be disrupted. They were, therefore, window dressing to the world. He eventually left. He is a very fine man. Nobody would doubt that. He is a man of great integrity.

We met many other people who were all in the revolution against Somoza. Many of them were in the original junta. They moved away because they became so dissatisfied with the activities of Ortega. They learned what the Nuclear Disarmament Party has learned in this country just recently; that is, they start off with these sorts of people and they are all in it together. But as soon as they get the opportunity, they want to take over. These are the sorts of things that we learned in that country. That is the way it operates. There is no freedom in Nicaragua. I will admit that there is not much more in other parts of Central America. The people of El Salvador, to my mind, were making some serious attempts to get their freedom. We did not meet Mr Duarte but, as I said, we met his Deputy. These people also had difficulties, but it seemed to me that there was at least a degree of democracy.

I thank the House for its time. I again express my disappointment at the anti-American statements and dissociate myself from those statements. I am sure that my colleagues, Mr Groom and Senator Crichton-Browne, who is in the other place, will speak for themselves. I will be interested to hear whether the honourable member for Lowe supports his Chairman in such anti-American statements. He, too, might remember the Chairman's attack on a man of the clergy, a Roman Catholic archbishop. There was an attack made to the Press to which many of us took exception. Although there were rumours regarding that gentleman, there was absolutely no need for our delegation to make asides and remarks about it as were made to the Press. There is good reason for the Chairman to be a little ashamed of his performance on that trip. I am not saying anything with hindsight. As I said, I was one signatory to a telex complaining to the Prime Minister in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Mexico and Central America, as other members have stated, started in Mexico. No one has really touched on Mexico but it is a country of enormous importance to our nation. It is a non-aligned country, a very large country and a country in which, for the first time, I was confronted with some of the appalling problems of poverty, gross pollution and lack of social welfare. This was particularly so in Mexico City, which is probably the largest city in the world. The Government of Mexico was delighted to receive us and made us very welcome. I am very pleased to hear that a delegation from the Mexican Parliament is coming to Australia in a fortnight. I think that it does us great credit that we were able to induce some Mexicans to come here and study how our parliamentary system works.

SPEECH.PARA: As the report says, Mexico is virtually a one- party state. The Institutional Revolutionary Party has been in power since 1929, and it is the envy of many Western politicians. However, it is a revolutionary party that seems to have calmed down and to have become somewhat moderate. The members of parliament and the Ministers whom I met were people of great ability and capacity. Of course, the Mexicans are leading the Contadora group in its efforts to obtain peace in Central America. The Australian Government has done everything it can to support these moves for peace in that very troubled part of the world.

After some days in Mexico, we moved on to El Salvador, where we found an entirely different situation. That country has been wracked with a dreadful civil war in which 45,000 people have died and in which 5,000 people have disappeared. The first day we were there 30 people-mainly soldiers-were killed when a train was blown up; on the second day we were there 18 people were killed when a bus was forced off the road in an ambush; and, on the third day of our visit, a local member of parliament was shot while having his lunch. So I was glad to move on on the fourth day. It was quite a frightening place.

We did not meet Mr Duarte, the new leader. He was actually elected President of the country in 1972 but he never took his post. He was deposed and later tortured by the military. However, we did meet a wonderful man, Archbishop Rivera, the Archbishop of San Salvador and a successor of the saintly Archbishop Romera who was murdered while saying mass. Although at page 12, the report states that the rebel guerilla movement is opposed by the 'Roman Catholic Church', that was not what I had in the notes which I made of our conversation with the archbishop. My impression was that he said that there were priests with the rebels and there were priests with the army. He did not quite say what is in the report. I am not criticising the delegation's Secretary; that is from his notes, and I took notes as well. It was my impression that the archbishop was trying to get peace, not take sides and to remain neutral, as his predecessor had done.

El Salvador is a country in which there have been appalling atrocities, but I had great hope for El Salvador when we left. I believe that the Americans, who have been that country's ally and have supported it, have been outraged at the civil liberties abuses and at the horrendous events that have occurred in that country in the last five or six years-such as the murder of four American nuns, the disappearance of a young journalist who arrived at a hotel, went down to the bar and was never seen alive again. He was a young man named Sullivan, from New York. Other Americans were shot while having dinner. These are appalling atrocities. As well, a lady leading the civil liberties group was found murdered. It is an incredibly frightening country. El Salvador had hoped to chart its destiny on tourism. It built tourist hotels along its beautiful beaches and in its cities but they are all empty and smell musty. They are totally deserted.

However, I believe that the El Salvadoreans, with American tutelage, have started to break through. They have held a trial and have had convicted a member of the army for murdering the nuns. They have been able to protect not only the judge, but also the jurors. They have taught the local administrators how to protect prosecutors. Once upon a time if a judge, a juror or a prosecutor tried to convict somebody in the military in El Salvador, he would be found dead the next day. So the situation has improved. As the other members of the delegation have said, we met people from all sides. Since we have returned from that country elections have shown that the people have opted for the Christian Democrats, and I note with interest that they have received a lot of aid from the European Christian Democrats movement.

We had a number of briefings from the American Embassy about rebels in El Salvador. The Americans briefed us on alleged aid from Nicaragua to the rebels but there was never any clear evidence put before us that this takes place. The report touches on this matter. It says that some arms undoubtedly get through but a succinct case has never been put. However the case has not been believably put that aid goes from Nicaragua to the rebels of El Salvador.

The delegation also visited Honduras, but I want to touch on the work of Australian immigration officers in El Salvador. As honourable members will be aware, there was an amnesty under which hundreds of people in El Salvador were allowed out of gaol because there was no evidence whatsoever against them. It was dangerous for some of these people to remain in El Salvador because they had enemies in the military, or the left, or the right-who would know? Some 50 of these people and their families came to Australia. In all, we took 200 or 300 refugees from El Salvador. They are wonderful people. When we returned to Australia, I was upset to read in the Press that they came here without a security clearance. As I understand the situation, no refugee who comes to Australia is adequately security cleared. It is not possible when a person leaves his or her country and becomes a refugee to obtain a security clearance. We have received thousands of refugees. I was very sad to read in the Sydney Morning Herald an allegation that we may be at risk because, on humanitarian grounds, we took as refugees a handful of people from El Salvador who were not totally screened. These people were in gaol, sometimes for years. If they were let out, it was because there was absolutely no case against them. I commend any government that brings in people and saves lives, because the lives of these people would have been at risk had they stayed in their country.

I should also like to praise the work of Australian immigration officers who work in places such as El Salvador. We met Australian officers there who were most impressive and extremely brave. They have had to leave their families and work in a country where lives are very much at risk. I am extremely proud of our career public servants who go to such places.

The other controversial nation to which we went was Nicaragua. All these countries are very small. Nicaragua has a population of only three million people. It is a country in tatters. Its economy is in tatters and the capital, Managua, has never recovered from the earthquake in 1974 in which 40,000 people were killed. Nicaragua clearly united to throw out the dictators. The Somoza family, which was running the country in a most corrupt, appalling and immoral way, was thrown out-driven out of the nation-by a united front of groups including the Left, the Right, the church and the Marxists. However, it is five years since the revolution and because of unnecessary censorship, conscription for the armed services, and other reasons, the Government has become unpopular with a vocal minority. It has fallen out with the church-over censorship, of all things. Even mass on Sunday was censored in Nicaragua. Church officials told us that the archbishop's sermons were censored, which sounded quite incredible. I could not really appreciate why there was a need to censor such things, although there is a tradition in Central America and South America for archbishops to preach on political issues.

It is quite obvious that the church is totally off-side with the Sandanistas. We were told that all the foreign-born priests had been expelled. No Cuban advisers had been expelled. We met some wonderful people who were pro-Sandanistas-people who were Jesuits and members of the clergy. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), said, the Foreign Minister there is a priest. Who are we to go into the rights and wrongs of what side people are taking in a civil war situation in a country which has thrown off an oppressive regime?

Certainly we could never say that the church is pro-Contra. The Contras are running a war in the northern part of the country. I will comment about that later. It is a very difficult situation. I believe the elections last November will start to put Nicaragua on the road to true democracy.

I think the attitude of the Reagan Administration in the USA is not right. I support the Australian Labor Party Government's attitude to Nicaragua, which has been critical of the American boycott on Nicaragua. The United States Administration tried to finance the Contras to the extent of $14m and this was rejected by the American Congress. Having been to Nicaragua, to all of its neighbours and down to South America privately with Senator Maguire, I believe that the Congress's policy is the only policy to adopt. The Costa Ricans, in their small, Utopian country next to Nicaragua, are a very right-wing group of people. They are appalled at the prospect of the war continuing, of the American Government financing the war in that country against the Sandanestas. Although the Costa Ricans take a very conservative stance on all issues, they want the war to end. They told us how the refugees who are pouring into their country from Nicaragua are bringing in all sorts of diseases which the Costa Ricans have previously eradicated. They are bringing in malaria and leprosy. They are creating appalling situations in Costa Rica. Costa Rica's one hope is that the war will end.

I am delighted that the American Congress stood up to the President. I believe its policy is the only policy to adopt. I can only say truthfully what I saw and what I was told. I do not feel I have any bias one way or the other, either pro-American or anti-American. We were delightfully hosted and thoroughly briefed by the American embassies in Honduras and El Salvador, but I believe the American Administration is wrong and the Congress is right. That is not just my view; it is the view of all the countries in that region. They want peace. That is their big hope.

I will not delay the House tonight. I join the Chairman of the delegation in thanking the other members of the delegation. I felt the Chairman did a very good job. It is difficult to lead members from both sides of the House, people with diametrically opposite views, and their spouses through Central America, when there are civil wars in two or three of the countries. I think he did the job very well. As an Australian who was born overseas he is a credit to our nation and our Parliament. I thank the departmental adviser who came with us, Max Hughes, who is now the Australian Ambassador in Poland. He had great calmness, great common sense and offered good fellowship. Our secretary, Derek Abbott, also did a splendid job. It was hard work moving the delegation around. People became very ill. The previous speaker was extremely ill in one country. We were all sick at some time as we went along. The Australian diplomatic, consular and trade officers really looked after us in each nation visited. I could never say how much I appreciated the assistance of the former Ambassador in Mexico, His Excellency Cavan Hogue, his wife and his staff, who went out of their way to look after us. They accompanied us through all the countries and put themselves entirely in our hands. In San Francisco we were also looked after by the Australian Consul. Later, Senator Maguire and I were met and welcomed in Peru, Brazil and Argentina, when we went at our own expense to study nations in South America. There are many talented Australians working overseas, representing our nation in these foreign posts. Most of the countries we visited lacked civil order. In many places, the embassies are at risk and are threatened with assault and robbery. In some, we found that staff had even been attacked during hold-ups. I think these people are a great credit to our nation. We do not really give recognition to the work of those overseas officers and their families. Their role is not really appreciated by the population.

Finally, I thank the senators and members I travelled with. They were a wonderful group of people. We got to know each other well in very trying circumstances. I believe we all worked hard. We spread goodwill overseas and advanced the interests of our nation in Central America and South America. I believe these are parts of the globe that are very significant for the future of world peace.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON VIDEO MATERIAL

TALK.START.PARA: — Madam Acting Speaker has received advice from the Government Whip that he has nominated the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace) to be a member of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material in place of the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles).

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill seeks to amend the Housing Loans Insurance Act, which governs the activities of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. That Corporation insures lenders against losses on loans secured by mortgage, principally housing loans. I was making the point that the legislation seeks to change the Corporation in ways that are unacceptable. Prior to the debate on this Bill being adjourned I made the point that the Corporation is being provided with a government supported reinsurance capacity which other insurers of mortgages do not have and is being given a government supported reinsurance capacity for other insurance companies which is unavailable to private companies insuring mortgages. I also complained most bitterly about the special provisions in the legislation which allow the Minister to direct the Corporation to engage in activities that the Minister thinks are important. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) said in his second reading speech:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government envisages that use of the 'special interest' provision will be strictly limited. It will be used only where proposals have particular importance in terms of the Government's housing policies and where mortgage insurance will not otherwise be provided because of the application of strict commercial principles.

So it is a political direction for the first time in the history of this Corporation, which has a very fine record. I resent the approach that the Government has taken in this matter. I said also that the Government had failed to deal with the difficulties of the secondary mortgage market by having discussions with State Governments on the levels of stamp duties that they impose upon the transfer of mortgages. The secondary mortgage market in Australia will not be encouraged to any real extent by allowing the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to become active in the secondary mortgage market, but the Government should be examining the level of stamp duty which is a real impediment to the transfer of mortgages within States.

The role of corporations such as the policy of the HLIC was discussed by the previous Government. It was the policy of the previous Government to sell the HLIC, but it failed to do so. That was a decision which I did not agree with because it seemed to me to be a token gesture of the policy of privatisation. It was one small, profitable organisation that could be used to demonstrate an intent that usually was not strongly felt by the government of the day. I felt that the work being done by the HLIC was so significant I did not agree with its sale. I have had views for a long time about restructuring of government authorities and semi-governmental organisations. If the privatisation or restructuring of the HLIC were to take place in a total, comprehensible policy package I would endorse that approach.

The HLIC has a proud history of providing funds, and guaranteeing loans to people who have a low equity in the house they are purchasing. In cases of people with deposits as little as 5 per cent or even, in some instances, no deposit at all the HLIC has been prepared to underwrite and insure the loans provide by building societies and banks. In any restructuring process a criterion that the coalition parties must put in place is a requirement that the low equity purchasers are covered and that the drive to provide an opportunity for home ownership is not altered. I regard that as a process which can take place by legislation and which should apply to the HLIC. There would also be a need, I believe, for a fidelity fund to be established for home loan insurers so that there can be no collapse and no need for government support or guarantee for these organisations.

Any decisions by governments to restructure and free up semi-governmental organisations which are conducting business in the name of the Government must be gone about in a comprehensive and sensible way. The stifling provisions of Public Service regulations in regard to employees restrict talent and ability in so many instances. Many corporations and businesses presently operated by the Commonwealth Government deeply resent the strict rules of Public Service employment. Personnel and management alike resent the implication of Public Service provisions. The need to work specific hours, the tight restriction on overtime, the staff cuts, the staff ceilings, the incapacity really to manage effectively stifle talent and ability in many corporations and organisations within government.

The absolute frustration of people with ability or drive is dreadful to see. It is a tragedy that those people lose their positions within organisations, fail to be advanced when often they should be advanced and, in other instances, leave the public sector altogether. As an Australian I resent seeing people with potential and capacity being denied the opportunity to advance their talents and careers. The ability of people cannot be recognised properly within the Public Service sector unless they go through a very tight and drawn out process of examination, promotion review and then, often, challenge. In many instances that has taken away the capacity of public sector managers effectively to manage their personnel. We see the effects of it in many instances in low morale, the failure to apply oneself to the task one is given and a very poor public image for some lower level public servants.

The propping up by the taxpayer of these organisations by constant contribution is often a detriment and a burden the taxpayer need not bear. I hasten to add that the HLIC has been a profitable organisation. It has not been propped up by the taxpayer. However, many business-type activities run by the Government of Australia are constantly supported and subsidised from the taxpayer's purse. It amounts in a year to millions of dollars spread across the whole sphere of government activity. Workers are supported in positions which they do not wish to hold. The all-embracing attraction of a superannuation scheme that locks people into positions from which they cannot move for fear of losing a benefit, or of not fully realising the results of their efforts at the end of the day, is stifling and debilitating. The way in which employees in some areas are held in positions of no importance when they should be encouraged to retrain and move into other areas is also debilitating. The purchasing policies of these organisations are also somewhat restricted by Australian Government policy.

All in all, political interference in corporations and business makes it difficult for them to be effective and to realise high standards of efficiency and operation. If they are business ventures they should be run as businesses. I believe that the welfare of all individuals must be carefully considered in any movement to change the status of or to restructure these organisations. Employees cannot be dealt with willy-nilly. Their interest must be preserved and their opportunities extended. Therefore, any change to privatise or to restructure organisations must be done with a great sense of delicacy and concern, both for employees and for their clients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is now in its twentieth year of operation. It has been an outstanding success. That is undisputed. It has a proud record of being a viable commercial operation contributing substantially to government revenue. In 1983-84 it returned a net profit of $5.4m and paid $2.9m in dividends and special payments to revenue as well as $4.9m in income tax. Consistent with this Government's well-known aim of assisting those most in need, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has been instrumental in enabling many Australians, particularly those in the low income bracket, to achieve the great Australian dream of owning their own home. The people on the other side of this House wanted to sell this asset. The master of histrionics, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), who is no longer in this chamber, wanted to flog it off. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who has just finished speaking, says that he did not want to flog it off. However, in this chamber he voted to flog it off. So how sincere is the Opposition when it comes to the provision of housing for those on low incomes?

SPEECH.PARA: The decision of this Government to reverse the Fraser Government's intention to sell the HLIC has certainly been justified. During 1982, when the Fraser Government had reached its nadir, the number of loans insured slumped from nearly 60,000 to 38,000, and slumped even further in 1983 to 36,000. However, due to the confidence instilled in the Australian community by the sound economic management of the Hawke Government, loans insured in 1984 soared to in excess of 68,000.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has won the broad support of the insurance industry and the overwhelming, wholehearted support of the Australian people. It has won the envy of the Mickey Mouse highwaymen on the other side of the other side of the House. They hate it, as they hate every success of the Labor Government-and they have much to hate. There are many outstanding successes of this Hawke Government. The initiatives in this Bill add to the Government's success in the field of housing. These initiatives will allow the development of new lending arrangements which assist low income earners to achieve home ownership. 'Low income earners' is worth while emphasising because that is what this Labor Government is all about-helping those most in need.

As the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) said in introducing this Bill, the Labor Government is achieving success in the housing field because, firstly, it has the confidence of business; secondly, it has the good sense to utilise the expertise of industry; and, thirdly, it can work with union co-operation rather than union bashing. The Opposition started 105,000 housing constructions in 1982-83. The Labor Government saw the commencement of the construction of 137,000 houses in its first year of government; 32,000 more houses. No wonder the conservatives' faces are green with envy. The Hawke Government's turn around of what was a miserable coalition performance has brought considerable economic and social benefits for the nation.

Although the HLIC is guaranteed by the Commonwealth, it is self financing. Its funds have been derived wholly from its business activities. It has contributed substantially to the development of the mortgage insurance industry in Australia. Of the four major initiatives contained in the amendments before us now, the most innovative is the entry of the HLIC into the secondary mortgage market. The gap in the secondary mortgage market was recognised in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the report of the Martin Review of the Australian Financial System.

The Campbell Committee considered the establishment of a broadly based and active secondary mortgage market as a useful development. It saw potential benefits deriving from greater integration between the housing finance sector and other sectors of the capital market; greater mobility of housing finance funds between regions of excess supply and demand, particularly across State boundaries; and greater diversity of choice for investors. The conclusion reached by the Martin Committee was that the development of an active and broadly based secondary mortgage market would assist the Commonwealth's objectives in the housing area. The Martin Committee believed that the development of a secondary mortgage market would be particularly valuable in attracting funds for housing from non-traditional sources, a method much preferred to the imposition of direct controls over non-bank financial institutions or the establishment of special funds.

Additional funds for housing are generated in the secondary mortgage market, generally by lending institutions in the housing field gathering together bundles of mortgages and selling them to other institutions. The Corporation's role is to facilitate the development of the secondary mortgage market by insuring pools of mortgages against loss, thus giving investors in the secondary mortgage market unchallengeable security.

The Minister in his second reading speech emphasised the fact that under the Government's proposal the Corporation will be insuring only the performance of the underlying mortgages. The Corporation will not be guaranteeing those who pool mortgages for sale or the market securities themselves. The establishment of a secondary mortgage market will provide a number of benefits to the community, mortgage creating institutions and the Government.

Apart from the major benefits I have already mentioned, the generation of additional housing finance will increase opportunities for home ownership. Another benefit to the community will be derived by providing a stable and flexible supply of housing finance. It will help home buyers and the construction industry to even out fluctuations of mortgage credit. Increasing the availability of housing finance will also lower the cost of borrowing, on both national and State bases.

Advantages accruing to mortgage creating institutions from the secondary mortgage market are derived from greater liquidity because such institutions are able to sell and buy mortgages according to their need for cash. Such lending institutions will be able to increase their profits by holding this cash and other low yielding assets and increasing the holdings of higher yielding assets, thus allowing savings banks and building societies to adjust their holdings of assets in such a way that their earning and liquidity preferences are matched. When financial institutions retain the responsibility of servicing the mortgages for a fee, it generates additional profit. This additional income may be sufficient to service the entire portfolio.

I am running out of time, because we have so much legislation to get through and I do not want to deprive others of the opportunity to speak. There is a clear market need for this service. The HLIC has already been approached by major institutions likely to be involved in the secondary mortgage market. The HLIC should be involved in the secondary mortgage market because it is a Federal Government body with an established reputation and could encourage the participation of substantial institutions and influence the development of the market in a sensible way, as opposed to some of the ratbag methods advocated by the rapacious fingerlings on the other side of this House.

I know that Opposition members will appreciate the positive benefits of this Bill-or they would if they were fair dinkum. I doubt very much whether they are fair dinkum; otherwise we would have seen from them some appreciation of the first home owners scheme. That scheme brought home ownership within the reach of many thousands of low to moderate income earners, people who would not otherwise have had the chance to buy their own home. Truly it can be said that while the coalition is intent on destruction the Labor Party gets on with the job of construction.

I have a great deal of other notes which I would like to use, but I am afraid that my time has almost expired. I conclude by saying that this legislation gives many thousands of Australians the chance of home ownership. I support the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) mentioned in his second reading speech, the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill proposes a range of measures relating to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, which is a government owned commercial enterprise. There is no doubt that it is important to have bodies performing the role which the HLIC performs. However, it is the view of the National Party in particular, and the Opposition in general, that this role could be much better performed by private enterprise. Sadly, the Bill does not make any attempt whatsoever to move the Corporation in the direction of having its ownership transferred to the private sector. Shamefully, there is an intention to expand the role of the Corporation as a government instrumentality.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has a number of aims, and I will outline some of them. Firstly, it will enable the HLIC to participate in the secondary mortgage market by insuring pools of mortgages against loss. Secondly, the Bill extends the Corporation's insurance services to include all loans secured by mortgage, including loans where the purpose of the loan is not directly related to mortgage security. Thirdly, the Bill provides for the HLIC to be empowered to act as agent for other insurance companies underwriting mortgage repayment insurance for borrowers in the event of death, sickness, unemployment, et cetera, particularly during the first years of mortgage repayment.

Lastly, and most iniquitously, the Bill provides for a new 'special interest' provision which empowers the Minister to direct-yes, direct-the Corporation to provide insurance for loss falling within a particular or specific class of loan, deemed to be of special interest in the terms of the Government's housing policies-I repeat, special interest in the terms of the Government's housing policies. One does not have to have a fertile imagination to imagine how this Government, with its sad and sorry record, will react to this newly- granted power. In effect, the HLIC has become the Government's political puppet on a string with the Minister, a left winger, as the puppeteer. The National Party utterly opposes this Bill including in particular the 'special interest' provision.

In my maiden speech in this House I spoke approvingly of Mrs Thatcher's sterling example in the area of privatisation of government bodies. In other words, the British Conservative Government is returning government enterprises to the people. I am pleased that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) has pledged that on our return to government the HLIC will be sold to private enterprise in accordance with the philosophies of our parties. The National Party is appalled at the way in which bureaucracy in government has grown under the present Labor Administration. The Hawke Labor Government is the biggest taxing government in Australia's history. It stands for bigger and bigger government and more and more taxation, whereas the National Party stands unashamedly for small government, low taxes and the freedom of society from excessive government interference.

I believe it would be advantageous to spend a few minutes looking at the concept of privatisation because this principle is a key element in the reduction of the size of government. Privatisation is most commonly defined as the transfer of government-owned industries to the private sector, implying that the predominant share of ownership in assets on transfer lies with private shareholders. There is no reason for HLIC to remain part of government and I believe the reason the Government has not acted is its philosophy and platform which states that the Australian Labor Party believes in the socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange. This Government is flying in the face of public opinion--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—I thank the honourable member for his support. Public opinion wants less involvement by government in the lives of ordinary citizens. Wherever it is possible to exclude the public sector this should be done without delay. The fact that the HLIC has been operating at a profit-in 1983-84 it returned a net profit of $5.4m and paid a total of $2.5m to government revenue-means that there should be no shortage of proposed purchasers. While privatisation is desirable in itself and respectable arguments supporting such a view abound, it is important to look at the economic implications. Nationalised industries and government instrumentalities sometimes provide various services which at first appearances are uneconomic at present prices and costs. Not all are necessarily uneconomic and many could be made viable by a private company or companies operating with increased efficiency. I believe that if the HLIC were exposed properly and fairly to the market place efficiency would improve, the cost of mortgage insurance would become more competitive and there would be a better economic performance by the HLIC.

SPEECH.PARA: Privatisation is not merely a matter of selling shares. The underlying intent is to improve industry performance by increasing the role of market forces. To achieve this other devices for promoting competition must also be looked at and adopted. The following general considerations should guide policy: Privatisation schemes should be designed to maximise net consumer benefits, measured primarily by lower prices and improved quality of service, and to promote competition as the most effective means of maximising consumer benefits and curbing monopoly power.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established in 1965 under the Housing Loans Insurance Act to insure lenders against losses incurred by secured mortgage, principally housing loans, but its area of operation was extended by Labor in September 1983 to include loans for the purchase, construction or refinancing of non-residential buildings also. While the Corporation may act as a business undertaking in competition with other insurers, great concern has been expressed over the years because of competitive advantages resulting from its government ownership. We on this side of the House believe that it is certainly wrong in this day and age for a government instrumentality to operate in unfair competition with the private sector. It is particularly improper that ordinary commercial operations should be disadvantaged. The fact that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is guaranteed by the Commonwealth provides it with a head start. When the Corporation was established its architects designed it to meet what was then perceived as a gap in the market for mortgage insurance cover for lenders wishing to lend outside the normal lending limits. To some people justification for its formation may be based on the fact that in 1965 mortgage insurance was not readily available in Australia. Cloaked in its armour of government connections, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has grown and grown to be the largest mortgage insurer in this country and in 1979-80 it had successfully cornered over 60 per cent of all new loans insured.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—I am absolutely opposed to government involvement in this area. However, while there are those on this side of the House who would justify the establishment of the HLIC in 1965, they would no doubt agree that now in 1985, 20 years later, there can be no sound reason for HLIC to remain a public body. There are in Australia at present three major private mortgage insurance bodies, these being the Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation of Australia, the Australian Mortgage Insurance Corporation and AFG Finance. The Fraser Government's intention, announced almost six years ago, to dispose of the HLIC encouraged much healthy public debate on the Corporation's place in society. The Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System looked into aspects of HLIC and its sale, particularly in connection with the availability of mortgage insurance, the degree of competition, the cost of mortgage insurance, the development of a secondary mortgage market and the stability of the private mortgage insurers. It has been suggested that the sale of HLIC could reduce the availability of high loan to valuation housing finance and that premiums could increase, as I will mention later. Because of the present competitive nature of this insurance field, there is no reason to believe that this would occur. I believe also that the major free enterprise insurers are prepared to guarantee that high ratio loans on reasonable terms and conditions will continue to be available. There would be no reason for insurers to leave this area of the market and consequently forfeit the profits which would be made in the long run.

SPEECH.PARA: It is utter nonsense to suggest that the sale of HLIC would reduce the level of competition. A healthy privatised HLIC could lead to some changes. However, these would occur even if it remained in Government hands as it has been recommended that whether or not HLIC is sold, it should be put on an equal competitive footing with its private counterparts. It could well be that the disposal of HLIC will result in increased, rather than decreased, competition in the long term. I would not support the acquisition of the HLIC by a major existing mortgage insurer as I believe it would not be desirable to reduce the number of companies working in this area. With HLIC no longer tied to the apron strings of the Hawke socialist Government there could be the entry of additional operators into the mortgage insurance arena because the unfair advantage of government association enjoyed by HLIC would no longer exist. In addition, unsuccessful intending purchasers of the Corporation even if they are not successful in acquisition, may enter into the field.

Another spurious reason raised quite often to oppose the privatisation of HLIC is the suggestion that without HLIC in the field to minimise rates, insurance premiums could skyrocket. In my opinion, there are no grounds for this concern. HLIC has calculated its flat rate for each loan to valuation category, regardless of location, as the most efficient and economical way to deal with premiums. Separate regional rates would add considerably to the Corporation's administrative costs. I might mention that MGICA and AMIC also have their rates set either nationally or on a State basis and a free enterprise HLIC is therefore unlikely to increase charges for mortgage insurance in higher risk areas. HLIC's belief that its present common charging system contains administrative costs means that a relatively low premium would still secure a high ratio loan. Regional and country areas are already serviced by the private insurers and there is no doubt that this service would continue.

Some people have been concerned about the stability of private mortgage insurers in the absence of government control of HLIC. It is a nonsense for the industry to rely on the HLIC by virtue of its market share and government guarantee to provide standards of prudence to be followed by the rest of the industry. It is not contested that standards of prudence by mortgage insurers are required but it is utterly ridiculous to use the HLIC as a pacesetter for this purpose. If the community deems certain standards to be necessary, appropriate requirements should be set under the Insurance Act. Mortgage insurers should be treated in the same way as any other insurers are treated.

The Campbell Committee has recommended the sale of the HLIC. The National Party, the Liberal Party and the honourable member for Denison have emphasised that when we return to government in just 2 1/2 years time this recommendation of the Campbell Committee will be carried forward and put into effect forthwith. The important thing is to reduce the size of the public sector. It is essential to diminish the oppression of the public sector. It is absolutely vital to encourage the private sector and to move to it those responsibilities which are quite appropriately within its role.

TALK.START.PARA: — What about TAA?

—TAA should be sold off as well. The Government has reduced the time available to participate in this debate. In the few seconds remaining to me, I want to emphasise that we oppose the Bill. We must remove the ownership of the HLIC from the Government and transfer it to private enterprise-to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposals to privatise the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation are out of step with the views of industry. The Opposition's isolation from the industry is evident in its attitude in this debate on the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill, as it is in so many others. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) and the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) seem to be blindly opposed to public enterprises, no matter how efficient they may be. The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), to his credit, is not so biased against the Corporation. Surely an efficient government enterprise is one worth retaining. Perhaps honourable members opposite are afraid that private enterprise will not stand up to scrutiny against such competition. If they are so lacking in faith in the ability of the private sector to survive and prosper in the face of competition from any quarter, including the public sector, I am not surprised that they are in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this debate the honourable member for Denison referred to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation as a socialist wart on the face of private enterprise. As a successful government business enterprise the Corporation could be better described as a beauty spot on the Australian commercial landscape. It belies the continual contention of the Opposition that no government undertaking can run at a profit. No wonder Opposition members want it dismantled. No wonder they want to sell it off, and no wonder they do not want to permit it to compete on equal terms with private industry. Successful government business enterprises are an acute embarrassment to some members on the other side of this House.

I reiterate the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) in chastising the Opposition for its failure to make its position clear on the establishment of a secondary mortgage market in Australia. This Government is prepared to support that market by providing the HLIC with the statutory powers to participate in it. This Bill provides for the HLIC to facilitate the development of the secondary mortgage market by insuring pools of mortgages against loss. In contrast to the primary mortgage market, which relates to the origination of mortgages by lenders such as banks, secondary mortgage markets are based on transactions in existing mortgages or mortgage-related investments between lenders and investors. With this new insurance, investors in secondary mortgage securities that are backed by an insured pool of mortgages can be sure that their security position is unchallengeable. There is a clear market need for this service. As was mentioned earlier by the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the HLIC has already been approached by major institutions likely to be involved in the secondary mortgage market.

A broadly based secondary mortgage market has significant potential to attract new funds into housing. As such it is consistent with the Government's policy objective of ensuring an adequate supply of housing funds for Australian families. Industry organisations such as the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies and the Mortgage Bankers Association of Australia have strongly supported the Government's initiatives in this area of endeavour.

The HLIC should be involved in this market because it is a Federal government body with an established reputation and it could encourage the participation of substantial institutions and influence the development of the market in a sensible way; furthermore, involvement in the SMM is a natural extension of the HLIC's existing business operations. The Government considers it important to assist this emerging market develop in a rational, orderly way, with the highest possible standards. It expects that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will make an important contribution to this and complement and support other initiatives already taken by State governments.

Clause 9 (c) of the Bill provides for the Minister to direct the HLIC to offer insurance in respect of special classes of loans involving projects that would contribute to the Government's overall housing objectives but might otherwise fall outside normal commercial criteria. Unlike the honourable member for Fisher, I see nothing iniquitous in this proposal. It is simply something that will help the Government to save revenue on certain types of housing proposals. Such a national interest provision already exists in the Export Finance Insurance Corporation Act. It would ensure that the HLIC is involved in supporting the Government's housing objectives. In addition, there are some areas where the HLIC mortgage insurance might remove the need for direct government outlays, as was previously mentioned, in the case of commercial housing projects with private sector financing, housing in remote areas, mobile housing, housing co-operatives, et cetera.

The Bill also empowers the HLIC to enter into agency agreements covering mortgage repayment insurance for borrowers. The Corporation would not assume any additional risk as it would act as agent for one or more of the general underwriters providing cover for the borrower's mortgage repayments in the event of death, unemployment or sickness. Provision for the HLIC to enter into agency agreements in this area will enable it to provide a similar service to its clients and open up competition in this field of insurance with potential benefit to borrowers. I remind the House that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is a successful government business enterprise established under the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965, which was introduced by the Menzies 'socialist' Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —By what Government?

—Was it not the Menzies Government? It was introduced in 1965. It was certainly not a Labor government then. It ensures members against loss on housing and building loans. As a self-financing concern it pays taxes and dividends to the Government.
—Free enterprise socialists.

—The free enterprise people opposite seem not to want it to pay taxes and dividends. I do not know how we are supposed to get the deficit down if we squash it and turn it over to private enterprise that does not pay taxes. The changes covered in this Bill should--

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the House that we are trying to listen to the speech by the honourable member for Cowan.
—It is a good speech, too, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I thank the honourable member. The changes covered in this Bill should increase the Corporation's business volume and its overall profitability. This in turn will mean increased government revenue by way of taxation and dividend payments. The major initiatives in the Bill are: Insurance related to secondary mort- gage market securities, as mentioned; insurance of all mortgage secured loans; agency agreements on mortgage repayment insurance; and insurance of special interest loans. Introduction of the new special payment to place the Corporation on an equal commercial footing with other mortgage insurers will also add to government revenue. While some minor losses may result from insurance contracts written in connection with a direction by the Minister under proposed new section 17 (3c), the Corporation will be required to keep a separate note of that business and any losses will be taken into account when determining dividend payments.

SPEECH.PARA: The availability of HLIC mortgage insurance is very important to marginal home buyers who require high ratio loans and repayment arrangements which reflect their capacity to pay. Presently, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation provides mortgage insurance to lenders throughout Australia. Building societies account for about 80 per cent of its business. The greatest part of this business is providing standard full cover insurance on first mortgage home ownership loans. Such cover protects the lender for the term of the loan against any financial loss arising from it. This form of insurance enables lending institutions to provide low deposit and other loans to low income borrowers without fear of loss.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation competes directly with three private insurers-the Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation of Australia Ltd, the Australian Mortgage Insurance Corporation Ltd and AFG Insurance Ltd. It currently holds some 60 per cent of the market for insurance of home ownership loans and around 20 per cent of the market for commercial loans. Naturally, the continued commercial success of the Corporation depends on its capacity to provide services to it clients. It therefore needs to be able to respond to developments affecting the operations of lending institutions. Through the proposals in this Bill, the HLIC will be able to continue to compete on an equal basis with its private sector competitors and to contribute to the support of the Government's housing policies-policies which have been very successful.

The proposals contained in this Bill can be implemented without cost to the Budget and will result in a net gain to revenue. They will also ensure that the Corporation is able to contribute to the ready provision of home finance to borrowers.
