It is hoped that the Corporation will work co-operatively with financial institutions to develop new lending arrangements which will assist low income earners to achieve home ownership. Flexible and innovative policies by government, business and community groups are necessary for the challenges ahead in order to meet the housing needs of all Australians. This Government is committed to that cause.

In 1979 the coalition Government planned to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to the private sector. It had the same plan in 1981. In 1984 it was still the Opposition's policy to sell off bodies such as the HLIC and, lo and behold, the honourable member for Denison today confirmed that its intention has not changed. This Corporation is worthy of support, as is the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support the shadow Minister for Housing and Construction, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), and my colleagues on this side of the House. I should probably briefly explain the concept of insurance for members on the other side of the House. The insurance industry, of course, has been around for a long time.
—How long?

—It has been around for at least 5,000 or 6,000 years. It has developed during that time and adjusted to market demands without any government intervention. Insurance developed from marine insurance to property insurance, to fire insurance, to re-insurance and to other concepts that are common today, without any necessity for government legislation. Why then do we need the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill? Why in fact did we need the original legislation? Of course, there is an acceptable economic argument for government intervention, namely, that governments may intervene when markets fail; in other words, when competitive markets do not provide a solution to an economic problem.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested to search through the second reading speech by the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and through the explanatory memorandum associated with this Bill to see whether the Minister could provide any such economic justification. Of course, there was no such justification. In fact, exactly the opposite is the case. If one looks at the explanatory memorandum and particularly at clause 16, one finds the Minister introducing a new special annual payment by the Corporation to place it on an equal footing with other mortgage insurers. In other words, there is already a competitive market. There is already a situation in which the market can provide the solution. Thus there is no economic justification for this Bill. Consequently, I decided to go back and look at the original legislation and the original debate. Lo and behold, there was, of course, some indication of market failure at that stage. The interesting things that were discussed at that stage were the limitations on the obtaining of finance-about #3,500 from a bank and #3,700 from a building society. Of course, there was also the problem of insufficient funds for housing. But it is interesting to note that these were problems caused by government interferences in the market-place.

In fact, it is rather ironic that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claims is a tremendous Treasurer, has done much to deregulate the financial markets, and by that deregulation, has made this Bill completely irrelevant. On the one hand, we have the Government saying that it is trying to deregulate the financial markets and, on the other hand, it introduces a Bill which is totally irrelevant because the Treasurer has been successful in that deregulation. Why then, if there is no economic justification, is the Bill being introduced? This has already been referred to by the honourable member for Denison and the previous speaker from this side of the House, the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper). Clause 13 of the Bill deals with special interest provisions. This Bill is designed to do nothing more than to redistribute wealth in this country. It is designed to do nothing more than to subsidise particular kinds of living standards, for example, communal living, which was mentioned by the Minister in his second reading speech. I do not necessarily disagree with the right of people to live the way they want to live. What I object to is the redistribution of wealth through stealth. That is what this Bill is all about. There is no economic justification for these proposals. They are simply an attempt to justify the redistribution of wealth in this society.

Let me turn to some of the financial implications of this Bill because, after all, government members, including the Minister in his explanatory memorandum, have made a big deal of them. The Minister, in his memorandum, suggests that one of the advantages of this Bill is an increased government revenue by way of taxation and dividends. That is the assertion but there is absolutely no economic justification provided for that. In fact, if this instrument were privatised, the taxation revenue would be at least the same. In addition, dividend payments in the hands of shareholders would provide further taxation revenue. That would provide further taxation revenue. That would also provide money in the hands of ordinary Australians who could invest it in areas which are productive for our country, rather than its being wasted by this damned socialist government.

I return to clause 13. The Minister suggests that there will be a special payment to place this Corporation on an equal commercial footing. Government members have asserted that this is a profitable organisation operating on a commercial basis. How do they know that? What is the risk level involved with this Corporation? What is an appropriate return? How is that determined? How do we know that the assets tied up in this organisation are being used efficiently? Of course, the assertion is that this organisation is making a profit. That is completely irrelevant. The relevant question is not whether it is making a profit; it is whether the organisation is making an appropriate return on its investment. If honourable members on the other side of the House knew anything about economics, accounting or finance they would know exactly that the real test is whether the rate of return on investment is sufficiently high. That is how one compares organisations and makes a decision on whether an organisation is efficient. This Government cannot do it. It does even know what the concepts are.

In case honourable members think I am being a little too hard on the Government, it is relevant to note that some of these issues were raised at the time of the introduction of the original legislation by none other than the one time Leader of the Australian Labor Party, the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Gough Whitlam. He understood-I think perhaps better than some of the new socialists on the other side of the House-exactly what some of the problems could be. Unfortunately, he did not go far enough because he did not understand the long term implications of what he was doing.

In summary, this Bill and the memorandum provided by the Minister give absolutely no justification for the extension into the secondary mortgage market. In my opinion there was no justification for the original Bill other than interference by the Government in the market-place. This Bill is designed for one thing only-that is, to redistribute wealth without coming back to the Parliament. This is an attempt to redistribute wealth-

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—By stealth. In this manner, there is absolutely no doubt that the Government intends to alter the manner of living for all Australians and, because there are particular segments of society which it wants to support, to undermine the moral standards of this society.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, because of time constraints, I do not think I can educate honourable members on the other side of the House on some of the intricacies of accounting and finance. But I can assure you and my colleagues that there is no justification for this Bill. The only way to deal with this Bill is as the honourable member for Denison has suggested, that is, to oppose it and throw it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-This time honourable members opposite have really exhibited how fearfully incompetent they are. During the debate on the Housing Loans Insurance Amendments Bill, they have an excellent opportunity to state their policies on the insurance industry and their attitude towards measures in this Bill and they have failed in a most fearfully inadequate manner. We heard the spokesperson for the Opposition on housing and construction, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman), make his usual inept attack on public enterprise. The Opposition's policy goes back a long way. It was first exemplified by the refusal of the National Party of Australia, which used to be called the Country Party. Honourable members opposite have this wonderful economic theory about public enterprise: Capitalise the profits and socialise the losses.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition made an attack on the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation because it has been a profitable and a worthy organisation. The honourable member for Denison said that back in the 1960s when the Menzies Government established the HLIC there was a market but that market was not being satisfied. The private sector would not accept the challenge and so Menzies had to establish the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in 1965, or whenever it was. The private sector then was too timid to satisfy the need. Now that the HLIC has demonstrated its capacity to operate at a profit and now that it has satisfied the market and other private corporations have entered the market honourable members opposite want to sell it off. It was essential back in 1965. Now that it is no longer essential but still a market leader covering 60 per cent of the market and 90 per cent of the permanent building society market, honourable members opposite want to sell it off. The whole problem is that the concept of a successful public corporation clashes irrevocably with their conservative ideology. So they get hooked on this enormous dilemma. They praise the efficiency of the HLIC and they say how good it is, how it established the market and how it is still the market leader. They then turn around and call it a socialist wart and say that we have to sell it off. In their frenzy of hate against the public sector they cannot even stand to see a successful public enterprise. Once again, we have been treated to this farrago of misrepresentation and nonsense which exemplifies their attitude to these housing Bills on every occasion. They will not face up to the real issues or address the clauses in the Bill. I do not think anyone really addressed the clauses in the Bill or stated what their purpose was.

I will not go over the Bill but I will remind honourable members of its purpose. It has four major initiatives. Firstly, it will insure the emerging secondary mortgage market security packages that are coming forward in Victoria and New South Wales. The Bill will allow the HLIC to insure the mortgage-backed securities and thus encourage the States in their efforts to develop a secondary mortgage market and encourage more funds into housing finance. Secondly, this Bill will allow the insurance of all loans by the HLIC, if they are backed by a mortgage. I say to my friends opposite that that is just what its competitors do now. All we will do is let the good old HLIC give them a bit of good old honest private sector competition in this area where they have enjoyed a monopoly in the past.

Thirdly, we will let the HLIC enter into agency agreements with companies that are already established in the market to insure the borrower rather than just the lender. In that way, we will be able to give some assistance to middle and low income earners who are paying off their mortgages and who may fall into difficulties. The fourth and final major initiative will allow the HLIC to back the Government's housing policies by allowing the insurance of special interest loans. As I understand that an amendment is to be moved in the Committee stage I will leave my comments on this matter until I have heard what the honourable member for Denison has to say, because I know very well that the Government has all the answers.

Let me conclude my summing up because there has been really nothing from the Opposition to answer. I will just run over a few points so that there will be no doubt. Since 1965, the HLIC has been enormously successful. It has insured over 700,000 loans since that date. The decision by this Government to retain the HLIC in 1983 was supported by the Australian Association of Permanent Building Societies, the Housing Industry Association, the Real Estate Institute of Australia and the Master Builders Federation of Australia. It does not have a monopoly, as was suggested by the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman); there are three major competitors. As all these organisations-the Housing Industry Association, the Master Builders Federation of Australia, the Real Estate Institute of Australia, the Association of Permanent Building Societies, and the Bankers Association-support this Bill, how can the Opposition portray it as an attempt to nationalise the industry? All the major industry organisations and trade unions support this Bill. All the State governments support this Bill. The industry supports it, the State governments support it, the trade unions support it, but the Opposition does not support it. Who is wrong? If all these people, including the industry organisations, are supporting it, how is it an attempt to nationalise the industry?

I will just repeat what my colleagues have stressed concerning this organisation's profitability. Payments to the Government-that is, the payment of tax, the payment of dividends and a special payment to make certain that private sector companies are not disadvantaged-totalled $7.8m last year and are likely to total $8.75m this year. So it has been profitable. It is not a drain on the taxpayer and it ought not to be sold. There should be no more talk by members of the Opposition about selling off the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.

My last point is that members of the Opposition are doing damage to the morale of a very successful public sector organisation. I do not want to condemn this organisation; I want to praise it. I assure honourable members opposite, the people of Australia and the industry that we will not allow the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to be sold off. I assure all of the people who work there, all of the staff and Mr Fitzpatrick, the Chairman, who is in the chamber tonight, that the Hawke Labor Government will not sell the HLIC. We have said that and we will stand by it. I commend the management and the staff of the Corporation for a job well done over the years since 1965. I assure them of our continued support. We know that they have been serving the industry in the past and after the passage of this Bill, when it becomes law, they will be in an even better position to serve the public of Australia and the building industry.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 8-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 9 (Corporation to carry on certain insurance business).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the critical clause of the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill. The Opposition will take this matter to a division because this is the clause under which the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) will be empowered to give a direction to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation in what are described as 'special interest matters'. As the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) pointed out, it is a most sinister clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I am about to make my remarks on clause 9, I would like to place on record the Opposition's gratitude-if I can be heard over the noise of the socialist rabble-to the honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and the honourable member for Forde for their contributions to the second reading debate. I also offer my congratulations to the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) for his interest, although his excellent speech, unfortunately, was not delivered due to the shortage of time.

Clause 9 is the clause under which the Minister will have power to direct the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to carry on business in areas of special interest according to the Government's housing policies; it is the clause under which this Socialist Left Minister will use the Bill in the most damaging and debilitating way. The Minister, in his second reading speech-I want all honourable members to listen to this-said:
It is possible that some minor losses may be incurred by the Corporation in connection with business written under the new special interest provision.

Honourable members on the other side think this is funny. I will now read what the Bill says and then we will see whether they think it is funny. Clause 9 amends section 17 of the principal Act, which sets out the powers of the Corporation. Those opposite should listen to the following provision that the Hawke socialist Government, by weight of numbers, will put into the law of this land:

(3C) The Minister may, from time to time, by instrument in writing, direct the Corporation to enter, under sub-section (2), into contracts in respect of loans included in a class of loans specified in the direction, being loans-
(a) made for purposes that accord with the policies of the Government of the Commonwealth in relation to housing; and
(b) in respect of which the Corporation would not-
I repeat, 'would not'-
so enter into contracts in the ordinary course of business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I should like the names of the honourable members who laughed to be recorded, because they are laughing at a provision which says that a Minister for the first time in the history of Australia, will be given power to direct a corporation to enter into contracts into which it would not enter in the ordinary course of business. If that is not the most socialist provision that has ever been brought into this Parliament, I know not what it is. To give such a power to this Minister and this Government is to enable the Minister to drive a truck through every principle of commercial practice which the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation has upheld since 1965.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat that this clause gives the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) the power to direct the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to enter into contracts which the Corporation would not enter into in the ordinary course of business. I challenge the Minister in his reply to point to any other Commonwealth legislation which gives such a power. The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is one vehicle which the Whitlam Government saw as a means of nationalising the insurance industry of Australia. If we legislate to give the Minister power to direct the Corporation-and the corollary is that the Corporation must comply-to enter into business into which it would not normally enter, who in this chamber is to say that this socialist Government will not seek to utilise the same powers in relation to private enterprise insurers? I give honourable members, and particularly the Minister, this warning: If this Government has this power through the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, it will be the first step towards the ultimate power of giving directions to private insurers which will lead to their nationalisation.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members opposite made a muck of it when they endeavoured to nationalise the banks, and the Whitlam Government had in mind using the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, back in 1973, to nationalise the insurance industry. This legislation provides for a four-fold expansion under which the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will be expanded in four separate and very significant directions. It is an opportunity to get a foot in the door leading towards the eventual nationalisation of the insurance industry.

We Opposition members have logic on our side. We are prepared to debate with the Minister and the Government, on a philosophical basis, the impropriety of this legislation and the track down which they are seeking to take the people of Australia. We on this side of the chamber are committed to smaller government and to lower taxation. We therefore opposed most strenuously the second reading of the Bill and we now oppose clause 9. To avoid any need for me to reply to the Minister, I challenge him in his reply to point to any other Commonwealth legislation in which a Minister is given the power to direct a statutory corporation to do things which it would not usually do in normal commercial practice. Tonight is for the Minister a watershed in socialist legislation. If he cannot provide any other case, honourable members will be left to draw the conclusion that this is his bid for power and to nationalise the insurance industry of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be insisting upon maintaining the integrity of clause 9 because it allows me, as the Federal Minister, to direct the Corporation to provide insurance on loans deemed to be of special interest in terms of this Government's housing policies. SPEECH.PARA: I take up the challenge issued by the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman). Where, in relation to an application referred to the Minister . . . the Minister is of the opinion that it is in the national interest that the Corporation should enter into a contract of indemnity in respect of the matter . . . the subject of the application, the Minister may, by writing under his hand, approve the entering into by the Corporation of such a contract.
There is the precedent-the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Withdraw.
—Exactly.
—Oh, come on. I will not withdraw. You are prolonging the debate for half an hour. You are an absolute idiot.

—Well, there it is. I really think that the Opposition ought to think about what we can do with this power, because this is the sort of thing we want to do. There are a number of such projects proceeding in Melbourne and Brisbane in co-operation with the private sector; that is, with major construction developers such as Jennings Industries Ltd. That is the sort of thing that in future this special interest clause would cover and it is a most laudable activity. SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by once again condemning the Opposition and its spokesmen today for the fearful misrepresentation that they have once again put forward in debate on this Bill. They have suggested it might be the start of nationalisation of the insurance industry and all sorts of other ratbag suggestions. I repeat that all of the major industry organisations and the State governments have supported this legislation. The Real Estate Institute of Australia, hardly a socialist organisation, and the Federation of Permanent Building Societies of Australia have not only supported it but lauded it. They have said: 'We want it, get it through the Senate and get it promulgated'. The Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Federation have all said: 'Get this operational. It is the best thing you have ever done for the HLIC and the industry. It will help to get the secondary mortgage market off the ground'. That is what we want to see because it will get more funds into housing funds, that we would not otherwise get without the market. If the States are going to develop the secondary mortgage market they have to have an organisation which will ensure the mortgage-backed securities that will be stamped by the State corporations. But the Opposition does not understand that. It says that it is the start of the nationalisation of the industry. That is nonsense; it is not. This measure is supported by the industry and by the States. The only people who oppose it are the fools opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a very sad day for the Australian Parliament when a Minister misleads the Committee. —It is not there. I can read it into Hansard. Unfortunately the Minister was too clever by half. —They are with us tonight.

—The Minister boasts: 'They are with us tonight'. DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 April, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shack Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill, let me declare on behalf of the Opposition our sincere and earnest belief in the importance of occupational health and safety. The Opposition deplores the loss of life, limb and livelihood that occurs in work places across the nation because of industrial accidents and disease. Much attention is given to the economic cost of physical misfortune in the work place. This is quite properly so. A figure of $6 billion is cited regularly as the estimated annual cost to Australia of industrial accidents.

SPEECH.PARA: The spiralling burden of the workers compensation component of on-costs borne by employers is a widely recognised consequence of industrial accidents and illness. It is clearly acknowledged also that increases in the supplements component of wages growth over the last decade has been largely the result of a dramatic increase in the value of workers compensation claims. Workers compensation claims and premiums have skyrocketed. This affects all employers, from the individual entrepreneur and small business person right up to the largest corporate unit, and is yet another cost detracting from Australia's economic international competitiveness.

All honourable members in this House are aware of the negative employment consequences of this state of affairs. The $6 billion figure which is cited so often is an inadequate indicator of the seriousness of the problem. The really terrible cost, the human cost, of occupationally derived injury and illness cannot be encapsulated in a neat figure, phrase or formula. There is no financial award adequate to compensate a family for the loss of a loved one. There is no monetary remuneration sufficient to make up for the diminishment of an individual's ability to live life to the full because of the consequences of industrial misadventure or disease. The coalition feels the utmost compassion for the victims of such misfortune.

Occupational health and safety is a matter that has exercised the minds of people wherever and whenever they have toiled. At the crudest level it is basic common sense and mortality that leads one to work in a manner that is not dangerous to oneself or to others. This has been true from the simplest original acts of work. In the building of shelter and the hunting of food it was logical, practical and moral not to injure yourself or your neighbour who was a partner in the endeavour. Here lie the very origins of the social obligations due to one's fellows when coalescing in a community with other human beings. Neither is occupational health and safety a modern preoccupation. There have been epochs of particularly terrible labour exploitation as manifest in, for example, slavery and other forms of forced labour. Unfortunately, in some countries today the unjust exploitation of labour still exists. The forced labour camps of the Soviet Union spring readily to mind.

Generally, those who have organised labour into productive units have seen the logic and practicality, if not always the morality, of ensuring safe work practices. Nor is concern about occupational health and safety a new concern which has just cropped up at this advanced stage of the free enterprise system's development. Since the early excesses of the Industrial Revolution, where even children were drawn into dark mills and mines, there has been a steady and continuous progress which has lead to safer, cleaner and more pleasant working environments. This is laudable. One can say with confidence that workers in Australia are not chewed up and spat out, drained and damaged in the process of production. Employees in Australia enjoy working conditions on a par with, if not superior to, those of any other country in the world.

Those on the left of the political spectrum sometimes try to argue to the contrary and state that employers are, by definition, exploitative and have no interest in the health and welfare of their employees, whom they regard as inanimate, expendable and easily replaced factors of production. Even if this were so-and the coalition strongly disagrees with these assertions-it ignores the substantial body of common and statute law which has built up over many decades in a concerted effort by those concerned to ensure that our moral and social obligations to each other in the workplace are fulfilled. Such a body of law cannot accumulate unless there is broad community agreement, amongst employers as well as others, that an obligation exists for them to ensure the safety and well-being of those in their employ.

One important judgment in the area states that employers must take reasonable care for the safety of their employees by providing proper and adequate means of carrying out their work without unnecessary risk, by warning them of unusual or unexpected risks, or by instructing them in the performance of their work where instruction might reasonably be thought to be required to secure them from the danger of injury. It states that the standard of care for an employee's safety is not a low one. Under common law employers must discharge this responsibility through the provision of competent staff, adequate materials and a proper system of effective supervision. They are obliged to provide employees with a safe place in which to work. No employee, except perhaps in the armed forces, is obliged to obey an employer's directive if it endangers his or her safety.

Employers take these responsibilities seriously. A number of industries and individual companies have long been active in promoting occupational health and safety for both equity and efficiency reasons. Various companies and organisations provide training services to equip those who oversee work practices from a safety point of view with sound knowledge and solid information. Common to many private enterprises are employees responsible for accident control, fire control, industrial health and hygiene, the inspection of equipment, the investigation of accidents and injuries, the heightening of safety consciousness amongst the work force and so on.

In addition, State governments have intervened in the area to provide the statutory protection of employees at the work place. There are over 160 separate statutes regulating occupational health and safety in Australia. This proliferation of statutes is not desirable. Simple, coherent and effective legislative guidance provided within a single statutory framework in each State is clearly preferable. If the States can liaise with one another and come up with a single national health and safety code, so much the better. One must add the proviso that they lay down sensible minimum standards and avoid overregulation and unnecessary interference with reasonable management prerogatives.

Several State governments are presently reviewing their existing occupational health and safety legislation. South Australia, Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales have all taken steps towards the creation of a single authority within their States solely responsible for occupational health and safety matters. I intend to make some more comments about the State legislation shortly. For the moment, it can be seen that this Bill arises out of a similar impetus for review and revision on the part of Commonwealth. Further, it arises from the Government's belief that, while occupational health and safety is the legislative responsibility of the States, it is, nevertheless, a national issue which must be addressed by Australia's national government. The coalition agrees with the Government that occupational health and safety is a national issue which the Commonwealth must address.

The coalition also agrees with the Government's Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission on the 'desirability of developing appropriate consultative machinery at the Federal level, and the need for further examination of Commonwealth-State responsibilities and mechanisms for co-ordination in the implementation of occupational health and safety legislative requirements'. The coalition does not agree, however, that the establishment of a statutory commission is the appropriate instrument for the Commonwealth's achievement of those goals. The coalition believes that occupational health and safety is first and foremost the business of those who are directly involved in and affected by it-employees and employers.

A few minutes ago I conveyed a broad brush historical continuity of the consultation and negotiation that has taken place between those who organise productive activities and those who participate in them. The concrete, modern manifestations of this are the work place consultative arrangements involving employees and employers or their representatives. As the Interim Commission notes:
'many workplaces in Australia have joint health and safety committees sorting out problems and constructing preventative measures on a daily basis.

The National Labour Consultative Committee recently endorsed such arrangements. On top of this layer of activity, we have the State judiciaries, the State governments and their bureaucracies all busy constructing health and safety guidelines of both a voluntary and compulsory nature. The Commonwealth, too, has a judiciary, a government and a bureaucracy doing likewise for the benefit of employers and employees in the Territories. We have an enormous amount of activity consuming an enormous amount of resources at these three levels of operation and yet we still have not conquered the major problems in the occupational health and safety field.

The Opposition does not agree with the logic that proposes the establishment of a National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. This is the logic that the creation of special structures leads somehow to the generation of overnight solutions. It assumes that one big body can do the work of smaller bodies more effectively. Regrettably, this reaction to problems has led to an endless proliferation of quasi-autonomous government organisations, or quangos. The coalition disputes that this was the appropriate structure through which to achieve national goals in occupational health and safety. Let me be clear: The issue is national. The Commonwealth has a definite role to play. That role is properly one of direct partnership with the States. The Commonwealth can contribute by co-ordinating the various approaches of the States to the problems in this area. The Commonwealth can contribute by helping to propagate positive attitudes in relation to occupational health and safety amongst both employers and employees.

What will the establishment of this Commission achieve that could not be simply achieved by direct interministerial and departmental contact between the Commonwealth and the States? Establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission shows an insensitivity on the Government's part to the decades of positive and productive progress achieved at the grass-roots level in the work place where it counts most. The Government proposes to create a Commission with powers to blunder into the work place, to order the production of documents, to summons witnesses under threat of $1,000 fines or six months gaol or both, and to compel people to give evidence under oath at its inquiries. Is this consensus at work? It is as though the Commonwealth had suddenly found occupational health and safety and intends to descend from above dispatching subpoenas left, right and centre, hoping to change the world. Will it do so? The coalition clearly doubts it. It is pointless for the Government to say that these draconian powers are merely academic and will never be used. If that is so, why are these provisions in the Bill in the first place?

Furthermore, the industrial relations consequences of a commission let loose on industry with all those sorts of powers could be horrendous. We must remember that occupational health and safety can sometimes be an extremely delicate industrial relations matter. It is inextricably bound up with the conduct of relations between employers and employees. There is much anecdotal evidence about unions using health and safety matters as a ruse in their conduct of industrial campaigns against employers. There is some very interesting research evidence also on the positive correlation between high levels of absence due to industrial injury and high levels of industrial disputation in industry. Dr Ian Low, the physician who pointed out this phenomenon, also cited evidence that poor industrial relations in an industry reduced employee motivation to resume work after injury and heightened the perceived level of pain an employee was suffering. Another researcher has posed the theory that union interest in occupational health and safety matters tends to heighten during times of wage restraint. Union officials feel that they must be seen to be doing something for the benefit of union members and in the absence of a struggle over increased wages, occupational health and safety comes under greater scrutiny by them. I do not wish to suggest that unionists are not genuine in their interest in health and safety matters, but I do wish to indicate the complex interlinkages between occupational health and safety and industrial relations in general.

The Bill proposes the creation of a three-headed structure. Under Part V of the Bill, the staff of the Commission is organised into two bodies, the National Occupational Health and Safety Office and the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety. These two bodies, the coalition believes, will have a natural tendency to expand themselves and this will inevitably lead to the establishment of two extra bureaucracies as well as that of the Commission itself. Thus the Bill effectively sets up three new Commonwealth instrumentalities-the Commission, the Office and the Institute.

The provisions of clause 38 of the Bill for the establishment of national standards and codes of practice have a particularly grave potential for overriding the jurisdiction of the States in occupational health and safety matters. It is true that they are only advisory, but what if codes recommended by the Commission were incorporated into a Commonwealth award? They would then take precedence over State legislation for all employees covered by that Federal award. This has the potential to create Commonwealth jurisdiction over all employees covered by Federal awards in whatever State they live.

The objects, functions and powers of the Commission set out in clauses 7, 8 and 9, are so general as to confer virtually unfettered power on the Commission to range far and wide on the issue. The budgetary consequences if the Commission should ever seek funds to enable it to discharge all its objects, functions and powers could be outrageously large. There are projections in the Interim Commission report that in its second year of operation, should this Bill be passed, the Commission will have an average staff of 300 and a net budget of $33.1m. The Opposition will not seek to amend the Bill. The amendments we could propose would be so extensive as to create a different Bill altogether. In any case, we have a fundamental objection which leads us to reject the Bill outright. We totally reject the notion that the creation of a statutory commission achieves anything more than the expenditure of more Commonwealth funds-funds contributed by taxpayers who are keen to see government expenditure controlled and the tax burden lessened. The Opposition continues to live in eternal hope that the Labor Party may one day grow out of its well-meaning but ever centralist paternalism and that it may critically assess its penchant for quango creation. It is a rather regressive throwback to the heady days of Whitlamism when many optimistically thought that statutory commissions could perform some strange potent magic which could be delivered by no other structures. Time and, more importantly, public opinion have moved on since then and the community wants less bureaucracy, less cost and more action.

The coalition gives the highest priority to occupational health and safety matters. As I stated in my opening remarks, the coalition deplores human suffering and economic waste. Regrettably, I feel that we-the Government and the Opposition-are in agreement about the desirability of action in this area but we are doomed to remain divided on how it should be pursued. The Government's proposed Commission begins the task of and possesses an enormous potential for the massive expansion of Commonwealth power over occupational health and safety. That we cannot support.

Statutory commissions, once established, tend to take on life and momentum of their own. Many Ministers have rued the day that they or their colleagues or predecessors set one up. It is a great pity that the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) is bent on pursuing this aspect of his ministerial program. The costs will be externalised upon all of us in the form of increased Commonwealth intrusion, increased Commonwealth expenditure and the upsetting of a very fine grass-roots system of consultation and negotiation between employers and employees on occupational health and safety matters. I reiterate the statement of my predecessor as Opposition spokesman on employment and industrial relations, the Hon. Ian Macphee, who said when the report of the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was tabled on 29 May last year:

The Opposition strongly supports the role of the Commonwealth in co-ordinating a national occupational health and safety strategy. Indeed, it pursued that objective in office. The question is, how it is most effectively done and cost-effectively done.

A statutory commission is not the answer. It is never a satisfactory substitute for the appropriate parties to get together, put their own cases and contribute their own experiences and research to each other. If this could be done directly by and between the governments of the States and the Commonwealth and their departments we could make positive progress in occupational health and safety that much quicker, and at much less expense. Communication, unfortunately, is not the Minister's strong suit. Most of his ministerial initiatives to date have centred on the commissioning of commissions and committees of inquiry-the Kirby Committee of Inquiry into Labour Market Programs, the Hancock National Superannuation Committee of Inquiry and the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The Interim Commission was the first of these groups to report. We believe the Minister has uncritically and unthinkingly accepted its recommendations-recommendations which of course perpetuate the existence of the Interim Commission itself albeit, in a more secure form. The exercise of ministerial responsibilities requires more than commissioning commissions and committees of inquiry; it requires action. In this case, it requires direct communication, direct liaison between the State and Federal Ministers and the responsible departments. Creating a new statutory commission is not the answer.

Honourable members may be aware that the Confederation of Australian Industry is involved in the present Interim Occupational Health and Safety Commission, that it supports the establishment of the permanent Commission and that if a permanent Commission is established the CAI will be represented on it. The Opposition believes that the CAI has involved itself in the Commission in the hope that it might be used to restrain State governments from the regulatory excesses to which they have tended in recent times. The Opposition judges that this will be a faint and forlorn hope.

The attempted Victorian reforms are, of course, the most notorious example of excessive and punitive occupational health and safety legislation. Had the Cain Government managed to push its occupational health and safety Bill through the Victorian Parliament prior to the last election, union-appointed safety representatives would have had the power to shut down any business without warning if a representative considered a situation to be potentially unsafe. Under the proposed legislation, Victorian employers would have faced a fine of up to $10,000 and/or five years imprisonment for failing to obey a safety representative's directive. Victorian employers now fear that if the Cain Government gains control of the upper House they will have the legislation foisted upon them without amendment.

The Cain Government has an equally distasteful Bill waiting in the wings which would give it monopoly control of workers compensation in Victoria. The legislation would completely exclude private insurers from the workers compensation area. This is a totally unjust and unwarranted infringement of the right to trade freely in goods and services. The Victorian economy, and employers and employees therein, will suffer if the Government obtains monopoly control of workers compensation. While the Cain Government argues that its takeover would lead to lower workers compensation premiums, it cannot be argued in the short run and it certainly would be shown not to be the case in the long run. Monopoly control inevitably leads to monopoly pricing. Higher workers compensation premiums would be the inevitable result.

The Victorian legislation would have terrible consequences for employees and employers alike. Other States have planned similarly damaging legislation. South Australians and West Australians have been threatened with legislation incorporating worker-appointed safety officers with wide powers in the work place. They have been threatened too with extremely heavy penalties under the proposed legislation. In the Act legislation could result in the imprisonment or levying of fines, even against the self-employed and public servants.

All of these health and safety overkills are taking place in States and territories governed by the Labor Party. This is no accident. The Labor Party, beholden to the trade union movement, is directly implementing trade union policy on occupational health and safety. Employers will be squeezed by unreasonable union and legislative demands and the Labor governments of those States will not lift a finger to reverse that trend. This Government has only one constituency to satisfy, and that constituency is the trade union movement elite, the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Employers cannot realistically expect Labor governments to be very interested in their concerns. They are a party of the trade union movement.

This brings me back to the Confederation of Australian Industry's support for the Government's proposed National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. I suggested to honourable members that the CAI was supporting the Commission in the hope that it may act as a restraining influence on the excesses of State legislatures. I am afraid that there is only faint hope of the CAI's wishes being fulfilled. Why should one Labor Government act to curb the excesses of other Labor governments? Is it not more likely that a Commonwealth statutory commission, created and nurtured by a Federal Labor government, will attempt to duplicate rather than restrain the intrusions of its State counterparts? The fact that 12 of 17 members of the Commission are needed to pass any recommendation is irrelevant in this case. The damage is done later when, by the insertion of a commission code in a Federal award, the policing of that code could pass automatically to union organisers, and union organisers alone.

The bottom line in all this is the cost. At the beginning of my speech I outlined the coalition's view of the terrible social and economic costs which result from occupational injury and illness. In my closing remarks I would like to explore the economic costs a little more closely. By doing this I am seeking to put the economics of occupational health and safety into its proper social context, and particularly in the context of the greatest of all the social problems facing Australia-unemployment. The Metal Trades Industry Association neatly summed up the problem when it said:
The spiralling cost of worker's compensation . . . is reducing industry's capacity to meet international competition, and consequently reducing employers' ability to employ more people.

There we have the problem in a nutshell. Improved standards of occupational health and safety are vital if we are to minimise the negative social and economic consequences of industrial injury and illness. As the MTIA quote indicates, the economic consequences have a profound, widely felt community impact. Workers compensation premiums have been said to be the key issue in the cost control problem facing Australian industry. Costs have zoomed alarmingly in all States. Compensation claims by private insurers rose by 148 per cent in the five years to 1982. Over the same period, the consumer price index rose by only 57 per cent. A recent MTIA study revealed that workers compensation premiums were the third-highest cost of employing labour, behind wages and leave entitlements. Clearly, these costs must be contained if our economy is to be placed on an internationally competitive footing. They certainly must be contained if our economy is ever to generate sufficient jobs to make inroads into our very high and entrenched unemployment. The unemployment statistics released today give us no hope for the immediate future.

Improved standards of occupational health and safety can contribute to the minimisation of occupational injury and illness. This will lead to less human suffering and less economic pain. Optimally, through a lowering of workers compensation premiums, improved occupational health and safety can restore our international competitiveness and produce new, real jobs for the hundreds of thousands of Australians who want them. Regrettably, the coalition does not feel that the establishment of yet another quango will positively contribute to these goals and we will oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day in this chamber when the Opposition opposes what I consider to be a most significant piece of legislation. It is sad because, in my view, the Opposition is opposing the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill although the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, which is now operating, is in fact a unique combination of tripartisan and co-operative federalism. In fact, the current Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, the structure of which mirrors that which is provided for in the Bill, includes members nominated by each State Premier and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Every government in Australia has endorsed that proposal. The State and the Northern Territory governments are to be congratulated for their co-operation and support of the National Commission. It is to be hoped that their current positive attitudes will not be influenced by the negativism displayed by the Opposition so far during this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, this Bill before the House is the product of sustained dialogue within the States and Territories with employers and the unions. It has been developed in the full spirit of co-operation. The honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) has already alluded to the fact that groups such as the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Confederation of Australian Industry were in agreement at all stages of the development of the national focus and strategy. Interestingly enough, on two previous occasions, so too was the Opposition.

Further evidence of this universal agreement on the need for a national strategy to improve occupational health and safety is readily obtainable. The National Economic Summit Conference in April 1983 called for a national occupational health and safety strategy. The National Labour Consultative Council has endorsed the establishment of the National Commission to develop and implement a national strategy. Even the Opposition health policy which was issued on 30 October 1984 stated:
The Liberal and National Parties support the development of a national strategy to improve performance in occupational health and safety . . .

Every employee at risk and every employer with a legal responsibility for the occupational health and safety of employees will welcome the establishment of the National Commission to develop national preventive strategies. It is a pity that it is not being welcomed by the Opposition.

Some attention has already been paid to the extent of this problem. Conservative estimates are that more than $6 billion a year is wasted through loss of production and associated costs because of occupational injury and ill health and that about 300 people are killed and a further 150,000 people are injured each year in work-related accidents. This is a gigantic social, human and economic penalty which can be reduced significantly only by concerted action on a national scale. This Bill represents the first substantial legislation by a Federal government to bring about a change for the better in the working environment. Recent New South Wales figures that have come to hand show that about $205m was paid in compensation under the New South Wales Workers' Compensation Act in the financial year 1982-83, which was in fact an increase of nearly $100m over the figure for the previous year. The figures tabled on the first day of the 1985 sittings of the New South Wales Parliament are confirmation of what employers and insurers have known for years-that the cost of workers compensation is not only growing but growing at an alarming rate. It seems that the answer is clear. Injured workers must be rehabilitated and returned to work in the minimum of time. The aim, therefore, of occupational health is quite simply to reduce these sorts of figures and to put industry back on a very strong footing. There is a need to prevent accidents by teaching the right way to handle certain tasks, to treat injured workers quickly and effectively to ensure a speedy return to work and in the process to check the alarming growth in compensation payments and the rises in insurance premiums that go with it.

It is important to take cognisance during this debate of some of the areas where occupational health and safety standards need to be improved. I can speak with some knowledge and with some conviction on this subject because, unlike the honourable member for Tangey, I come from an industrial city. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West), who was in the chamber tonight, and I represent a most significant part of Australia's industrial growth area. During the development of the Interim National Commission an organisation was formed on the south coast. It was called the South Coast Occupational Health Coalition. It was concerned with putting together a package which spelt out quite clearly for all the workers in the industrial scene on the south coast, and certainly extending right to the Victorian border, the need for formal and clear guidelines for occupational health and safety. This organisation had the support of the Illawarra Migrant Resource Centre, the South Coast Labour Council, various unions in their own right, the South Coast Workers Medical Centre and the Wollongong Women's Centre.

The South Coast Coalition, in its deliberations in preparing a submission to the Interim Commission, looked at a number of basic problem areas and dwelt upon the problems that would be faced by workers and therefore the need for the National Occupational Health and Safety Commissions. In particular I refer to the problems in the basic metal manufacturing industry for which Port Kembla is famous world wide. Workers within that industry, within the steel works, are exposed daily to a full range of industrial health hazards. These include gases and vapours from carbon monoxide, hydrogen sulphide and so on, which emanate from slag pits and metal furnaces, and aerosols such as acid mists coming from electrolytic bars. We have physical hazards such as heat, noise and vibration, biological hazards; safety hazards such as fire and accidents; and chemical hazards. The underground coal mining industry, of which again I have some knowledge, is one of the most hazardous areas of work. In the last decade the frequency rate of lost time accidents in the industry in New South Wales has almost doubled. Fifty-five per cent of those accidents occurred in the southern mine districts. Most fatalities and injuries associated with that are caused by difficult working conditions.

Within women's occupational health and safety problems, a number of particular issues can be identified. I refer particularly to work where repetitious activity is necessary. Repetition strain injury has become the most important problem. Out-workers, office workers and so on are all exposed to this problem. Shift workers suffer from emotional problems, and occupational health and safety must make allowances for that.

I referred to the fact that these were problems which had developed and for which a solution must be sought. I believe some solutions have been advanced. Certainly, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill before us tonight will go a great deal of the way towards overcoming those problems because the problem is first and foremost a national one. In the States a series of different organisations has been established to deal with this problem on an individual basis. But a national program is certainly needed. One such area which unfortunately is handled by private enterprise is the Illawarra Rehabilitation Centre which is located at Thirroul in my electorate. It was set up to look after the interests of people suffering from occupational health and safety conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does a good job.

—It does an excellent job. It does so because it has looked at the problems in the work place and has tried to do something about them by recreating a work environment to teach people how to lift properly and how to carry things properly. Workers are rehabilitated back into the work place as quickly as possible. But it is not a patch-up job. People are not just fixed up to a certain level and told 'Back to work you go, son', and that is it. It is done in stages. Specific testing mechanisms are used to see whether a worker can go back to the work place after a graduated period. A full report is supplied to the employer stating how quickly that person can return to a full working life. That is most important. It is extremely important because it gives a person a sense of self-esteem and, after all, that is really what we are looking for.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government considers that the establishment of the National Commission is the most cost effective means of achieving an improvement in the appalling record of industrial accidents and injuries. The cost effectiveness, which has been touched on here, of the Government's approach has already been demonstrated through the access to international occupational health and safety data bases which the National Commission has arranged. United Kingdom, Canadian and International Labour Organisation data bases have been provided more readily to the Interim National Commission because it is a single, national body. The Interim National Commission in turn is making information from these data bases readily available to the States, Territories and the social partners.

The reduction in occupational hazards which will result from the work of the National Commission will materially assist in the reduction of workers' compensation premiums. These additional labour costs are very significant to medium and small businesses which have the capacity to employ many Australians. Yet we hear those on the other side of the House say that they are not concerned about this aspect. I cannot believe that those who purport to represent small business can come forward and actually say those sorts of things. The National Commission, by this legislation, will be given powers of inquiry which are an essential element of any preventative approach to occupational health and safety. Parliament itself has established inquiries into hazardous chemicals and the exposure of Aboriginal communities to the dangers associated with asbestos. The availability of such powers will contribute to a reduction in the possibility of a major disaster in Australia such as that which occurred at Bhopal in India. I am sure that every member of this House would support such action.

In conclusion, I say that the problems to which I have alluded here are problems which need to be remedied. It is my view that the proposed Commission will seek to remedy some of them, not least of which is the Commission aim to provide a forum for the discussion of occupational health and safety issues and, through the promotion of community awareness of occupational health and safety, to redress any notions that injuries and disease resulting from work are an accepted or inevitable by-product of the labour process. Workers and employers will be encouraged to discuss areas of concern in the working environment, including any of the types of problems I have already identified. I certainly commend the Minister for his initiative and foresight in bringing down such an important milestone in industrial legislation. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill is to establish the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, yet another statutory corporation and quango. It is not enough that the Commonwealth has already established 338 statutory bodies and 307 non-statutory bodies. In Victoria the situation is worse. There are 9,000 quangos, of which 1,000 are considered to be significant. Until recently most of these bodies failed to report adequately their activities or financial operations. The public, and perhaps more importantly the taxpayers, hardly know many of them exist, what benefits-or lack of them-they provide, how much they spend, or to what degree they are responsible for the intrusion into and regulation of their lives and work practices. Here we are, not having learnt anything, proposing to set up yet another statutory body that undoubtedly will grow like topsy and demand ever increasing amounts of revenue, all to provide dubious benefits for workers and employers, not to mention taxpayers.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody would argue that the health and well being of everyone in the work force and their families is not of fundamental importance. What is of even greater importance is how best we can achieve their health and well being. I do not believe that a Canberra-based bureaucracy will be able to ensure that a worker puts on his protective helmet or ear muffs or even that a worker returns to work as soon as practicable after injury without further jeopardising his own recovery or causing strain or injury to co-workers. Only action on the shop floor, with incentives or even penalties to encourage both workers and management to be responsible for safer work practices, will bring about a situation wherein safety equipment is used and attendance at work brings about greater financial returns than do workers compensation payments at home.

The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) referred in his second reading speech to the $6 billion wastage through loss of production and associated costs of occupational injury and ill health. I suggest to honourable members that the $6 billion wastage is due more to the lack of incentive to return to work after injury. There are just no incentives in Australia to return to work when workers' compensation payments provide 85 per cent of salary and even 100 per cent when the employer makes up the difference. This contrasts noticeably with the situation in the United States of America, where compensation payments make up 50 per cent of salary, and with the bonus system based on units of output the worker could end up receiving 30 per cent of his normal take home pay. Unless there is an incentive to return to work no amount of expensive, centralised, bureaucratic commissions, institutes or committees will succeed in regulating or educating workers to the merits of working rather than receiving workers compensation premiums at home. The $6 billion will continue to grow.

Clause 8 refers to the principal functions of the Bill. Some of these functions have very questionable implications. Take the sub-clause that proposes recommendations for action by Australia, which states:
. . . to comply with the provisions of any international instrument relating to occupational health and safety matters.

It is bad enough that we have Australian State and Federal politicians and bureaucrats regulating shop floor activity let alone Geneva based International Labour Organisation ideologues telling us how we should manage our affairs. Overseas experience tells us that these sorts of government initiatives provide little benefit at great cost. Alan Saunders, the technical director of the corporate underwriting group of companies from Sydney, when speaking at a national conference on overseas trends in occupational health, quoted the reaction of 1,600 delegates at the National Safety Congress in Chicago. He had this to say:
The almost universal reaction from people I spoke to was that the Occupational Safety and Health Act, which has now been in force for ten years, is an abject failure.

the general consensus is the OSHA has cost a lot of money and has not achieved anything very much. Over the past ten years lost time injuries have increased by 25% and lost days have increased by 34%. This is not matched by the population increase over that time which has been about 1% per year. Obviously OSHA is not an occupational and safety health program, but has set itself up as a policeman to report and fine on mechanical breaches of the Act.

The proposed budget for the Commission as set out in the report is a minimum of $24m in the first year, and $41m will be required in the second year for the activities of the Commission. The Commission will employ some 300 persons. Also incorporated in that budget is an item of $7.5m for training. There is no allowance for superannuation on-costs. I put it to honourable members that they should consider the full cost of this Commission in 10 years time in real and money terms. Although the Minister says in his speech that the major jurisdiction over occupational health and safety will remain with the States, I can find nothing in the Bill that actually ensures that there will be no duplication of awards or codes of practice. If the intent of the Bill is maintained, why is there any reason to duplicate State regulatory activities with an expensive bureaucracy based in Canberra?

I turn now to the Victorian legislation, to which the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) referred. The Victorian Government had a proposal before the Parliament for an occupational health measure, a vital component of which had been drawn up by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. The safety officer elected by the union officials was to be able to call an immediate stop-work on the shop floor and the management was to have no say in that decision either on the shop floor or in the factory. If this proposal had been incorporated in the Act one could imagine the industrial muscle that that would have given union delegates. The concrete pour syndrome which is so evident in the building industry in Victoria would have been further entrenched. Just imagine what would happen at the Alcoa company, which has a continuous process of manufacture, if a safety official was able to turn off the plant without any redress by the management or any discussion.

Further sub-clauses in the Bill refer to the declaration, encouragement and evaluation of national standards and codes of practice. It never ceases to amaze me how we continually kid ourselves that either we or the deputies of the statutory authorities are better placed to set standards rather than those people actually involved in the activities we seek to regulate. The attitude of the management and the work force in the work place are key elements. Other key elements are the human factor and the participation by those involved. I have had occasion to discuss these matters with a major manufacturing company where through a positive approach the management and the unions involved have arranged for a meeting of union personnel and the foreman once a month in eight sections of the plant. There is a meeting at the end of each month where discussions on safety matters take place-matters such as safety glasses, helmets, safety boots and protective clothing. In this arena there has been good progress when there has been an understanding of the problem.

I have no doubt that the worker probably faces the greatest risk in travelling to and from the work place in a motor vehicle. How do we propose to solve that problem? We already have an inordinate degree of regulation governing road travel. Police forces try to protect us from ourselves when we drive from point A to point B, but still we have death and carnage on the roads. Million dollar qangos will not fix errors of judgment on the part of individuals. Finally, co-operation, understanding and a degree of common sense between management and the work force will greatly assist in solving this industrial safety problem. I have worked in high risk industry and I am sure that a $41m Commission will not protect other Australians or me from work related injuries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand Mr G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to rise in wholehearted support of this historic Bill-the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill. It is an historic occasion that we are tonight debating this all important issue. I am somewhat disturbed by the fact that the Opposition is not inclined in any way to support this historic piece of legislation. This is a Bill which, while long overdue, marks the beginning of a new approach to occupational health and safety matters in this country. At the very heart of this legislation is the fact that, for the first time, we have before us a national strategy which attacks a national problem-that is, injury and disease in the work place.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us not underestimate the size of the national problem which is involved. What we are talking about, as previous speakers from this side of the House have mentioned, is the fact that some 300 people die per year and an estimated 150,000 people are injured. In anyone's terms the loss and suffering in these two areas is totally unacceptable. I am still bewildered by the speech of the shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), when he said that the Opposition totally opposes this legislation. While there has been reform in a number of Labor States over the last decade, which has led to significant improvements in this area, the fundamental problem of a fragmented and inequitable response remains. This will be overcome only with the implementation of a nationally co-ordinated approach to occupational health and safety matters.

For me, occupational health and safety marks one of the Australian Labor Party's most important policy areas. This enabling Bill, which establishes a permanent National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, represents one of the more significant pieces of social reform legislation introduced by this Government. The pitiful neglect of occupational health and safety matters at the national level is well understood by honourable members on this side of the House, if not by those opposite who, when given the opportunity to do something, actually reduced Commonwealth involvement in this area, on the ground that it was a State matter. That is not the view endorsed by my Party.

I think it is a mark of this Government's commitment to improving occupational health and safety that we have acted so swiftly in bringing our policy to fruition, especially in the context of the long consultative process entered into with the States, Territories, employers and unions. Of course, without the consultative process we would be debating this legislation in a vacuum. As the Labor Government has recognised in response to many issues, but nowhere more justifiably than in this instance, the success of our strategy depends on the level of support that we obtain from the parties which will have to make this policy work in practice.

As the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) said in his second reading speech, this Bill has been developed in a spirit of full co-operation and with a recognition of the appropriate areas of responsibility by all the parties. It has the support of the unions' peak council, the Australian Council of Trade Unions-I am always proud to associate myself with the ACTU; I have no problems with that, in view of the criticism of that body by the Opposition in the last couple of days-and one of the biggest employer groups, the Confederation of Australian Industry. The Bill is premised upon a number of principles which indicate a changed conceptual outlook about how we approach occupational health and safety matters. Essentially, this new approach challenges and rejects the antiquated nineteenth century British model, with its emphasis on protection. This is the model upon which all of our original State health and safety laws were predicated. In its place the newer legislation emphasises a preventive strategy which recognises the need for structures, measures and controls directed towards finding and removing the causes of occupational injury and disease.

The clearest definition of policy principles on occupational health and safety endorsed by the Australian Labor Party and by the trade union movement are set out in the prices and incomes accord. It says, inter alia, that the work environment needs to be adapted and designed to suit the needs of people working in it. I do not think anybody would disagree with that, or should not. Employers have a basic responsibility to provide a healthy, safe, stress-free work environment, and workers have the right to know what hazards they are exposed to.

One thing that is a great worry in my electorate and industries within it is the high component of migrants that work within those industries. One of the great difficulties that employers and workers face is being unable to explain to people who are not able to communicate in our language, the problems or dangers they face on the job. That is a fundamental right that workers ought to have. I believe this legislation will assist greatly in overcoming that problem. The accord further states that peak councils of unions and employers at the national level have the right to set standards of health and safety in the work force and that unions and union appointed workers health and safety representatives, meeting with management in health and safety committees at the local level, have the right to set standards of health and safety in the work place. The basic means by which these principles are to be realised include, first and foremost, the involvement of employers and unions in setting health and safety standards at the national level through the establishment of a tripartite national occupational health and safety commission responsible to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations.

This Bill represents the fulfilment of that aspect of the accord and the culmination of a consultative process which included the National Economic Summit Conference, the National Labour Consultative Council and the discussions between the various parties and the Minister. In turn, these consultative procedures led to the establishment of the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in 1983. In May 1984 the report of the Interim Commission was released. It laid the foundation for the national strategy and action plan and the enabling legislation which we are now debating. The key elements of that strategy are directed towards overcoming the major deficiencies in our institutional and legislative framework. The major areas of concern include: Developing and co-ordinating national uniform standards; developing procedures for the notification of occupational ill health and injury; information collection, storage and dissemination; research and development; and training and education. We believe that these areas are best developed at the national level so that a uniform approach is adopted and valuable resources are not dissipated.

The structures and functions of the Commission, as set out in the Bill, give effect to the Commonwealth's fulfulling this co-ordinating role. The broad objectives of the Commission are as follows: Firstly, to develop amongst the community an awareness of the issues relating to occupational health and safety matters and to facilitate public debate on them. The more we talk about these problems, I am sure all honourable members of the House would agree, the bigger the chances of overcoming some of the injury risks on the job. The second is to provide a forum where all parties can consult and debate matters of relevance in this respect. The tripartite structure of the Commission creates an institutional framework which ensures both a philosophical and practical commitment exists which is necessary to make the national strategy work. The third broad objective is to develop a national focus for activities.

Much of the work which the Commission will undertake has been initiated by trade unions in recent years. It should be pointed out to the House that without the pressure which the union movement has applied, this issue would not have received the recognition it so clearly warrants. Many unions have increased their efforts and resources to eliminate hazards in the work place and to heighten awareness of occupational health and safety issues among the workers on the job, and particularly their own members. If the national strategy is to work it is essential that the unions continue with the development of their own policies which can then be channelled into the national strategy. Likewise, it is absolutely vital to have the support of the State governments, for it must be understood that the major jurisdiction in occupational health and safety matters lies with the States.
