As pointed out previously, some State governments have introduced reforming legislation similar to this Bill. However, as one would expect the Queensland legislation remains in a nineteenth century backwater.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense! Utter nonsense!
—It is true. I suggest that the honourable member goes up there and talks to the people in the various jobs.
—I come from there.

—I know the honourable member comes from there but he does not talk to any workers; we all know that. If he talks to the people on the job he might find out what the problems are. Of all the State legislation, the Victorian Bill represents the model which I believe most closely approximates the aims and objectives of this legislation and the approach taken by the Federal Government. It would be a tragedy for the whole future of this issue if that legislation failed to pass the upper House in that State. If members of the Opposition are genuine in their concern for workers in this country and particularly in Victoria, they will get behind the Victorian Government and support that proposal. They will convince their State colleagues in the upper House to let that legislation go through. I understand that it was introduced in Victoria either today or yesterday. I am not quite sure, but I think it was this morning.

SPEECH.PARA: The major stumbling block, of course, is that the Victorian Bill provides workers' health and safety representatives with powers which those opposite believe are too great. But if the process is to work effectively it is crucial that union-nominated health and safety representatives are involved in the decision-making process concerning safety on the job. We cannot apply rules and regulations which exclude those people whom they affect. I agree with the Opposition spokesman in this area about the high cost to industry of injury on the job. It is enormous, but it is more of a concern to these people who suffer such injuries. We have to prevent that occurring. The hardship and the suffering of families of workers who are injured has to be stopped and this legislation, as I said, will go a long way towards doing that. The Victorian proposal was endorsed by the Minister when he announced the establishment of the Interim Health and Safety Commission in November 1983. It is enshrined also in the accord.

As the Minister said in his second reading speech, this Bill represents one of three in this area. The next will provide a legislative framework for Commonwealth employees and workers throughout the Australian Capital Territory and the external Territories. I believe that if we are genuinely committed to ongoing reform which will improve the quality of working life in this country we must as a government-I hope the Opposition will join us-show the way in this area. The Federal Government has powers beyond those of the States. It has the ability to bring the States together and, by pooling the information that comes through those States that are co-operating, show the other States where they are going wrong. It can bring that information together and improve the health and safety problems that currently exist on the factory floor, at the workface or, for that matter, on the farm of the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur).

The next phase of our occupational health and safety legislative program will be the testing point. Only if the Commonwealth jurisdiction has an effective legislative model will our attempts to work in co-operation with the States to develop a nationally co-ordinated health and safety initiative significantly reshape the basic framework in which we currently operate. I look forward to supporting that next phase in the implementation of our policy.

As a person who worked on a factory floor and who suffered injuries from time to time, as a former member of the blue collar work force, I make a plea to the Opposition. Quite frankly, I find it astounding that people in this House can reject this issue out of hand. I cannot for the life of me understand the Opposition rejecting a proposal such as this when, as a shop steward, I have seen people injured because they are unable to read signs on walls or because they have not been told about the problems of machinery. I cannot understand how the shadow Minister can acknowledge the death of three hundred people in the work force and the fact that 150,000 people have suffered injuries in the work force and, at the conclusion of his speech, say: 'Of course, the Opposition is totally opposed to this proposal'. If honourable members opposite believe that these things are bad-300 people dying and 150,000 being injured-they ought to have the guts to put up the amendments or the alterations they consider necessary to improve the Bill. They have engaged in an exercise of running away from the problem. They have taken the easy way out.

Honourable members opposite should go on to the factory floors and tell the people on those factory floors that they are totally opposed to the introduction of legislation that will bring about a change to the risks those people face. Most of those opposite have probably never been on a factory floor and do not know what it is like. They do not know what it is like to be hurt; most of them have never gone on workers compensation and had to rear families, or look after them, while they have been too sick to go to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense.

—That is not nonsense. Most honourable members opposite are in that category. It is obviously not nonsense; otherwise they would try to do something to rectify the problems. In seven years of government they did nothing. Now, when we are in government, what are they doing? They are trying to knock over a genuine attempt-in fact a harmless attempt, from their point of view, as it will cost them nothing to support it-to introduce legislation which will bring about the saving of human life and a reduction of suffering in the work force, a reduction in the suffering of working class people.

SPEECH.PARA: All the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) can do is lie back with a smirk all over his gob, grin and nudge his mate next to him and say that it is all nonsense. Well, it is not all nonsense. He should go out and talk to those people who get hurt and tell them it is nonsense. I make a plea to honourable members opposite. They might reject this legislation here but I ask them to talk about it with their Senate colleagues. Do not oppose it in the Senate. Let it go through, and if the legislation needs improving we will make those improvements as we go along. Do not reject it out of hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by re-emphasising that the Opposition is acutely aware of the problems of health and safety in the work place, and it is both intellectually and morally dishonest for people such as the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) to suggest that our commitment to the issues of occupational health and safety is anything less than total. The only basis for debate is determining what is the best and the most efficient way of improving Australia's record in this field.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members are aware that Australia's record in the field of occupational health and safety is, in global terms, one of the worst. In early 1984 the National Safety Council claimed that Australia had the third highest work place accident record in the world. While different industrial and economic structures and different statistical methods, can make international comparisons fairly misleading, such casuistry in no way detracts from the fact that our record is poor. As previous speakers have pointed out, official figures show that accidents at work kill some 300 Australians each year and injure another 150,000.

While the human loss is the principle concern, it is also important to remember that the cost of work-related accidents is, as others have said, conservatively estimated at around $6 billion, which is twice the cost to the nation of road accidents and easily exceeds the cost of industrial disputation. In my State of South Australia alone, the annual cost of work-related accidents is around $500m. These figures are at least part of the explanation as to why workers compensation premiums cost Australian industry $1.7 billion in 1982-83, which is the latest year for which I could find figures. I make no secret of my concern about the advent of new technology and the growing use of chemicals in the work place, and the effect that this has on both accidents and the potential for accidents in the future to get worse. The report of the Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission referred to the problem of hazardous chemicals. Those of us who have worked in both the private and public sectors, in particular with keyboard equipment, are only too aware of the problem of repetition strain injuries.

None of us is in any doubt that action must be taken to confront these problems. The only question is whether the proposals put forward by the Government in this Bill offer the right path to a more acceptable occupational health and safety record. Several points need to be made about this. Occupational health and safety is constitutionally a matter for State governments except, of course, in relation to Commonwealth employees and employees working within Commonwealth Territories. The responsibility for the high incidence of work-related accidents must rest ultimately, of course, with employers and employees themselves. But it must also rest with State governments. Many State governments have given a rather low priority to occupational health and safety matters for decades and although all States have in one way or another legislated in this field, that legislation is disparate and unco-ordinated. In the case of South Australia, for example, there are 19 pieces of legislation which contain occupational health and safety provisions. Altogether in Australia there are 166 separate and often unco-ordinated pieces of legislation relating to this issue.

The fact is that we need some kind of national strategy on this issue. The onus rests very firmly on the States to move to co-ordinate and rationalise their legislation. It is surprising that no real effort has been made already to co-ordinate this legislation through a body such as the National Safety Council which this year received $170,000 from the Federal Government. That strategy has to be worked out in co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth Government. Action should be taken to ensure that firms, particularly small firms and firms involved in new technology which have not maximised health and safety provisions, should be encouraged to do so. A decision by a firm to raise its levels of work place health and safety may well be a beneficial investment, not just in terms of individual welfare, which is ultimately important, but in terms of the overall cost structure of the firm.

Instead of taking these sorts of general steps, and doing so in a way which is conducive to the enhancement of employee welfare and corporate profitability, the Labor State governments have been preoccupied with the development of health and safety legislation which, to quote the Business Council of Australia, is 'seriously disruptive and damaging'. This legislation has been introduced without any thought being given to the need to have co-operative legislation and co-operative action with the Commonwealth Government.

In my State of South Australia the Labor Government has proposed that a union appointed worker safety representative should have the power unilaterally to close down a plant if that sole representative judges that safety standards are inadequate. Under this socialist legislation, total power would be given to the unions. There would be no negotiations, no discussion and no thought on how to rectify what may be a perfectly simple problem. No consultation would take place with other employees either. The whole plant would be brought to a halt.

Victorian members are aware that similar legislation has been proposed in their State. It is also being proposed in Western Australia. As the Business Council of Australia says, these proposals are of 'serious concern'. The South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has said that these sorts of proposals were examples of 'the them and us syndrome' typical of the industrial system. The Chamber has gone on to say that the South Australian business community-this is a typical view-is willing to co-operate with the Government and the unions to achieve significant improvements in health and safety and to lower compensation costs. But as the Chamber has pointed out, the proposed South Australian legislation is totally divisive. It would give union appointed representatives a mortgage on work safety and there is no doubt that that position would be repeatedly abused for political rather than safety purposes.

For the record, I note that the Victorian Government's legislation of this kind is to proceed following the re-election of the Cain Government. The honourable member for Melbourne referred to it being introduced either yesterday or today. In South Australia the State Government proposes to introduce this legislation in the extremely unlikely and hypothetical event of it winning the next State election. However, I remind the House that both of those proposals have been introduced regardless of anything the Commonwealth Government may have been considering. But what, above all, is worrying is that the Federal Government also intends, following the establishment of its Commission, to proceed with similar legislation.

The infamous prices and incomes accord says that union representatives should have the right to close a whole plant pending the arbitration inspector's decision. The whole works, as with the State legislation, can be closed under law at the whim of a trade union official. As with the State legislation, this provision has enormous scope for abuse and is frankly totally undemocratic. It is consequently being vigorously opposed not only by the Liberal Party of Australia, but also by the business community. What worries me is that once this Commission is established this anti-business, union-demanded measure will be introduced as it is signed. If it is, it will be yet another example of the Government putting the interests of the unions before the proper interests of Australians.

I should like briefly to make a few specific comments about the Commission which is to be established by this Bill. For all its rhetoric about consensus, the Government has consulted only one business group in the drawing up of the Commission, and that is the Confederation of Australian Industry. While I welcome the CAI's involvement, it is extraordinary that groups such as the Business Council of Australia have not even been notified of the introduction of this legislation, let alone consulted. Yet it is big business, represented in effect by the Business Council of Australia, which has the best safety record in Australia and which has done the most to promote health and safety. The last time the Business Council of Australia and other business groups were consulted on this issue was at an informal meeting in February 1984, convened not by the Government but by the Confederation of Australian Industry. At that meeting, which I attended, the relative business groups all agreed that in taking steps to improve occupational health and safety the Government should avoid costly bureaucracy. They also expressed concern that the public sector could become a pacemaker setting standards which would be too complex and too expensive for business to follow.

Yet what the Government has decided to do is to establish a commission with no fewer than 17 members, who have to be flown from every corner of Australia. This Commission is, in effect, with its 17 members, a form of permanent summit. That contrasts rather unfavourably with that irrelevant bureaucracy, the Prices Surveillance Authority, which for all its faults comprises, I think, just four members. I also note that the Commission includes three business members. I welcome the involvement of the business sector in this sort of exercise, but all those business members are to be nominated by just one business association, and that is the Confederation of Australian Industry. There are, again, to be no representatives from groups such as the Business Council of Australia or the Chambers of Commerce and there will be no representative from that great forgotten sector, the small business sector, which will be seriously affected by regulations set down by the Commission. One can only wonder why, with all those members, the Government cannot find a place on the board for small business representatives in particular.

The correct solutions to these issues of workers safety will eventually rest with consultation in the work place and not with some sort of corporate State structure which depersonalises issues which ultimately are of very fundamental personal concern to the employees and the employers. It is interesting that the Australian Labor Party, in its policies, has recognised this fact. I welcome its recognition of that and, indeed, it is something which has been recognised by the employers as well.

I should like to end where I began and state once more that the whole issue of occupational health and safety is of vast importance to Australia and is a matter of very great concern to the Opposition, just as I concede it clearly is to the Government. This Bill still leaves many questions unanswered. There is still a great deal of work to be done on this issue and there is also a great deal of concern to all of us about the role of the trade union movement in drafting future legislation which may emanate from this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill is centrally important for it addresses a major problem. There can be few people who have not suffered or who do not know someone who has suffered from a disease or injury related to his or her work. The dangers of industrial chemicals, asbestos, injury from unsafe working conditions in factories and on building sites, and repetition strain injury, for example, are now widely recognised. Yet the lack of an organisational structure for dealing with occupational health and safety has contributed to the neglect of major problems, such as the current epidemic of repetition strain injury.

SPEECH.PARA: There are no national statistics on repetition strain injury, just as there are no comprehensive statistics on any aspect of occupational health and safety. A recent survey within the Public Service revealed over 3,000 sufferers, almost half of them in Canberra. Yet within Canberra there are no clinics for treatment or support services available for repetition strain injury victims. Until now there has been no national organisation with responsibility for this type of problem. The Government came to office determined to fill that gap. This commitment was endorsed by the National Economic Summit Conference--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a fraud.

—It was an agreed representative summit which stated in its final communique that the summit 'believes that the nation must give occupational health and safety a greater priority and endorses the need for concerted government, employer and union action to improve the quality of the working environment in Australia'. That was agreed by all employers, all community groups, all unions, and all but one State government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government acted promptly to achieve that goal. An Interim National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was appointed. The Commission included members representative of national employer organisations, unions and State and Commonwealth governments. Dr Richie Gun, an expert in the field with international experience, was Chairman. As requested, the Commission completed its report within six months. The report was unanimous and therefore maintained the momentum of agreement based on national tripartite consultation. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), who spoke previously, would have us believe that this was all union inspired. It has been just as much endorsed by employers. When the report was tabled it was welcomed and supported by the Opposition spokesman. That bipartisan support continued when the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) announced last October the Government's acceptance of the Commission's recommendations.

Since then the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill to establish permanently the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has been prepared. The effectiveness and speed with which this whole process has been completed is a great credit to the members and staff of the interim and the non-statutory commissions. I particularly praise the dedicated, sustained work of Mr Jim Brassil, Mrs Joan Uhr, and their staff. This Bill is an outstanding result of a process of consultation with employers, unions and State governments. It exemplifies the benefit of close consultation in the context of a strong government commitment to solving a major problem.

The Bill involves establishing the institutions which are necessary for a concerted attack on occupational disease and injury. Until tonight there has been no disagreement with this goal or strategy, but tonight the Opposition made the extraordinary announcement that it opposes the Bill. One wonders whether the shadow Minister really understands what he is talking about. There was some evidence in his speech that he does not because he talked about the Commission staff entering work places, imposing fines and having horrendous powers. The Commission will have none of those powers, except to a limited extent in the Australian Capital Territory. Mr Braithwaite said that the Commission and Institute will be costly and will involve the establishment of a statutory authority. Of course there is some cost-$12m this year-but that is not the central issue. The important question is whether those funds are being cost effectively spent. There can be no doubt that they are. There is certainly no doubt about the need. The national cost of lost production of goods and services because of occupational injury and disease was greater than that from time lost through strikes, even at the peak periods of industrial conflict in the later years of the Fraser Government. The Opposition surely ought to be concerned about that. As the Minister said in introducing the Bill:

The nation as a whole is incurring enormous losses from unsafe and unhealthy working environments. Individual employees suffer the hardship of physical pain, disabilities and loss of income. Employers bear losses through reduced output and higher workers compensation premiums. The community as a whole faces higher prices and taxes to meet the spiralling costs of occupational injury and ill health.

The Government's approach will steadily reduce costs for employers and reduce hardship for employees. Some of the States have taken significant initiatives recently. This Bill does not reduce their responsibility. However, it is essential that there be national arrangements for co-ordination and facilitation as well as prompt upgrading of the Commonwealth's activities in its own areas of responsibility-the Australian Capital Territory and Commonwealth employment. Many types of activities, such as research, the setting of standards and the circulation of information, can be cost effectively undertaken only by the Commonwealth and the States acting together. It would be simply wasteful for each State to set up its own research program and to try to collect the huge quantity of information required in isolation from the other States. Establishment of a commission with membership from all States, employers and unions is the most effective means of achieving this. The Opposition spokesman simply has not thought through his opinions. One wonders why the Opposition is opposing this Bill. Is it simply a wish to establish political distance-to show that it is different by opposing anything the Government does?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bad Bill.

—It is an excellent Bill. It is a necessary Bill. It is an essential Bill. Perhaps the Opposition spokesman wants to show that he is a dry; that he is opposed to any form of public sector intervention in the private sector. That is hardly a tenable position in this area because government neglect of occupational disease and injury has allowed the massive national economic and personal damage to occur. That simply cannot be allowed to continue. Government action is clearly essential. That action is being taken with the support of employers, unions and all State governments. All groups recognise the costs of continuing neglect and the enormous benefits that effective preventive action can achieve. Therefore, the Opposition's position is both irresponsible and without support. It is also entirely inconsistent with its earlier policy. Only last October the Opposition spokesman said:

SPEECH.PARA: Occupational safety, health and welfare is an issue which transcends party policies.
He went on to say:
The commitment of the Opposition's policy to reduce the personal suffering and economic loss as well as the loss of productivity to the country in coping with these matters is well recorded.

It cannot be recorded any longer. The Opposition now seems to be more interested in ideological purity than in the well-being of workers and the economy. The non-statutory Commission has already begun work. One of its first actions was to set up a national committee to report on the repetition strain injury epidemic which I mentioned earlier. That committee has almost completed its report. After it has been presented to the National Commission, it is expected to be released in July. The report will recommend ways of preventing RSI, of managing the problem, and will also suggest types of research which should be undertaken and rehabilitation programs. This is one example of the kind of work enabled by the establishment of the Commission.

Before concluding, I briefly mention action planned for the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister mentioned in his second reading speech that later this year he will be introducing a Bill relating to occupational health and safety within the Australian Capital Territory. Drafting of that Bill is well advanced. It covers a general duty of care relating to all workers and work places within the Australian Capital Territory. The responsibilities required of employers, the self-employed and workers are set out. Regulations will be made under the Act relating to specific hazards such as asbestos, scaffolding, machinery safety and noise. This Bill will, therefore, be a great advance on the present situation in the Australian Capital Territory as currently there is next to no legislative coverage of occupational health and safety. The Australian Capital Territory is represented on the National Commission by Dr Ben Sellinger. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has already established an Australian Capital Territory standing committee. The Executive of the National Commission is to meet with the Australian Capital Territory standing committee next week to discuss particular problems within the Australian Capital Territory. Finally, a Director of Occupational Health and Safety in the Australian Capital Territory is about to be appointed.

There has been considerable frustration about the time taken to get to this stage within the Australian Capital Territory. However, the steps which have been taken recently show that the Government is working hard to introduce effective occupational health and safety arrangements here as in the rest of Australia. This is an historic Bill. It will create the basis for safer and healthier working environments. It gives great satisfaction to be able to commend it wholeheartedly to the House.
Friday, 10 May 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank those members of the Opposition and of the Government Party who contributed to the debate. This is extremely important legislation that the Government is attempting to pass tonight. Indeed, it is historic legislation. I know from practical experience gained when I was Minister for Defence Support of the very considerable occupational health and safety problems that existed within the various government establishments which were part of that Department. One of the things that struck me most forcibly when I was in that position was the lack of basic statistical information in order to be able to build up over a period a picture of the causes of injury and occupational disease.

SPEECH.PARA: Previously, when I was in opposition, I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, which carried out a major inquiry into the subject of hazardous chemicals. I believe that that inquiry in many respects was a path breaking inquiry and that the Parliament will come back to its report more than once. It assembled for the first time a limited but, relatively speaking, comprehensive picture of the problems of hazardous chemicals within the community, particularly within industry. In this country we have had a notorious record in terms of the way we have accepted into the country many very dangerous chemicals without any testing whatever having been done in this country. Very often those chemicals have not been effectively tested overseas. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill establishes the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. Given the statistics to which the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) was referring, it is amazing that in 1985, after the best part of a century of manufacturing industry in this country, we are only now establishing a national approach to occupational health and safety.

I must say that I have been somewhat surprised by the attitude of the Opposition. I remember that when the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) was a Minister of the previous Government-I think he was the Minister for Productivity-he concerned himself very much with problems of occupational health and safety as well as with a number of other problems to do with the working environment. Indeed, his work in the Department of Productivity was remembered in the Department of Defence Support, which inherited sections of the Department of Productivity, with considerable admiration because the honourable member was prepared to face issues such as the occupational health and safety issue. I remember a number of occasions in this House when that Minister referred to the disastrous record of this country and the appalling loss of time as a result of occupational injuries.

It is very interesting that members of the Opposition who are so enthusiastic about talking about industrial conflict and time lost through industrial conflict so rarely refer to the fact that we lose much more in productivity in this country, as the honourable member for Goldstein often suggested, from the failure to have proper standards in the area of occupational health and safety than we do from our industrial relations problems. Our record in relation to industrial relations may be bad but our record has been absolutely devastating and appalling in the area of occupational health and safety.

So it has been something of a surprise to me and, I am sure, to other members of the Government to learn that this Bill will be opposed by the Opposition. I regard that opposition as little short of disgraceful, given the conditions that exist in Australian industry and given the priority that I had thought both sides of the House would give to ensuring not only safety and health but also that Australian industry becomes more efficient and more competitive. A safe working environment can be justified on economic grounds alone, notwithstanding the great contribution that is made to eliminating the needless suffering that occurs in thousands of work places across the country. I understand that the opposition is to the concept of a statutory authority. That would seem to me to be a very insubstantial basis on which to oppose this Bill.

The creation of this authority will make possible the development of a co-ordinated national strategy. It will mean that we can begin as a country to seek progressively to achieve the quality of working environment and a safe working environment that many other countries addressed throughout the post-war period. It is belated, but I believe that all members of this Parliament over time will come to recall that the establishment of this Commission meant the beginning of a new deal for workers with respect to a safe working environment.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.

The following notice was given:
Mr Jacobi to move-
(1) That a Joint Standing Committee, to be known as the Joint Standing Committee for Business Affairs, be appointed:

(a) to review- (i) Commonwealth legislation with a view to removing- (A) provisions (including provisions that require information to be furnished to a person) that impose or may impose unreasonable burdens on business and on industry, and
(B) unnecessary or out-of-date provisions;

(ii) the administrative practices of Commonwealth Departments and instrumentalities, so far as those practices have an effect upon the operations of business and industry, with a view to ensuring that those practices do not impose unreasonable burdens and demands on business and on industry;

(iii) such laws and practices with a view to ensuring that, in respect of business and industry in Australia, they comply with international obligations assumed by Australia, including through the United Nations, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and the International Labour Organisation;

(iv) suggestions for the improvement of Commonwealth laws and practices in relation to activities of business and industry, whether made by business, industry or consumer representative bodies or otherwise, and

(v) reports of commissions and other inquiries with a view to making recommendations for the enactment of laws that may be made by the Parliament concerning business, industry and consumers in Australia, and
(b) to recommend, in relation to the activities of business and industry, appropriate laws that may be made by the Parliament and that may have effect uniformly throughout Australia.

(2) That the committee, for the purpose of performing its functions, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the House.

(3) That the committee consist of 9 members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Prime Minister, the Leader of the House or the Government Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition or the Opposition Whip, 1 Member of the House of Representatives to be nominated by either the Leader of the National Party, the Deputy Leader of the National Party or the National Party Whip, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 1 Senator to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority group or groups or independent Senator or independent Senators.
(4) That every nomination of a member of the committee by forthwith notified in writing to the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives.
(5) That the members of the committee hold office as a joint standing committee until the House of Representatives is dissolved or expires by effluxion of time.
(6) That the committee elect a Government member as its chairman.

(7) That the committee elect a deputy chairman who shall perform the duties of the chairman of the committee at any time when the chairman is not present at a meeting of the committee, and at any time when the chairman and deputy chairman are not present at a meeting of the committee, the members present shall elect another member to perform the duties of the chairman at that meeting.
(8) That 3 members of the committee constitute a quorum of the committee.
(9) That the committee have power to appoint sub-committees consisting of 3 or more of its members and to refer to such a sub-committee any matter which the committee is empowered to inquire into.

(10) That the committee appoint the chairman of each sub-committee who shall have a casting vote only, and at any time when the chairman of a sub-committee is not present at a meeting of the sub-committee, the members of the sub-committee present shall elect another member of that sub-committee to perform the duties of the chairman at the meeting.
(11) That the quorum of a sub-committee be a majority of the members of that sub-committee.

(12) That members of the committee who are not members of a sub-committee may participate in the proceedings of that sub-committee but shall not vote, move any motion or be counted for the purpose of a quorum.
(13) That the committee, or any sub-committee, have power to send for persons, papers and records.
(14) That the committee, or any sub-committee, have power to move from place to place.
(15) That a sub-committee have power to adjourn from time to time and to sit during any adjournment of the Senate and of the House of Representatives.
(16) That the committee, or any sub-committee, have power to authorise publication of any evidence given before it and any document presented to it.

(17) That the committee in its inquiries take account of the investigations of other parliamentary committees, avoid duplication, and take account of the investigations of other agencies and committees.
(18) That the committee have leave to report from time to time.
(19) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the standing orders, have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders.
(20) That a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution and requesting that it concur and take action accordingly.
